We were lucky to see a bull moose on the trail, but even without that experience the trail isn't strenuous and is a great way to experience the Tetons with teens! We did take the boat back to the main area because of rain. Keep that in mind you have that option, but don't tell them!

Don't go to Yellowstone and skip the Tetons! There are so many beautiful things to see and do...something for everyone...drives, hikes, float trips, horseback riding, picnics, lakes, waterfalls...it's beautiful!
We traveled from Big Sky and the trip was worth it. The mountains are awesome and we took some great photos.
One of the most beautiful spots in US. Really - I know that is subjective but if you visit, you will see. Truly worthy of the word "awesome" as in to inspire awe.

We were a little disappointed that you are so far away from the actual mountains. We stuck to the scenic drive, which was nice but really the mountains are in the distance from the National Park. We did see lots of wildlife: elk, deer and antelope. Had a picnic lunch at Jenny Lake - beautiful!

Undeniably Grand Teton NP is a beautiful place with its iconic snow-capped mountains, clear lakes and wildlife with various trails catering to different abilities and interests. We took lots of great photos and really enjoyed the Taggart Lake trail (there's a separate review here in TA). However, GTNP is much smaller compared to Yellowstone NP. One night stay in GTNP should be enough unless you want to do in-depth exploration or trekking the various trails. We spent 4 nights in Yellowstone and were still not able to cover as much as we had wanted.
review_title: Small, Beautiful - But Different than Yellowstone

review_body: What can be said about the Tetons that hasn't been written in history books? The accommodations can be a bit pricey, but the view is unbeatable. I've been visiting Teton National Park since I was a child and my parents brought us up here regularly on the way to visit my grandmother in Wyoming. Buildings, hotels, and businesses have sprung up madly over the last 45 years, but the view is still the most beautiful in the country, in my opinion.

Grand Teton National Park is one of the most beautiful and serene spots. The views are 360°. Lots of wildlife, beautiful hikes and spectacular drives. There really are no words to describe the beauty. Just do yourself a favor & place in the top spot on your bucket list.

We passed through the park on the way to and from Yellowstone. It was amazing all the wildlife we were able to see in a short period of time. We saw pronghorn, a moose and a grey wolf in the span of about an hour. The mountains are breathe taking.

This was just a great way to spend a day - beautiful vistas, wildlife, and more. The boat ride across Jenny Lake was the highlight of the day and I wish we had allowed more time. A great day with friends.

Great scenery. I was surprised to see the Grand Teton is under 14,000 feet in elevation (13,770 I think). It is definitely majestic and the views are amazing, especially with the reflection off the lakes in the morning.

This has got to be some of the most beautiful countryside anywhere in the world. The area is outstanding and the mountains themselves are picture perfect. When we were there they were still snow topped thus adding even more beauty to the location. I loved Yellowstone and there is so much to see but there is a feel that it is part of a big commercial settings and everything is geared up for the tourists and all is very pristine.As we left I felt disappointed that we were leaving it behind but WOW did I not expect the amazing place that is the Grand Tetons. All is so beautiful and so pleased we pulled off and booked our stay at the Colver Bay Lodges.Wyoming is a beautiful enchanting State and the Grand Teton is the icing on the cake.
review_title: This is a place you must get to visit. Beautiful mountains

review_body: Looking for a stretch road/camping trip from Northern Colorado for me and my 18 year old daughter and wanted to go somewhere i hadn't been before. I was aiming for Yellowstone, but as soon as I hit Teton, I knew this was it. Gorgeous scenery, no crowds, and more photo opportunities than you know what to do with. You will come home with 1,000 photos of the mountains.We had no reservations anywhere, and rolled in on a Friday afternoon in June. We stopped at the visitor's center before the park and asked about dispersed camping. The people behind the counter were incredibly helpful and knowledgeable. We ended up getting a camp spot right on the lake at Atherton Campgrounds in Bridger-Teton National Forest that abutts the park. (Worth several days on its own.)I can't recommend visiting here enough. Yellowstone was nice, but Teton won me and my daugther over.

We loved our visit to the Grand Teton National Park. As we had young children with us we weren't able to do the hikes etc but we managed to see everything we wanted to from the easily accessible roads. The views of the mountains in the park are amazing!! We saw elk, moose and bison while in the park. I enjoyed photographing at Mormon Row.
Stayed in Teton Village...One mile to entrance. Saw lots of wildlife..took wonderful pictures..too many hiking choices..for all levels of expertise..
Grand Teton was so beautiful I actually cried! It was a favorite thing about visiting Wyoming!! Do yourself a favor and see it!
review_title: The Most Beautiful thing I've ever Seen!

review_body: We drove through Grand Teton Park and the scenery was just amazing! It was nice, clear day and the mountain still had snow on them. It is a must see in Wyoming.
A great place for scenery. Walking, fishing and sailing seem to be the activities available. Many signs warning of bears which made me a bit nervous of walking on the trails.
Take your time and visit the part. Every view is stunning and every picture is worth the time to take it.
Wow! The Grand Tetons was on my bucket list, and this June 2016 I can say I have visited this lovely place. Cool in the am and mid 80's in the afternoon. Breathtaking scenery!
These mountains are beautiful! Snowcapped, majestic, pointy, and massive. You can see them for miles as you drive. Be sure to look for wildlife too!

Teton National Park is spectacular. The mountains jut sharply out of the earth above a green and lush valley. Buffalo and moose can be easily found in the valley, and both hiking and skiing (in season) are options in the mountains. You can also raft out of Moose nearby. A friend of mine once said that the Tetons look as if you could walk up to them, then reach out and touch them as they go skyward. I agree.
Wife and I were here to run and we loved the area. Certainly presents images more beautiful than books can reveal.
Seeing the Grand Tetons was on my bucket List. The mountains are so beautiful. The wildlife was plentiful. I highly recommend taking Teton Park Drive if you can. The views were spectacular!

Grand Teton is truly one of the most amazing sights that I have laid my eyes on. Driving toward the Tetons will forever be etched in my memory. We took more photos of the Tetons than anything else in Teton or Yellowstone National Park. I know a few people who traveled to Yellowstone and bypassed the Tetons. It's a big mistake. They are so close, if you plan to do one park, you really must do the other.

The views in the park are nothing short of spectacular! We hiked our first day there in the Jenny Lake area up to Inspiration Point. We saw some wildlife that we didn't see anywhere else on our trip. The elevation change and our first day in the mountains kept us out of breath for awhile but we finally adjusted. We were in and out of the park for several more days later in the week as we drove to Yellowstone. Got to see a mama grizzly and her cub on one of the trips and had to stop for an elk that crossed the road in front of us. It's another national park we can cross off our list.

My husband had visited the Grand Tetons about 14 yrs. ago. We got married almost 2 yrs. ago & he has continued to tell me we've GOT to go to the Tetons. So, we took my parents & my sister's family for a week. In all my world travels, this ties with Alaska as my favorite! The blue skies, majestic Tetons, Leigh Lake, Jenny Lake, the bison, and great places to eat just can't be beat. The wildlife is incredible... loved having to stop the car for bison to cross the road. We also saw elk, pronghorns, a fox, and a huge Great Grey owl (the largest owl in North America). My sister & her family also saw several black bears & a moose with her calf.  The raft ride down the Snake River with Baker-Ewing was great. Our guide, Reed, was so knowledgeable & informative.  Even if you're not a big outdoors person, the Grand Tetons National Park has so much to offer!

Driving toward the park, we came up over a hill and BOOM. There they were. We had to pull off the road and just look. Grand Teton is one of the most beautiful things I've ever seen. There's much to do in the park. We took the boat trip across Jenny Lake and hiked around the falls for about two hours. The views from Inspiration Point are like nothing else on earth. The boat ride is only 10 minutes or so, but it was a great way to see more of the area. Other things we saw: the General Store, Chapel of the Transfiguration, Mormon Row. Loved all of it!
It's hard to believe how beautiful these mountains are! No matter where you turn in the park it seems that there is another place to take another picture. Pictures just don't do it justice!

We were looking for peaceful walks, views, birds, animals, flowers and butterflies. It is all there. People float from Jackson Lake Dam through a nature area in kayaks, rafts, even standup paddle boards. On walks and even from the car we saw moose, elk, deer, antelope buffalo, bear, hawks heron. The views of the Tetons are surreal.
review_title: Better than Yellowstone, and less people to boot

review_body: I love the Grand Tetons! They are so majestic and beautiful, such a peaceful place! Filled with s variety of wildlife and incredible trials to explore! There is so much to see there and Jackson is not that far away. I go here at least 2 times per year! Lots of bear, moose, buffalo , elk, badgers, beavers etc. we have seen it all there!

It is hard to describe such beauty. A relatively short ride through the Tetons but such an exceptional ride. It is mostly flat so you can concentrate on the beauty of not only the mountains but the water and land. Our ride ended in Moose and then on to Jackson. A small sanctuary built in 1937 was noted along the way. A nice place to reflect.

We left Yellowstone NP after several days and drove the ten miles up to Jackson Hole. During the summer months, Jackson Hole is not much to look at - all the real action is during the winter months when it's ski season. We drove inside the park and found all forms of wildlife there - just like at Yellowstone. While the wildlife was terrific - the mountain views were simply spectacular!! The mountains are majestic against a summer blue sky. The peaks still had plenty of snow on them. The drive was quiet and peaceful. There is a seven (7) mile stretch of roadway in the park I encourage everyone to drive - and bring your camera..the good one! Your lenses will be able to pick up all the colors and the slightest details in the landscape.If you are doing the Yellowstone/Grand Teton/Glacier NP tour line, as we did, make sure you take a good, long look at GTNP! You will NOT be disappointed!
The mountains seem to rise right out of the valley. There are no foot hills. Nothing else like this geological wonder.

We were passing through this park with an RV. Saw lots of buffalo. Camped in Moran, Wyoming at Fireside resort in Buffalo Valley. Floated on the Snake river, which was totally awesome. Saw hundreds of buffalo in the Valley along with moose.

Little did I know how stunning this Park is. It's wide open for driving and soaking up the vistas. The Jackson Hole airport is essentially IN the park, so start looking around and turning out at the overlooks immediately. The most attractive route north is to the west of the main road and you need to take a left to get to it soon after leaving the airport. All of the scenic roads are worthwhile for different views of the mountains and grassy meadows.

Of all the Tetons, Grand Teton stands out. A charismatic presence of the surreal beauty. You see the best from the Visitor center at the South entrance. The park employees go above and beyond to make the visitors comfortable.
Beautiful place to visit, less crowded and worth visiting for people interested in photography. Good restaurants at Jackson. Recommend doing float tours on Snake river and Wildlife Safari

The Grand Teton national park never ceases to impress us. We are taking our youngest and they love it. We got into Jackson late afternoon, grabbed a picnic, fried chicken from Albertsons cheap and works for something hot and quick along with other quick items and headed to park. We grabbed a picnic table and ate and the spent evening driving and looking at animals. Going in evening has less traffic and we see so much more. The staff are very informative at visitor centers.
I prefer this park over Yellowstone. Yellowstone is interesting, but this park is majestic and offers a lot to see in a short distance.
Merman road had a lot of old farm houses,the road is not paved lots of mud but the barns are very nice.

Grand Teton Nation Park is a majestic wonder that everyone needs to see. The mountains are tall and beautiful. The meadows peaceful. We had rain and clouds a lot of the time we were in the area but there was enough change in the weather that we got to get out and see the beautiful. Being from Houston we enjoyed seeing the snow in the mountains and the cool weather. We do plan on another trip here someday.

My wife and I have spent the past week hiking in these beautiful mountains and have loved every minute. Most trailsvare not for someone who does not hike but can be done if you use your head. Be prepared with bear repellant, good hiking shoes, layer you dress ( temps drop as you get higher). If you don't mind cold wx hiking these mountains are great up to June. It is May here and temps range from 32-57 degrees with some snow at night. July is the time for warm wx hiking. Either way, you won't be disappointed.

We saw Bison which were so close you could touch them But don't. The mountains were magnificent and they still had snow. There is lots to see and you can see more animals at dusk when they go to the streams and eat in the meadows

I can see how Grand Teton can get lost with so much attention going to its neighbor to the north. I myself made that mistake two summers ago by visiting Yellowstone and skipping Grand Teton. I quickly corrected that error the following summer.Grand Teton is magnificent! And it's also very different from Yellowstone despite their nearness. If you plan on visiting Yellowstone, do yourself the favor and stop by Grand Teton as well.

In the past, we flew into Jackson Hole's Airport & as the plane got closer to those mountains, it just became surreal! Those mountains..they're just so IN YOUR FACE & in a good way! This time we didnt fly in Jaxson Hole Airport, but nevertheless, we drove that long stretch of road out of Jaxson Hole & did as everyone did...try to keep our eyes on the road all the while gawking at the those beautiful mountains. In any season, at any time of day, they're just breath-taking. You eventually come along a stretch whereas the buffalo are hanging out...& hey..if you have the great misfortune to have someone with you on this trip that wants to get close to a buffalo for a great shot or selfie or wants to pet a buffalo or just get near one of them..please have them look at youtube to see the outcome of others who had that same brilliant idea. Don't be fooled by their docile appearance. They're totally unpredictable. And when you're out there in the wild, you're on your own. However, the Tetons are the star of the park..& the buffalo, beautiful as they are too in their own prehistoric way, are, imho, the co-stars. They all play a part in making Grand Teton National Park one of our nations top parks you might want to put on your list to visit.
review_title: In any season..those Tetons are breath-taking!

review_body: OK some folk will disagree but I loved this view more than any at Yellowstone. It is far lesser known but so intensely beautiful. I wish we had allowed ourselves more than 2 days to see it all. Be aware, the mountains create their own weather system & things can change in the blink of an eye. We sailed across Jenny Lake in glorious sun & retuned an hour later in a snow storm! All part of the fun. The west loop has far more to see than the east

The Tetons are striking and can be seen from miles away. The park itself is beautiful and grand indeed. Plan to spend some time just admiring natures beauty. Plenty of wildlife to see and trails to hike. For cyclists, there are marked bike trails/paths.

Exiting Yellowstone at the South entrance, Grand Teton suddenly appears just seven miles away and it is small and stunning. The Tetons are in full view at all times and you can find bears and buffalo in several spots (just look for lines of cars along the side of the road). Yellowstone is overwhelming in its beauty, but Grand Teton more than holds its own.
I some ways not the largest park around but somehow the combination of salt bush flats in the juxtaposition with steep snow covered mountain range just makes this a very unique and beautiful place

We walked around Jenny Lake...7 miles. This is a beautiful place to go. We saw a moose. There was construction at Jenny Lake. We parked in the Jenny lake Overlook. On the way back, the path was closed off. A very nice trail builder park employee (Tyler) from Wisconsin guided us around that last mile on the trail. What a nice experience as he explained how many improvements were being made at this fabulous park. I recommend you go to the visitor's center. Tomorrow, we will be taking a ranger recommended bike ride. Thank you, Tyler.
The Tetons are incredibly beautiful! We were on a long drive and the change of scenery really helped. Seriously, the most amazing sites I've ever seen. Driving through a mountain? Yes please.

I didn't know about Teton until I planned our trip for Yellowstone. What a shocker. When we went to Yellowstone it was busy, cool temperature, and rainy. The pools were so steamy (too cold <15°c>) you couldn't see the prismatic brilliance. Teton however; was astounding. There was beautiful sheets of rain over the mountains, enormous billowing clouds, water all over for incredible reflections of the mountains. Personally I would rather spend a cloudy muggy stay in rainy day here, over a hot sunshine day. It just added to the beauty. Even though we saw Yellowstone on a cold day (hard to see pools); Teton was by far my favourite. Take the time to explore it, instead of rushing into Yellowstone.
Just Go. Words and even the best pictures can't capture the beauty of this place. One of the most breathtaking sights ever.

America the beautiful!!! Went through twice. Saw a moose when coming in from Dubois! Went in at six am had park to ourselves. Animals in the road. Saw a coyote walking down the road.brought a picnic and pulled over enjoyed a glass of wine with glorious view. Very nice visitors center near Jenny lake. Had snow in morning giving everything a magical look. Easy trip out of Jackson.

We visited Grand Teton immediately after being at Yellowstone so we had already experienced magnificent scenery. We thought of Grand Tetons as the "smaller brother" of Yellowstone but it certainly delivers on stunning scenery especially the massive Jackson Lake, Colter Bay and the magnificent Teton mountains. Don't miss out on this National Park

Grand Teton National Park is one of the smaller parks in the park system, but it is one of the most recognizable in the world. Checking in at about 480 square miles it is a little larger than Rocky Mountain National Park (415), but tiny compared to its neighbor, Yellowstone (3,462). What makes Teton such an attractive destination is the amazing scenery that is so accessible. And Wyoming has done an excellent job creating an infrastructure around the park that is cowboy rustic with the availability of all the luxury any one could possibly want. I can safely say that you can go into any restaurant wearing just about anything you want and fit right in. You are accepted for who you are and how you like to enjoy yourself. Sure, there are limits, good taste and common sense, but I think you know what I mean. There is no “Gentlemen must wear a jacket” nonsense. It is casual and relaxed throughout Jackson Hole. So don’t worry about that. I say this because there are some tremendous places to dine in Jackson Hole and the scenery outside the dining room is unlike anything, anywhere else in the world. So, Teton offers everything from slogging through wetlands looking for moose, hanging off rock faces from ropes or your fingers, crashing through rapids, floating through forests, hiking trails, riding horses, flying in helicopters and eating anywhere from a smoky campfire by a lake to 5 star, seven course cuisine in an historic lodge. You name it, you can probably do it. The trick to doing the Tetons right is to learn everything you can about the place, identify what you want to do, learn about that, and then book early. Grand Teton National Park is suffering the same influx of tourists as everywhere else. Cheap gas and an improving economy has more people than ever exploring the national parks. Not quite loving them to death, but certainly making their presence known. So with all the vacationers out there, you want to plan and book way ahead so you don’t have any panic attacks while you are in such a beautiful place. Lodging options are varied. There are many choices to explore including Jenny Lake Lodge ($$$$$$), Jackson Lake Lodge ($$$$$) Signal Mountain ($$$$) and Colter Bay ($$$). There are several camping and RV options within the park too. Outside the park there are hundreds of options from the obscenely expensive to downright economical. My choice, Colter Bay Cabins inside the park on the shores of Jackson Lake. I will say it again, BOOK YOUR LODGING EARLY. One more time: “BOOK EARLY!!!” Dining is another aspect of the trip that you may need to address in advance. If you want to do the fine dining in the Mural Room or Jenny Lake Lodge, book early. Get that out of the way. You will be disappointed if you try to book the day of. Most of the other dining options in Colter Bay and Signal Mountain and even Jackson Lake Lodge are less of a challenge. And check out the chuck wagon breakfasts and dinners where you ride a horse to your dining location or take a boat to a secluded island. Start at the activity desk. There’s even a chuck wagon barbeque at Dornans in Moose as well as a rockin’ pizza joint. So, what is there to do in Teton? If you are at one of the fine lodges, it’s not bad just hanging out in the great rooms relaxing or sitting out on the patio and watch Mother Nature strut her stuff in front of you. Activities are unlimited and you can go to any recreation activity desk and book things to do. All the lodges have brochure stands and you can book your own, or the lodges have their own guides and you can book with the guide. There is hiking that takes you to amazing OMG locations. Some of the hikes involve a ferry ride across Jenny Lake to the trail head. Any hike you take is surrounded by beautiful mountain peaks thrusting up out of the earth as well as dense forests on the lower mountain sides and the beautiful lakes and meadows left over from the glaciers of the last ice age. All you need is a desire to see nature up close and personal and a sturdy pair of footwear. Oh, and carry a can of bear spray. Bears know what the red can means and when they see it, they will usually go the other way. If you get tired or don’t want to walk. Ride a bicycle. Or go for a horseback ride. The float trips are amazing. Some floats are a few hours, others take all day with a picnic in the middle. If you don’t want to float, take a whitewater trip through class 5 rapids. Nasty canyons are nearby. Name your rafting preference, you can find it in Jackson Hole. Teton is also a driving park. You can drive the roads and stop at the dozens and dozens of pullouts to marvel at the scenery. You can drive to the top of Signal Mountain for a panoramic view of the valley. See if you can figure out where Ansel Adams parked his wagon when he took his photo from the Snake River Overlook. You can drive down to the trail that takes you to the beaver ponds at Schwabacher Landing and watch the otters during the day and the beaver at night. You can drive all the roads in the park in less than a day. Don’t forget to drive out the road to Gros Ventre. It is a beautiful valley that is not in the park. There are moose, elk, deer and bison. Well worth the time and miles to see it. Teton is a small park with a big backcountry. If you like expedition hiking, then this is the place for you. You will need to plan early so you can get all your permits and campsites ahead of time, then you strike off into the backcountry for a wilderness adventure. The back country is filled with world class climbing. If you want to try it, there are mountain schools and guides that will take you out and show you the ropes. You will be at altitude and climbing is strenuous, so make sure you are fit for what you want to try. If you are going to go it alone, check the climbing ranch for preparation and permits. If you are a photographer then you are in heaven when you get to Teton. Shoot RAW files as well as JPG. If you don’t know what RAW is, one day you will and you will thank me. The picture taking starts a couple of hours before sunrise and continues well into the night after the sun goes down. There are so many iconic places to take the National Geographic shot that I can’t name them all. If you want to be shown, sign up for a photo expedition with a guide and you will see things most people don’t. Or, you can get out and explore the park and find your own favorite locations. The park has an abundance of fauna and flora. The meadows explode with wild flowers during the spring. Hiking up mountain trails you see flowers all summer long next to the streams and pools. There is a huge variety of trees, so autumn is especially beautiful (Check out the historic barns on Mormon Row in late Septmeber). And the furry animals will be plentiful including bear, deer, elk, moose, bison, coyotes, wolves, ground squirrels, chipmunks and marmots. And there are dozens of birds including owls, hawks, golden and bald eagles, magpies, jays, etc. If you like standing around, getting wet and teasing fish, then the lakes, pools, rivers and streams will not disappoint. You can study up on where you want to go or hire a fishing guide. Lures and flies are standard stuff. Lots of people fish below Jackson Lake Dam (because there are a lot of fish there) but get out and explore the other rivers. If you get a good catch, the chef at your lodge will probably cook them for you. Just ask. One day in Teton is not enough. It will just make your realize that you needed more time and will have to come back. I would say two full days is the minimum stay as a survey vacation with some activities (meaning you will come back). And you could stay a week and never get bored. Remember, it is all in the planning. I know that lots of people are concerned about connectivity. Cell service in the park is fairly good, but can get spotty up on the hill. All the lodges have wifi in the great rooms, but probably not in the bed room. So if you need to stay connected, you can do that with a little effort. It’s kind of hard to review Grand Teton National Park just because it is such an amazing place. There is something for everyone and the park and outfitters have made every attempt to make the park as accessible and enjoyable as possible. So plan your trip early and you will not be disappointed.
review_title: Grand Teton is a must see National Park

review_body: It was early in the season and the road on into Yellowstone Park was still closed, but the beauty we saw was still worth the trip. The mountains were gorgeous and the splendor of the valleys and plains breath taking. The air was quite cool still, but we still enjoyed getting out for clearer looks at God's handiwork, and then we saw a farmer clearing a spot of land. The peacefulness that still exists in this troubled nation of ours!

This is an annual trek, and the mountains never change. However, each year they have a different look, depending on the weather and time of day. It is always thrilling to come out of Jackson and round that corner, only to have this incredible vista of awe-inspiring mountains burst into view. Am grateful for the numerous turnouts so one can gaze in peace and search for wildlife. We normally see buffalo, elk, antelope, deer, and even occasionally a bear. The best view of the mountains are on the road outside the park. And one shouldn't miss going on the roads east to visit some of the historical sites in the flats in front of the Tetons. The visitor centers both in Jackson and at the entrance to the park are wonderful resources for places to visit. This should be a must-do on everyone's bucket list!!!

Very beautiful and magnificent Park but weather vary significantly. Day 1 we came in early afternoon, super clear. Day 2 snowing, mountains completely fogged up at the south end of 191 (near jackson). North end (bordering Yellowstone) was snowing heavy with low visibility. However, from moose to Colter Bay, it was clear! Lucky us. Would advise staying at least 2 full days in Jackson in case of weather like this.....

Beautiful part of the world, easily accessible for taking amazing pictures of the landscape. Lots of fun looking for wildlife. Beginning of May was off season but the weather was perfect, and the park was not crowded.
This small church is located in one of the most beautiful spots around. The church is open to the public and well worth the stop.
The spaciousness & grandeur of our National Parks is on display! Grand Teton is not just a gateway to Yellowstone, but deserves to be explored as its own Grand Land!!
Have yourself a look at our photos we took today. You won't be disappointed. I highly recommend experiencing a sunrise in this neck of the woods.
This park is so beautiful. The entire family loved it and would be happy to go back. Driving at dusk was great for viewing wildlife.

The most crisp mountain view I've ever seen and I've been to the Sierras, Rockies, and the Appalachians. Amazingly clear lake in front of the Tetons that mirrors any of the trees or mountains in itself. Blue mountains on a pristine landscape! A must see!

Grand Teton offers a place to get away into the solitude of towering mountains that jut from the plains below. We hiked the Cascade trail and enjoyed every step, even in the rain. At the top, we were blessed to visit with a mother moose and her young calf! What a beautiful place that deserves preservation and protection.

My favorite scenery from my 3000 mile trip cross-country! Having gone in early April, most of the areas were still closed due to snow being present. Unlike Yellowstone, you can still travel and see most of this park. Jackson Lake is a quiet field of snow and ice, and Snake River Overlook is just starting to show through the winter remnants. The temperature was in the 60s, which made for a very comfortable experience of the awesomeness that is the Grand Tetons!
Grand Teton with its natural rugged peaks is beautiful mountain scenery. Lots of trails and nature make for a terrific national park. Beautiful through all seasons.

The first time you behold the Rockies covered in snow, and it is mid august, when you have never been there, is astonishing. This is the second set of the "Rocky Mountains", and the newest mountains in the world. The oldest mountains in the world are the Smokies/Ozarks/Poconos; all of the mountains in the east of the great land called North America. The Tetons are spectacular

If you want to be blown away by mother nature's beauty - then add this place to your list. Every where you turn there is something more and more incredible to see than before. The wildlife, the water, the mountains, the forestry - everything is just picturesque.
review_title: One of the most beautiful places

review_body: We traveled from Salt Lake to Wyoming to visit Grand Teton and Yellowstone NP in early Fall. Was the perfect time to go with mild weather and minimal crowds. Staying in Jackson Hole at the Flat Creek Inn allowed us to venture into Grand Teton then make the 42 mile loop trail back to the motel that evening. With stops at almost every overlook, lake, or attraction. After several days, we went on to West Yellowstone for 6 days to start our tour or the entire Yellowstone park. What an wonderful experience I wish everyone could make.
review_title: One of the Nations Best Parks

review_body: It's been called a craggy landscape. I enjoyed the Crand Teton National Park, I drove over to Oxbow Bend on the snake river, spotted otter, beaver, moose, elk. On the way back to the Headwaters lodge saw bald eagles and a large group of bison. The Flagg Ranch is located at the North entrance.

Words and pictures cannot describe the beauty and grandeur of The Grand Tetons. We took a detour to the Moulton Barn, then drove through the park on Teton Park Road stopping at Jenny and Jackson Lakes. We saw many deer and antelope, but no bear. I cannot wait to come back and spend more time here.I would recommend The Tetons to everyone as it has something to satisfy everyone.
review_title: National Park - check off bucket list

review_body: We spent 2 days and 2 nights in the park. Staying at the Headwaters Lodge at Flagg Ranch just North of the Northern Park Entrance we were truly in the wilderness. The scenery is breathtaking. Driving out from the lodge just after dawn, we were lucky enough to see a multitude of wildlife living in the region. The frost on the ground, mist over the lakes and snow-capped peaks stopped us in our tracks. With this as a background we were also fortunate to see herds of Bison and Elk in their natural habitat.At the Southern end of the park lies Jackson a picturesque old trading post, founded at the start of the 19th century. It is now a bustling mountain town, home to artists and back-packers in summer and thronged with skiers and adventurers in winter. This is a town well worth stopping in. Fabulous art galleries are interspersed with boutique shops and fantastic eateries.On our return to Flagg Ranch, we were treated to a Park Ranger presentation on the wildlife to be found in the park and Bear Safety. This was undertaken outside, overlooking the river and to the sound of Elk and Coyote and beside a big camp fire. Fresh warm cookies were supplied to ward off the chill, one of which was also enjoyed by a local squirrel who made off with one bigger than himself!There are numerous scenic drives and trails to keep even the most adventurous happy. But remember........be Bear Aware!
Wonderful cabin in the heart of the park. Thunderstorm the nights we stayed and and we lit a fire. Dinner in the lodge was excellent.

The Grand Tetons are one of those majestic areas in North America. You can just sit and watch the sunset and think to yourself that there is a great power. The hikes are all well within the range of a novice, and some areas that will challenge even the more hardcore hikers. If you were to ask me if the trails are as hard as Yosemite hikes; I would say no. However, the wildlife can only be challenged by the Alaskan frontier. My teenagers enjoyed just taking their water bottle and hiking throughout the many miles of hiking trails. Although, be warned that there is an active bear population. Nothing to fear, but good common sense and knowing the proper protocol will make for a safe hike. In other words, don't pack a freshly cooked steak or don't approach a mother bear and her cubs. This is area is mother nature at her best!

I wish we had planned well and spent more time. We took the scenic drive along the Jackson lake on our way to salt lake city. Grand Teton was absolutely beautiful with the majestic mountains, blue lake and vibrant fall colors. I think it's easy to miss or underestimate it while planning because of the larger and famous YNP. we will definitely go back and spend some time again.

The Grand Teton National Park is my favorite Park!! I had been there with my family as a little girl, it was one of my Father's favorite places to vacation! He passed away last year and as a tribute to his memory I needed to go again! The Teton Mountains are spectacular!! So much to see and do! Definitely going back and my dream is to live out my days there!

The minute we drove into the valley from Jackson I knew this was paradise. The spectacular tetons were breathtaking. The wildlife diversity was awesome. We saw a sizable herd of pronghorns, a red fox searching for lunch (and ignoring us), a huge bull moose watching over a moose cow & her calf right next to the road. Several bugling bull elk were looking for females. Just to hear them calling gave you chills. It felt like we were transported back in time before white men ever stepped foot in here. We actually saw more animals here than Yellowstone. Jenny lake was a jewel, so clear & beautiful. Jenny lake lodge's architecture was beautiful too. So much to see. We took several day trips all over the park. All the different visitor centers have such great people working in them. I couldn't, think of a better place to work. Our only regret was we didn't see bears. Maybe next time. What a gift this place is to America, we should treasure and protect it always.

Don't miss out on seeing and getting a photo with Mother Nature's art that is Grand Teton. If you want to catch it at the most spectacular, be sure to wait until after mid-morning, when the clouds have risen. Mormon row provides a great view of the full range.

Getting as close as you can to the majestic Grand Tetons is a prime reason that we visited Jackson Hole. Winter driving conditions slow you down some, but there is so much to see. We parked and snow shoe hiked in the area. Simply spectacular! Enjoy. ...

This is one of the most visited US National Parks for a good reason! If bordering Yellowstone National Park was not enough, GTNP has a rich history, amazing views, geological history, world class fishing, wildlife viewing, rafting the Snake River, great accommodations and some of the best mountain climbing in the world! I have been to GTNP every summer for the past 25 years and can always find a new and interesting place. There is a fee to enter the park but very reasonable for seniors and if you are visiting numerous National Parks within one year period. One lane roads are posted at 45-50 MPH so drive slowly and be careful for wildlife and cyclists. The park does have a separate bike path next to the road so be sure to bring your bicycles! Best time to drive the park roads are early morning for sunrise photos of the Grand Teton range and wildlife. Evenings and before sunset are also nice. During the day you can drive the park roads and stop at numerous pull outs, some with bathrooms. Plenty of places to visit with historical markers and such. Camping, lodges and ranches provide accommodations inside the park. There is limited options for groceries and gas within the park and Jackson Hole Wyoming is the closest large town with all you need. Be sure to take binoculars, camera, sunscreen and consult with your doctor on traveling to altitude. Grand Teton National Park is approximately 6,600' in elevation, headaches and shortness of breath is common for new arrivals from sea level. The airport could not be located any closer but fares can be expensive. The park itself is closed to vehicular traffic during winter so check with the National Park Service for specific details. Summertime is the busiest time of year for the park. Great for families and fond memories, don't miss out on this place!
review_title: One of the most inspiring places in North America!

review_body: This is a must - lesser known than it's neighbour, Yellowstone, but well worth the visit. Didn't see bears - but plenty of chipmunks, squirrels, deer and bison.

One of my favorite places in the United States, the Grand Tetons are a must see for anyone who loves mountains. They are absolutely beautiful, and not far from Yellowstone. Jackson Hole has been of places for accommodation and is charming in of itself. Great place to get in touch with nature!
One of the Greatest parks in the world. the wildlife the snake river I could sit and find inspiration from this place for hours

We went snow shoeing on a Sunday afternoon and there were miles and miles of groomed trails - it is just amazing. There are also many miles of groomed cross country skiing trails as well. We chose the path to Taggert Lake and it was amazing. I suggest you bring a map, just in case. Cannot wait to head back in the summer! Have fun.
review_title: Beautiful, Majestic Views, Great Snow Shoeing & Cross Country Skiing

review_body: It's right next to Yellowstone, and has about 1/3 the people. Beautiful glacial lakes, and peace and quiet. I loved it, I didn't see any wildlife but I was there middle of the day, I'm sure around dusk you would see tons.

From my experience, the majority of travelers and tourists head to Yellowstone for a week and put aside a day or two to check out the Tetons, upon my 4th trip out to the area I decided to do the opposite and spend a week in the Tetons, it turned out to be one of the best trips I ever took. I spent a week camping throughout the park, Id wake up at sunrise every morning and do another hike. Cascade Canyon will go down as one of my favorite hikes Ive ever done, be sure to check it out. The boat ride across Jenny Lake is also a fun thing to do if you aren't in the mood for hiking. All in all I could go on for hours, The Tetons are a great place and one of my favorite parks.
review_title: Overshadowed by its neighbor, but just as amazing!

review_body: This is simply one of the most brilliantly gorgeous places in the USA. And, it is a welcome respite from the abundance of tourists just a half hour or so up the road in Yellowstone. Certainly don't miss the spectacle of Yellowstone, but it will be a true shame if you miss the scenery of Grand Teton NP. Experience Yellowstone for all it is, and then relax at the Grand Tetons. We even had a mother bear and her two cubs entertain us roadside (while we safely remained in our car). Don't miss sunrise or sunset; both are special experiences.

Go here! So pretty! Take your time because we ran out of it before we got to see and do everything we wanted. It wasn't too busy in September but there were still plenty of people. Lots of nature and wildlife to be seen. Pull over at some of the turn off, read the history, walk around and take in all that this area has to offer. Can't say enough.

We stayed in Jackson Hole for a few days while we explored Grand Teton and Yellowstone. The views of the Tetons were spectacular and the Jenny Lake Trail was a highlight for us. One evening whilst passing though Grand Teton on the way back to Jackson we saw a grizzly bear in the picnic area lay-by off the main road. We were able to watch him from the car for a while before he went on his way, a lovely experience.
The lake in front of the Grand Tetons is my favorite, especially with this mountain view behind it! One of my favorite pictures of a Moose is from Grand Teton National park.

I visited Grand Teton in June 2014, and this place is just amazing! When I got out of the bus and looked at the snow in the mountains, it was just breathtaking! As we had just some minutes to walk around and take pictures, I was not able to see much of the park, but if you are closeby, I reccomend you stop and take some pictures. Just the fact of standing in the grass and observing the mountains it's so peaceful.

Grand Teton National Park is on my top 5 list of National Parks I have visited (and I have visited quite a few). I have visited the park a few times and it is one of those places that always leaves me breathless. On our recent trip (August 2015) to many of the National Parks (Glacier, Yellowstone, Theodore Roosevelt, Wind Cave, Teton) I was very much looking forward to seeing this park again. In fact we added to our vacation as we were planning to make sure that we hit this park. Unfortunately, we happened to hit it at a time that the wild fires were burning in several West Coast areas and the smoke from them decided to settle into Grand Teton National Park. The first day we drove through on our way from Yellowstone to our hotel in Jackson Hole we couldn't even see the mountains! If you've ever been there this will surprise you because the mountains are big and beautiful and all around you. We decided to try it again the following morning because we were hoping some of the smoke had cleared. Well.....it was better than the day before but it was still pretty smokey. We were able to see sunrise at Jenny Lake but it was a little disappointing with the lack of visibility. Still a wonderful place and nothing you can do about natural events. Oh well...just means I have to go back!Do not miss the views of Jenny Lake or the views from the Chapel of Transfiguration if you are headed to the park. Put this on your bucket list! You won't be sorry!
review_title: One of my Favorite National Parks

review_body: Like many, I came to the area for Yellowstone and more or less stumbled upon the Tetons in the process. I've been here twice and I have to say I am completely in love with the Tetons. I wish I could come back every year. Fresh air, moose, history, lakes, and of course mountains... it's heaven.
review_title: Favorite place I've been in my life.

review_body: We went in August of 2014 and cannot wait to come back for this beautiful landscape, ranger programs, wildlife!

This mountain range is breathtaking! Everyone should get to see them at least once in their lifetime! My husband and I are not able to walk and get around much, but just driving through the park was amazing. When we drove out of the mountains and into the valley I glanced in my rearview mirror and was amazed again at the mountain range and landscape. I've seen a lot of mountains, but none quite like this! You just have to make this trip!

Took Red Bus tour and was overly pleased with the tour. Was able to enjoy a lot of tour even thought there was a fire at St Mary's when we were there. Was not able to go over the mountains but still saw quit a lot. Every day was a different experience.

Our first day we couldn't even tell they existed, the second day started off the same, then the fog started to lift and oh my, they are exquisite. We were there during off season and found a place where we were along 45 minutes before another soul came! It was amazing and would recommend going off-season!

A wonderful drive west to GTNP, except for all the tall pines dieing of a beetle disease for miles and miles. The roads are good; many parking pull off areas. When I was a kid 50 years ago, I remember seeing slides that my aunt took of the Tetons. They were up IN the mountains! Now accessibility is limited to hiking trails only, the Park Ranger told us. You can stay in pricey Jackson Hole, or find many great hotels/inns in towns with in an hour or less.

Everything you have heard about Teton is true. The hikes, the views, the wildlife (we saw several black bears, a moose, a gray wolf, a fox, a herd of bison,...). I want to add that after hiking Teton, Yellowstone hikes were not as rewarding. However, the Yellowstone thermal features are a must. So ideally, stay near Teton and do most of your hiking there. Then take 1-2 days to drive to Yellowstone to visit the main thermal sites (luckily they are south of Yellowstone, the part closest to Teton).

One of the most beautiful sightseeing area in the states.You can go for ride and enjoy the beautiful scenery.Or park your car have a picnic somewhere by the river or on top of the mountain, enjoy the breeze and the mesmerizing view.Stop by the grand Teton village and feed the horse. But I'm not sure if its allowed.Do some tracking or lake activities.definitely worth a visit !

We reached Grand Teton National Park at about 8:45 pm in June 2015. There was still natural daylight when we entered the park. The place where we were staying was almost at the end of the park. One minor problem we had was there was not much signage and the place where we were staying nobody picked up the phone after 7:00 pm and we were a little tense as to where our accomadations were exactly. The Jackson Lake Lodge where we stayed was absolutely beautiful and the staff were very courteous. The park itself is stunning. The mountains are incredibly beautiful, the lakes are very nice and the trails are very varied. Carry bug spray and you are all set for great hikes. We took the river rafting on the Snake River early morning and it was very nice. All in all it was a beautiful location and I highly recommend it.

I absolutely love the Grand Teton National Park. We purchased the annual pass when we went to Yellowstone so we decided to drive out through the south entrance so we could visit Grand Teton National Park. They never stopped us to ask for our pass coming from the south so we didn't realize we were in the park at first. There is so much to see and do here. We didn't realize all of the hiking trails so we didn't plan on spending much time here. We will definitely go back to explore it all.
review_title: One of my favorite National Parks

review_body: The 310,000 acre park is just 10 miles from Yellowstone Park. It includes the peaks of the 40 mile Teton Range of mountains and the river basin valley of Jackson Hole. There are over 200 miles of trails to explore and the area is ideal for mountaineering, hiking, camping, fishing and its alpine terrain has wildlife, lakes and the Snake River to enjoy. No roads cross the Tetons, but those along the eastern side provide great views of the mountains including the Jenny Lake Scenic Loop leading to the enormous 13,700ft Grand Teton Mountain. There is also the narrow track to Signal Mountain which provides a fantastic panoramic view of the Tetons and Jackson Hole.

This is a must for anyone's bucket list. Unbelievable mountain range. Hiking trails available, but don't recommend for people with difficulty walking. Rocky, dirt trails that may be difficult for small children also. A beautiful mountain range.

I had never been to the Jackson Hole area and decided that I wanted to go for my birthday. My wife had been as a teenager and told me I would be amazed, she was right. I couldn't take enough photos. The views are spectacular and seeing the free range buffalo and antelope was so incredible. Drove my wife crazy stopping over and over again to take photos. The weather was perfect, beautiful fall days. I highly recommend going in October, the crowds were very small compared to the summer, or at least that's what we were told.

What we loved about the Grand Teton National Park is that the distances are so much more manageable than in Yellowstone We stayed in Teton Village which is just outside the National Park. It is right beside for the ski lift which has great views and the possibility of an exhilarating bike ride back down. It is only few minutes from the Moose - Wilson Road which is great for those early morning drives in search of wildlife and we were fortunate to see some moose grazing in a roadside lake. We usually finished up at Dornans chuck wagon for breakfast which has outdoor tables with amazing views of the Grand Tetons.

We go every second year since 1985. Hiking, canoeing, eating, camping, exploring are just a few of the reasons to come to the greatest park in America. It is 1,000 miles from home, but it is worth every mile.

Like all USA National Parks its not quite as pristine, un-impacted and animal filled as you’d think : or as the brochure makes out. Located on the south side of Yellowstone you will find less people, less aggression, and better animal and scenery opportunities. Having said that there is a main interstate running through this one so its not empty wilderness and grassland with herds of bison.
review_title: Quiter than Yellowstone, close tto, add it to the list

review_body: We really enjoyed our time in Grand Teton. The weather was perfect - crisp and sunny! We saw deer and elk, but no moose unfortunately. Very pretty part of Wyoming, often over-looked for Yellowstone. Easy scenic driving loop that takes you through some of this gorgeous National Park.

While the Grand Teton listing found elsewhere in Trip Advisor has attracted many reviews of the national park, it was not specific to the mountain itself, a unique destination in its own right worthy of your consideration. Dr. Hayden in 1872 called it "the shark's tooth." Views of the peak from the valley floor are spectacular but the closer you approach this mountain the more it will reward you. A strenuous 4.6 mile dayhike from the Lupine Meadows trailhead brings you to Garnet Meadows, immediately beneath the towering Middle Teton. It becomes more arduous to hike to the 11,600 foot lower saddle between the Middle and the Grand. Please talk to rangers at any GTNP visitor center for information regarding these breathtaking options. But to approach the summit requires technical expertise and even more guidance; a permit is required for backcountry camping and the best way for a first-time attempt on the summit includes this. In case you seek the easy or "walk-up" route to the top, there is not one. Of the 38 distinct climbing routes with many variations in between, none of them are not technical. A very skilled climber under dry conditions may go up in shorts and running shoes if the weather is good, but those are some rather broad caveats: seasoned climbers have perished that way. Please visit the Grand Teton via the Exum Mountain Guides or the Jackson Hole Mountain Guides or, on your own, in a party if you are well experienced and know how to protect yourselves and to decipher the meanings of descriptions in guidebooks.This place will blow you away. It is the iconic American mountain. Please be safe and open up all of your senses.
Absolutely beautiful park and scenery. I loved everything about being here from the beautiful mountains, to the clear skies, the color of the water in the lakes and streams and all of the wildlife.
review_title: Can I give it 7 or 8 stars?

review_body: nice and easy trails, beautiful lakes and great waterfallsthe weather during the week of october (12-18) was between 45 and 71 , no rainfoliage viewsnice to try
Beautiful views, relaxing boat trip on the lake, but only saw some bison at a distance, disappointing after seeing so many animals in Yellowstone!

What a beautiful park with views every way you look. My favorite was a day when Jenny Lake boating service was closed due to helicopters delivering supplies to rebuild a trail. The lake was so calm we were able to get wonderful mountain shots with a perfect reflection in the lake. We also saw saw moose, a mama and baby bear, pronghorns, and a field with buffalo and horses.
The Grand Tetons were beautiful. Visiting in September the trees were just starting to change colour. Against a backdrop of snow/glazier peaks the mountains were beautiful.
Love this National Park. Trail are well maintained, scenery is breath-taking. Best time to visit is fall

Grand Teton NP is stunning. The valley, the mountains, glacier lakes and everything in between is like paradise. Its vehicle friendly with many marked spots that are awesome viewpoints. Of course there is a lot of backcountry for the adventurer too.I recommend Shwabacher's Landing, Obxo Bend, and Mormon Row for EXCELLING wildlife viewing opportunities and beautiful scenery.
What a beautiful park. We came here after a few days at the overrun Yellowstone NP. Much more relaxed; and the views! and the wildlife!

There is a reason that most National Parks are preserved areas - because they are all so beautiful. Grand Teton is no exception with so many amazing views. We spent a couple of days touring around the park. If you are coming from Jackson, there is a road between Wilson and Moose that is partially unpaved and pretty bumpy, but it's great for seeing wildlife. Our first day we spotted a black bear. The mountains are magnificent and have unusual, pointed shapes and there is scenery at every turn. A wonderful national park to visit.

Ditto on previous reviews containing superlatives about this magnificent national treasure. The Park is truly the standard against which other scenic wonders are measured. The number of wildlife sighting are immeasurable! Beaver, wolves, elk, bear, antelope, martins, marmots, and so many bird species...you name it, Grand Teton probably hosts them. We had always wanted to stay at the Jackson Lake Lodge and our wishes came true. Fantastic, and such views from the lodge of Jackson Lake, Mt. Moran and fellow Teton peaks, elk, wolves and birds of every stripe. We loved catching the rising sun at Oxbow Bend and walking the trails of Jenny Lake and Coulter Bay. Signal Mountain was a great drive with wonderful panoramic views. So much to do...and in September without the crowds. People tend to visit Grand Teton because they love the outdoors, respect the wildlife and scenic treasures, are courteous and ready for the maximal overall experience. If that sounds like you, make it happen! This is just a super Park and we loved it so. Thank you, National Park Service and Lodge staff for enabling so many fabulous memories. We hope to be back soon!
review_title: Wonderfully scenic and lots of wildlife

review_body: I was there September 28, 2015 and there was a full moon out on a clear night and I was able to take some breathtaking photos of The Grand Teton Mountain Range after dark using the light from the moon. Awesome!
We enjoyed ourselves even though it was in-between seasons. Maybe even more, as there were fewer people. The Tetons were majestic and bucket list worthy.
This is such a special region of the world and the mountains are just stunning on a clear day, and mysterious on an overcast one.
Absolute must see National Park close to Yellowstone with great camping, fishing and hiking options all over!

After being in Yellowstone and Grand Teton several times now I think Grand Teton is the best place to see wildlife. Best places for moose, bear, buffalo and maybe elk) are Moose Wilson Road, Willow Flats, Gros Ventre Campground (saw a family of 3 moose this year). Other great scenery locations for great photos are Oxbow Bend, Snake River Overlook, Mormon Row on Antelope Flats Road, and newly discovered this year Schwabacher Landing Road.

I had visited Grand Teton back in Sept 2009 and 2010, my DH had never been so it was high on his bucket list and it wasn't hard for me to agree to come back again since it is such an amazing and beautiful place.The Teton range at times appears like it's fake and it's green screened, that's how magical and incredible it is.It's hard to drive by them because you just want to stare at them, so it's a good thing there is a lot of pull outs and overlooks.We got into the park on Labor day Monday, and stayed in the area until the Friday and truly had the best time.We spent the first day hiking Taggert lake and Bradley lake, both are so beautiful.Then we went to signal mountain lodge where we were spending the night and watched the most beautiful sunset over Jackson lake and Mount moran.We also stopped at a lot of the overlooks, Oxbow bend is a favorite so breathtaking and snake river overlook is gorgeous.We went to Antelope flats and got some great photos from Mormon row with the barns and the Tetons.We went to schwabacher landing another favorite spot for some nice reflections of the Tetons and we got to see beavers building their dams down there.We also hiked Heron pond and Swan lake in the Colter bay area, that's a nice short hike to do both of those.We saw an amazing sunset on Jenny lake and to top it off on our final night we saw a Grizzly with her 2 cubs by the side of the road.This is a place of pure stunning beauty, and we loved every second we were there and we realize how lucky we are to have been able to experience this wonderful natural and wild place.All I can say is if you haven't been "go !!"
review_title: One of the most beautiful places on earth

review_body: Grand Teton is doing it right. I hope this park continues to stay under the radar, unlike Yellowstone. In this park they have minimal signs, minimal man-made contraptions/pathways and they are truly letting nature do what it was meant to do. They do have a bike route that goes with the main road through the park. This is where I saw most of the people during the day. Once off the beaten path, you are immersed in nature. If you are looking for nature, this is the park for you. The views are spectacular, the air is fresh and there is a beautiful peacefulness to the experience of this park. I highly recommend taking the time to hike and explore its beauty.
Superb natural wonders, one of the most stunning places I have visited. We had sunny weather and blue skies that emphasized the beauty.

Get your hike on, or just a scenic drive. Wonderful views. We enjoyed the Signal Mountain view point (it's a drive up look out). It's perhaps the most amazing view I've ever seen; mountains and valley together - see bison in the distance. Pretend you're in 'Dances with Wolves'. Amazing. we also greatly enjoyed the Ranger lead wildlife caravan tour. It ends in September due to weather, but was great; we saw moose, elk, prong horn, beaver. Really good.

We arrived from the east and entered the park at Moran, WY. The view of the mountains can be seen for miles and only got better the closer we drove. Whatever you do, go to Jenny Lake via the Teton Park Road. Possibly the most beautiful lake I have ever seen. Also, Jackson Lake is huge and offers stunning reflective views of the mountain range. The park is easy to navigate and can be driven in less than a day, which is what we did on our way to Yellowstone. It has tons of wildlife and we witnessed fabulous September fall foliage with mountain vistas. Hope to come back soon and stay awhile as they offer hiking and camping. Don't miss...just stunning!

This has to be one of the most appealing parks in the U.S. The Teton range has to be one of the most beatiful in the world. You could whistle through in a day or you spend a lifetime here. Take the time to see what is on offer here, great mountain views, especially from the Chapel of the Transfiguration, scenic views of the Snake river and the surrounding countryside especially from the top of Signal Mountain. Beautiful sunsets, great reflections from either Jackson Lake Dam or Oxbow Bend. the history of Mormon Row and the opportunity to view widlife. Wildlife was not quite as readily seen as it was on our last visit in 2007, then there were plenty of Bison and you could hardly move without falling over female Moose and calves. this time we hardly saw a Bison, but were lucky enough to see a Bull Moose. There was plenty of Elk and Pronghorn to be seen this time as well. This is a park no one should miss.

I guess it's the combination of the open vistas, forested lakes and the Snake river with dramatic mountains in the background but I never get tired or returning to Grand Teton. The wildlife is another attraction: bears (if you're lucky), elk, moose, pronghorn, bison, and many kinds of birds to name a few things.
review_title: Possibly the most beautiful place in the U.S.

review_body: We have visited many National Parks but the Grand Tetons stand out for their amazing views and the beautiful lakes. It is a small park and easy to get around in a day.

Grand Teton National Park was a great place to spend a week! We camped at Colter Bay Village and took day trips to check out the park. Saw many types of wildlife, including bears and elk, and the views are amazing. Would definitely recommend!

This park was georgeous. I couldn't stop taking photos of the mountains. The scenery was fabulous. We saw lots of wildlife, too. Within the first few hours we saw a black bear, antelope and mule deer. We saw lots of bison, lots of antelope, 5 moose and many deer. We flew into Jackson Hole and stayed in Jackson. The drive into the park was short and Jackson was a neat town. The visitor center at Jackson is nice. It has a little more content than most of the centers.We stopped at Moose. It is one of the few places to get food, gas and sundries. We ate pizza on the porch. The pizza wasn't great (nor was the service) but the view was fabulous.We stopped at the Craig Thomas Discovery and Visitors Center just by Moose. The center is worth a visit. You will only need 30 minutes to see it.We drove around Jenny Lake and then drove up towards Jackson Lake. We took the road to the top of Signal Mountain to see the valley. The view is good from there. We stopped at the Jackson Lake Dam and saw a bald eagle.We drove to Colter Bay and went to the visitor's center. There is a small store there to buy groceries and things. While driving through the park, we stopped may times. When we saw people pulled over by the roadside we would stop to see what they were viewing. We saw lots of animals that way. We saw our second bear because we pulled over to the side to see what another couple was doing. We met the nicest people this way. There are lots of hiking trails, there is much scenery and lots of fun to be had. What a great place to visit!

We planned to spend there only 3 days. This short stay turned into a 6 days long visit, and we will be back to do some multiday hiking and backcountry camping. What a great park!! It is shadowed by neighboring Yellowstone, but it really shouldn’t. Both parks are different, both offer different attractions. In Grand Teton it is challenging hikes (especially for those who like multiday backcountry camping trips), dramatic vistas. It also offers plenty of wildlife (although not as displayed as in Yellowstone) and fewer crowds especially when you hike past the canyons. I read comments about this place being boring, and if you just do your sightseeing from the car, or stick to paved walkways I can understand why the impression. If you hike, you will think different. We took long (up to 12 hrs) hikes and on one of them we only met 2 other guys. One thing I learned on more than one occasion – be always prepared for an animal encounter no matter how busy or secluded the trail is. We had a sow with 3 cubs about 50 yards from our campsite, huge elk at the campsite, moose cow with a calf on the trail, bear encounter, missed another bear on another trail by few minutes... in other words wildlife is everywhere. You might not see any but if you come with pets or kids keep an eye on them because this is not a zoo with fenced in animals. Having a bear spray is really a good idea. A lot of trails lead through dense vegetation, along river and waterfalls, and have several blind turns. It is easy to startle an animal.

On a clear, crisp October Sunday my wife and I had the pleasure of taking the self-driving tour of this spectacular national park. From crystal clear lakes to snow capped mountains, the grandeur of this place is unbelievable! A must visit while in Wyoming.
review_title: On a clear day you can see...everything!

review_body: One of God's gifts to us immortals was also a gift from the Rockefellers. Wildlife everywhere, stunning peaks, awesome trails. Leave Yellowstone to the caravans full of Asian tourists and head out to where the 'real stuff' is.

Didn't plan to visit this national park, it just happened that our accommodation is located at Moran, which is part of Grand Teton. The scenery was really desktop wallpaper material, it was really beautiful, especially in autumn.

We visited when there was smoke from a Yellowstone wildfire then rain- so the vista's were not as magnificent as they are on sunny days- and we still found it to be a beautiful park! Mountains, water, plains, wildlife, history, AWE- it has it all, and it's small enough so you can see and do what interests you the most. If you go to Yellowstone, tack on at least 1 more day to see the Tetons, more if you like to hike!

Beautiful park with lots of charm and beautiful scenery. Saw one bear deep in the woods and a few pronghorns and 3 moose that were chased away by a ranger so couldn't get a good shot. Mountains were absolutely awesome. Too crowded on weekends. Go during week if you can. Traffic not bad but there after Labor Day and middle of the week

Unbelievable. Photos certainly won't & can't do this park justice. So don't just drive through; get out off your vehicle and hike or bike. Whatever it takes to really experience the glory that nature has to offer here. Expect wildlife sightings.
The whole place is wonderful. The landscape is outstanding, the lakes and the peaks are fascinating. The visitor centers, the rangers, the information, etc are just what is needed.

While we enjoyed the views, it was definitely not as impressive as Yellowstone. We had and Access Pass so we get in free to National Parks. While Yellowstone would have been worth $30, we would not wanted to have paid the extra $20 to drive through the Tetons.
review_title: Nice Scenery, but Expensive Without a Free Pass

review_body: We were lucky to catch the park as it was closing for the season with perfect fall weather.Our near 50 mile drive on the park loop was the perfect way to experience the majesty of this park. Lacking the power of Denali or Yosemite, this park slowly permeates into your consciousness.Slow down and enjoy- save your hyper behavior for the so much bigger Yellowstone
review_title: More subtle than Yellowstone but world class as well

review_body: I hope those of you going to Yellowstone will also put Grand Teton on your agenda. This is sooo worth the visit...only an hour+ from the south entrance of Yellowstone. And if you really are short on time, make sure to visit Jackson Lake Lodge...go all the way inside the lobby. You will not regret it....go ahead, grab a quick lunch (at the coffee cart or the Pioneer Grill; both in the lobby) and go outside....BREATHTAKING.....it's postcard perfect.
One of my favorite national parks with beautiful mountains and lakes. The numerous hikes into the mountains are challenging and extraordinary.
While planning for Yellowstone, I came to know about this location via these forums and we are glad we decided to visit this place. Best place for mountain & lake views

We'd never heard of this park until we started researching our visit to Yellowstone, but we were so glad we decided to include it in the overall trip. It is completely different to YNP, & in many ways we actually preferred it. The mountain range itself is stunning, the lakes very pretty, & the main stopping points (Mormon Row, Menor's Ferry, OxBow Bend etc) generally much more peaceful. We drove up from an overnight in Jackson & had a 2nd night at Colter Bay Village, & this gave us plenty of time to see all we wanted to (including the boat trip across Jenny Lake & the hike up to Inspiration Point)

This amazing national park is grossly underrated.If You are visiting the more famous Yellowstone particularly if you are based close to the southern entrance please reserve a day to make the 42 Mile loop in this park.Get hold of a map which has well marked look outs beforehand because you will not encounter a visitor centre for 15 miles if you are doing an anticlockwise loop.Else do the clockwise loop so you get all the information at the beginning.The common entrance pass for Yellowstone and teton costs $50 per vehicle and is valid for a week,both park maps are given with entry pass.The oxbow bend lookout,Jenny lake and Signal hill are the most scenic places.You can stop by for lunch at Jackson lake lodge at the northern end of loop,which has the patio and lobby with most exotic view.Tip- visit it during fall,the red and yellow foliage adds to the beauty.
The Grand Teton mountains are a USA must see. Lodging is available there or in nearby Jackson. Plus Yellowstone is a short drive north. Plan on spending several days seeing everything.
review_title: Grand Tetons should be on everyone's bucket list

review_body: I was just there in late Sept, everyday was over the 70's, sunny, blue sky with Fall colors shimmering gold providing the contrast. Silence to be had everywhere even when there are fellow visitors. I understand that it's much busier during the peak season but the beauty of this land is perennial.
Do not miss touring this park. It rarely gets mentioned, compared to Yellowstone, but it is smaller, more compact, and has amazing scenery!

If you are going to be in the Jackson Hole area you owe it to yourself to check out the Grand Teton National Park. The views from the lakes are spectacular and the serenity of many of the areas is in measurable.

spent 2 days there, sunrise and sunset of teton are must-see, a little hiking. for me, it is bit expensive booking hotel in jackson,so i lived like one-hour drive away. still, a must-see at least once a life time. highly-recommend, 5 star.

While Yellowstone can be a bit overwhelming, both in scenery and crowds, our day at Grand Tetons was refreshing and beautiful. Basically it's a drive by the majestic Grand Teton mountain range with stops along the way for visitor centers at each end, many places to pull in and hike, a couple of lodges, and Jenny Lake. Gentle boat tours on the Snake River is also available. Highly recommended is either a hike or a boat ride across Jenny Lake, and the scenic drive up Signal Mountain for great views. A round trip can be done in a day, and I regret not getting to the south east corner of the park--there are some good photos to be had there. The park adjoins Yellowstone at its south entrance. Not knowing the area, we got a cabin that we thought would be nicely situated in between Yellowstone and Teton, but we ended up having to drive through Yellowstone a lot anyway to get to other places so we would have done better to find a place at one of the entrance cities of Yellowstone. Old Faithful Inn is perfectly situated for a trip into Grand Teton, since it's on the lower loop of that park. The way we did it was to drive outside the parks from Island Park, ID, down through farmland and into Jackson Hole, a stop in JH to eat second breakfast and walk around, then up through Grand Teton Park Road and up to the south entrance of Yellowstone, stopping at Old Faithful Inn for a late dinner and to see the geyser one last time, then back out through the west entrance and down to our cabin. Not a bad day, but I wouldn't recommend it.
review_title: AMAZING! And more managable than Yellowstone

review_body: We camped at one of the campgrounds there. The lakes and mountains were so beautiful. Many animals roaming around. Glad we stopped.

This park is very close to Yellowstone and I recommend visiting the park for its spectacular mountain range; Its very scenic are will put you in aw. There are many animals for viewing and has a lot of open land. I camped at this park prior to going to Yellowstone and have memories of a lifetime.
Great views, great family time, good hiking...rivers, lakes, trees, wildlife...this was a great adventure!
review_title: How Can you Rate a Natural Wonder?

review_body: Well you just have to see the Tetons sometime in your life. There's nothing like them. There are some great hikes all around to get good perspective.
Make it number one on your list. Seeing the Tetons at sunrise is a must. They are awe inspiring and bugling elk just gives you another whole dimension to the visit.

Beautiful national park with plenty to do for adults and children alike. It's definitely worth booking the free Ranger-led Wildlife Caravan where up to 10 cars trail the ranger's and intermittent stops are made to spot and learn more about the wildlife in the Grand Teton National Park.

or skip Yellowstone all together (wink). The Tetons have become my favorite place on earth. We made the mistake of going to Yellowstone AFTER the Grand Tetons and it was sort of a let down. We very quickly headed back to the Tetons for the rest of our vacation.. from hiking all the trails off of Jenny Lake to driving down Moose-Wilson Road.. it was all beautiful. We saw black bears, heard elk calls, saw moose and red fox. It was absolutely fabulous.
review_title: Do Yellowstone first... but save the majority of your time for the Tetons

review_body: This is a great National Park. Wonderful views of the rugged Tetons and peaceful lakes. Unfortunately when we were there the smoke from fires in California somewhat obscured the peaks. However, it still is a great place to visit. The Jenny Lake boat shuttle is very worthwhile. The boat takes you to a spot on the side of the lake where there are several great hikes which are not too long nor too strenuous for most seniors (1-2 miles, some elevation change).

The mountains and lakes were beautiful. The Snake River was eerily inviting while cold and demanding of respect. My only complaint was not with the park but the signs. Eventually, critters can read because the park is littered with signs of warning regarding the wildlife and the only "wildlife" we saw was a rapidly moving chipmunk. In spite of our lack of creatures, it was a gorgeous place and the final in the triple crown of mountains - Yellowstone, Yosemite, and the Grand Tetons. What a wonderful and beautiful country we live in.

Magnificent Teton Park National Park in Wyoming is an amazing collection of jagged peaks, tranquil lakes and stunning pine forests. There are numerous hiking trails, camping sites and the park is well known for mountaineering, hiking and fishing. Great family holiday destination.

The tour books rave about this park, and it does notdisappoint. We visited in late September in order toavoid the summer crowds, and it was perfect. Theaspens were glorious in reds and yellows, but theleaves had not begin to fall. Spectacular.Everyone needs to participate in this adventure at least once.
review_title: Better than the rave reviews of travel books.

review_body: After leaving Yellowstone National Park we drove to the Grand Teton National Park and were amazed by the magnificent mountains and the start of the leaves changing colors on the trees in the valleys. We enjoyed taking the scenic drive through the park taking in many splendid sights including wildlife. You need at least a full day to see the sights in this national park.
We visit the Tetons every year or so, and I never grow tired of the beauty and majesty of these amazing mountains. They are a must see for anyone traveling through this part of the West.
review_title: Some of the Most Beautiful Country Anywhere

review_body: I can't help but be awestruck when I drive through the Grand Tetons. Every time time is completely new with different clouds, light interactions and wildlife. The snake river is very nice to hike along and quite a few animals if you sit quietly.
review_title: America the Beautiful is exemplified when you see these mountains.
