Get up early and get photos of the mountains as the sun rises. You don't need to be a professional photographer to drive down to Schwabacker Landing or Mormon Row (where the most photographed barn in the world resides) and get some amazing photos. The entire park is a hiker/backpacker's paradise with an almost infinite number of trails, and easy access to Yellowstone NP. When we visited in 2008, they had just begun construction of the park's paved bike path. This is not completed from Jackson, WY all the way to Jenny Lake Lodge. I would never ride a bike in this park on the roads (too many people do the old "drift and jerk" when trying to look at the views while driving). However, the bike path is an awesome way to take in the vistas, particularly with kids.If you have not been to GTNP, just go. OK? Just go. Trust me.

We loved the lakes below the Tetons so much on our vacation its all we talk about. Jackson lake is warm enough for a little child to swim in. Lake Jenny has more awesome water to swim in and great hiking. We can't say enough. Love it more than any place in America.

Definitely do the hikes from Jenny Lake. Take the boat ride (beautiful and with great guides) and hike to the canyon via the beautiful trails. The scenery is amazing and the hike is moderate exertion. We could have gone further but at the 4 hr mark we knew our 17 year old had had enough. Great experience.
Beautiful mountains and a great stop for the kids and family alike. I really liked the loop you could take around the park and the many viewing points you could snap pictures at.
If you like wildlife and scenic mountain and forest views you will like the park! Worth every penny to get into the park!
After Yellowstone, one is simply awe struck by yet another natural wonder. The Grand Teton is wonderful even when enveloped by clouds.
This was our first time visiting and Oh my not the last.The Grand Tetons was just breathtaking.There was snow on several mountains in July but I have a feeling it never goes away.Just Gorgeous!!
We were driving from the south and the view of the Tetons as you approach is breath-taking ! Great area to hike and see wildlife - not as busy as Yellowstone.

Although very touristy, this place is not to be missed for the scenic beauty and the wildlife. The primitive campgrounds at Coulter Bay were spacious and well kept. The entire park is a photographer's dream

Wow wow wow! Overwhelming beauty here at the Grand Teton Park! Numerous excellent places to stop, take pictures and have a picnic! There's a Marina where you can have a meal or a pizza , but very busy during the peak summer! Plan for extra time to really pull over at the pull outs and enjoy this beautiful park!

The views of the Tetons are fantastic. It is what most people come to see. To really experience the parks wonders take a hikes or a boat ride across Jenny Lake to hidden falls. Or along the shore of String lake to Leigh Lake. For the more adventurous there are endless possibilities, Cascade Canyon is a must see.

We have a family of 5 and took an "epic" road trip in June 2015. Our kids were 5, 7 and 8 at the time. This park was the highlight of our vacation (loved it more than the Black Hills, Yellowstone and Rocky Mountain NP)! The views are breathtaking and there are so many hikes and fun places to explore. Take advantage of all the ranger-led activities that you'll learn about when you drive into the park and get the summer newsletter. We especially loved our hike at Hidden Falls, our experience at the Lawrence Rockefeller preserve (AMAZING building and habitat) and swimming at String Lake (a must with kids!). We also loved our hike to Taggart Lake. Can't say enough about Grand Teton NP.
review_title: Highlight of a 2 week road trip

review_body: We took an OARS kayak trip on Jackson Lake in the Grand Teton National Park, and it was one of the most memorable family trips. Jackson Lake is immense and beautiful. We kayaked during the day and camped at night at spots picked by our able guides. A few times we pulled into coves and hiked. It was a beautifully leisurely way to spend time in the park.
The sites in Teton National Park are like very few in this entire country. We have seen the mountains in Switzerland but I these are more beautiful.

This was our second trip here in the last two years. I couldn't wait to come back . We saw so much wild life that we were checking them off our wish list. The most incredible thing we saw was bear #399 with her three cubs . This was amazing , on this trip, we went later in June and it was s little more crowded and was slightly hazy every day .you had to wake up really early to catch the wild life. The trip was still amazing and we met some fantastic people. Can't wait until next years trip

Five days in the Tetons surrounded by wild flowers, abundant opportunities to hike, boat, wander and take it all in was heaven! Jenny Lake & Jackson Lake offer boating that gets you out right next to the Tetons.
review_title: Never Tire of Seeing This View!

review_body: We stayed at Jenny Lake Campground. They are 1st come sites and tents only. we were lucky to get 2 sites. All the sites looked spacious and had a platform for the tents. We took a few nice hikes and a boat ride. our jeep. We also had Elk and deer in our campsite. Jenny lake is beautiful in every direction!!! We ate at Signal lake lodge and that was yummy and another review!
review_title: I fell in love with Teyons!

review_body: We spent a whole day in Grand Teton, hiking and looking for animals. The day started chilly but quickly warmed up, so definitely dress in layers. It is definitely worth the trip if you have time.

Grand Tetons is a separate entrance than Yellowstone National Park, but the two national parks feed into each other. Grand Tetons is unique and beautiful rising straight out from the water. The visitor centers are different and each is worthwhile. The displays, exhibits, and movies are all good. The junior ranger program is well-worthwhile.

Everyone said that the Tetons were beautiful but that is no exageration. They are so different than the mountains in Colorado because they are so jagged and there are no foothills. There is the valley and then the mountains. Definitely worth the trip.

Must see at least once in your lifetime. By far the prettiest mountains in the USA. Be sure to stop at the lodge. While we were there we saw moose down in the mountain base. Plan to stay during sunrise or sunset for amazing photos.

I've wanted to see the Grand Tetons for years and finally got the chance last week. What a view. When yo get off the plane at Jackson Hole the Tetons are in hte backgraound. I drove the 42 mile loop. On one turn out not too far from the airport there was a herd of Buffalo just grazing in a field!!! First time seeing buffalo. Very cool. The Teons themselves still were snow coveered and look like a painting. Tremendous views of the moutinas when you get closer driving the loop. It was a great site to see and highly recommned the trip.

A lovely area full of incredible scenery and wildlife. The mountains are so picturesque that it's difficult not to keep photographing them from all angles. Saw loads of pronghorn plus an elk. Definately would like to go back and do more exploring as we were there for a couple of days and didn't see it all. The ranger talks are very interesting too. Managed to catch one about bears; the differences in them and how to deal with a bear encounter! There's nothing I didn't like as it's a very good park with great visitor centres and plenty of trails for those who want to head off into bear country.

Spent 3 days in Teton. Went up the cable car to the mountain top and had a bit of a walk. Views are fantastic. Struggled a bit with the altitude - couldnt understand why I kept having to take a deep breath. Anyway it was all worth it. Could spend much longer here and talke a chance to do some of the river excursions ... Maybe next time.
review_title: Beautiful place, Massive mountaind, Awsome view, Lovely people

review_body: Hiked to the summit of Signal Mountain and camped in Signal Mountain Campground. It was an awesome experience. Stayed three days. The Tetons cannot be seen in a day! Plan to hike and enjoy the lakes, trails, food, and wildlife.

There are plenty of things to do including hiking, canoeing, swimming & biking. The facilities are excellent and include a dedicated bike path. I would definitely recommend this to anyone planning a visit to Yellowstone.

When we planned our trip to the National Parks in the west we weren't sure if we wanted to visit the Grand Tetons. It is a much smaller park than Yellowstone or Glacier but it is very beautiful and we are very glad that we added this NP to our list! The loop road will take you to all the top area of this park. Be sure to stop at the pull offs and read all the interesting history about each area. Allow at least 3 hours or more for a visit. It was a great experience and we would definitely recommend Grand Teton if you are visiting that area of Wyoming!

It takes a lot to get me out of bed at 4am to go anywhere. But we hired a guide to take us for "an insider" experience: the Tetons at sunrise. How to describe? Awesome... magnificent... magical... you get the idea. There were just a few clouds to augment the color changes as the sun rose and cast its rays. Slowly they turned from grey/white to a yellow/golden hue. There were photographers with tripods and "just folks" with iPhones. (Not as crowded as sunrise at Angorwot, Cambodia!)Brad, our guide, knew just how to work the 5+hour trip... from the mountains to the flowers to the cabins to the wild life. And since he is a professional photographer he provided coaching throughout the experience.I guess there are some things/events worth arising in the wee hours of the morning :-)
review_title: "The Tetons at sunrise are a 'must' experience!"

review_body: You can make a perfect picture no need professional to help here you must see this beautiful landscape.

One of the most beautiful places in the entire world. Words cannot describe how lovely the scenery is here. One never tires of looking at the GT mountains because around every curve there is a new perspective of this gorgeous landscape. Everyone needs to see it in person at least once in their lifetime.

Grand teton park is a gem. Very nice hikes, great lodgings, beautiful nature, scenery and mountains, lakes. Lots of info at the site. We stayed 5 days and loved it. Very recommendable. Very close to yellowstone

We landed at the Jackson Hole Airport,grabbed a rental car and headed north toward Yellowstone. We entered the Grand Teton Park at the Moran entrance and within minutes arrived at Oxbow Bend and were overwhelmed with the beauty of the Tetons. The park roads were in great shape and we were surprised how quickly we could get from one attraction to another. We simply followed the scenic route stopping whenever we wanted. We saw bison, eagles and a few deer. We also stopped at the Moose Entrance and went to the visitor center where we got to touch all sort of animal pelts, planned a future 3 day hike and watched a 20 minute film about the park. Afterward we headed south and passed the numerous old homesteads and were back to Jackson Hole in 5 hours. What a great day trip for kids and adults :car- $50 entrance fee -$30 nature -priceless!
Breathtaking! This is to me the best National Park in the United States. I would spend more time there next time

Drove through Grand Teton National Park on our way to Yellowstone. Spent the day seeing the Teton Range from various viewpoints. Stopped at the Visitor Center first in Moose Junction to gather good information/tips from the park rangers. Then we drove the 42-mile scenic loop making various stops per the ranger's suggestions. Absolutely breathtaking!!
review_title: Teton Range is a Beautiful Sight

review_body: One of the prettiest parks I've been to - it is breathtaking. There are many clearly marked areas to visit. Check out String Lake in the morning - there is a peaceful walk. One of my favorite things was the boat ride on Jenny Lake over to the Hidden Falls - there is a short hike that is worth the walk to the falls. There are a sections that will make you breathe a little harder but I saw all ages on the trail. When you get to the falls, there is a shady spot to sit and look at the falls - it will be tough to photograph as there is harsh light and shade on them but they are really beautiful and the park does a great job on the upkeep of the trails. The park rangers are very vigilant and heavily monitor guest behavior. The monitor all groups making sure they have the correct permits in place, keep an eye out for drivers who may be drinking and insure you stay a proper distance from animals.

Took the boat ride across Jenny Lake and hiked the Cascade Canyon Trail out-and-back. Great morning! Views just incredible. Stopped along the creek, Tetons towering overhead, waterfalls, saw a moose, took lots of pictures. Boat trip a bit crowded coming back, but totally worth it.
Had my wedding....flew 7 of us from London, Ohio. A Storybook wedding....enjoyed Yellowstone, Jackson and Flagg Ranch...

Very accessible; spectacular beauty and wildlife everywhere you look, even if you aren't able to hike much. Please be a considerate visitor: don't speed, don't litter, be respectful of the land and the wildlife that you will see. Bring binoculars! Must do: a river float. a lake hike. a Dornan's sandwich.
So much smaller than Yellowstone but equally beautiful. You really have a great chance of seeing more wildlife here. Very crowded but worth the time and effort to see it.

A very short drive from Jackson on our way to Yellowstone, we entered the Grand Teton NP drive and it is a drive not to be missed. The views are fantastic, there are several places to stop with walks of various lengths. In our USA attractions I would rank this third behind the Grand Canyon and Bryce Canyon. for spectacular views.
If you are going to Yellowstone National Park, make it a point to spend sometime at Grand Teton. Grand Teton is very beautiful.

Grand Teton National Park surpassed my highest expectations. Gorgeous, accessible, and beautiful either up close or at a distance. To best enjoy the park, begin early in the day. We did the Taggart Lake Loop (about 3.9 miles round trip), starting about 8:30 in the morning. We were among very few in the parking lot or on the trail which made the experience that much more enjoyable. When we finished the hike, the parking load was over-full and the the trail was crawling with people. Because we had started with Taggart Lake, it meant that we got to Jenny Lake (among the most popular locations in the park) later. Jenny Lake offers the Hidden Falls and Cascade Canyon, two iconic Grand Teton sites. When we arrived, about 11, the parking lot was very crowded. (I think if you continue to the subsequent lots, parking gets a bit easier.) We were worried that the trails would be equally crowded but most people take the boat over to the falls. The walk is well worth is with appropriate footwear. (It's probably 5 miles round trip.) We walked the southern trail. The falls themselves are a bit of a crush, because of all the people coming off the ferry. Coming out of Jenny Lake, if you go north and complete the loop back to Jackson, more stunning views of the mountains that replicate the positions of Ansel Adams. I especially recommend stopping at the Snake River Overlook.Park Service personal very helpful. Entrance to Yellowstone and Grand Teton $50 which is good for one week.
Breathtaking scenery, easily accessible for all ages, especially with Jackson, WY, as a home base. Perfect for hiking and biking.
review_title: One of the greatest scenic views in the world

review_body: We camped one night at Colter Bay campground. it was cool and quiet, wonderful sleeping. There was a trail to Jackson Lake next to our site. We enjoyed that remote, quiet gorgeous spot twice. It was easy to get a spot, without a reservation so early in the season, the first week of June. Jackson Lodge is a beautiful place to relax enjoying the view of the mountains, with free wifi available.

The Grand Tetons are amazing. Every way you look there are brilliant views and so much to see! Please make sure you go if you are visiting Yellowstone! Don't miss it!! Even if you just do the 42 mile loop or even just the Park road, it's well worth the drive and the views. OUT OF THIS WORLD!!
review_title: Grand Tetons are AMAZING! Don't miss them!!

review_body: As part of a road trip my wife and I took last June (2014), we made it a point to travel through the Grand Teton National Park. The views are truly spectacular! The majestic mountains rise in rich pinnacles as you travel through the region, while the Snake River winds its way through the valley. The area truly is a sight to behold.
review_title: Majestic Mountains in Grand Teton National Park

review_body: We went to Yellowstone and Grand teton national park in june first week. We just went to Grand Teton and did the 42 mile scenic loop drive. It was really good and we were able to get some beautiful pictures.
It is beautiful here...bring your cameras for sure!!!! Lots of beautiful flowers, wildlife, birds, etc...
Beautiful, with all the snow on top of the mountains! We went in May, still pretty cold, snowing at times. Drove through going to Yellowstone!

The view of the mountains is breathtaking and makes you want to stop and take pictures every step on the way. Reserve all the time you can to see these beauties you will be happy you did! Jackson is also a nice town to stop and visit! Can't wait to come back!
review_title: The most beautiful place on earth :)

review_body: Oh My!!! We had such an Awesome Tour!!! Miguel Gaviria was super!!! We learned, saw, touched and enjoyed soooooo much of this awesome National Park!!! We were in awwwww!!!! Still are!!!!

The airplane landing is the first thing to take your breath away. The view never lets you down- whether lakeside, meadow, incline, or trail. Trailheads are well labeled and sparsely populated. The geology varies drastically depending on where you wander! Great history and props for painters galore.

The mountains and the trails are fabulous. It has a much lower key feel than Yellowstone to the north, but offers wonderful experiences. We rode horses twice at Jenny Lake, and people we talked to did fly fishing and river rafting nearby.
Beautiful park, lots to see, hiking, flowers, near Jackson, close to Yellowstone so include both in your trip!
A great contrast to YellowStone stunning to camp on Jenny Lake with the snow capped mountains beyond

We only spent a night in Jackson but we drove through the entire park on our way to Yellowstone. It's beautiful and you will get a chance to see some majestic elks. Just please have a bit of common sense: I have seen some Indian tourists getting extremely close to a huge elk male (like 5 meters way) and getting almost charged, besides we were trying to tell them it was dangerous.

The Grand Tetons offer a beautiful mountain range to stare at, hike, climb, mountain bike, and enjoy. This place is like a mountainous paradise where you can do anything. The lake in front of the mountain range is fun to kayak and take in all the beautiful views. There are also a variety of awesome hikes to partake in.
Spectacular scenery, loved seeing Moose in the wild, floating down the Snake River with Barker Ewing was beautiful

Visitors to Yellowstone Park should certainly make time to visit the Grand Tetons. While much of Yellowstone's sights are bizarre and unique, the Grand Tetons are just spectacularly beautiful. Friends of ours had passed through the park on route south, and strongly advised us to spend longer here than they had. So we had 2 nights at Jackson, and very glad we did. The visit to Jenny Lake and the hike to Hidden Falls is a great way to spend half a day. Jackson Lake also offers spectacular scenery. The views from Signal Mountain are fantastic, and Menor's Ferry is well worth a visit.
review_title: Wow!! Spectacular mountains, lakes and waterfalls.

review_body: My third trip to this park and it never ceases to "blow me away". It is so different to Yellowstone - lots of great hiking opportunities amongst pristine scenery and jaw-dropping mountain scenery. Even if you are not into hiking, there are lots of attractions you can drive to like Jenny Lake, Mormon Row, Menors Ferry Historic District, Signal Mountain etc. Some of these roads are not RV friendly - we hired a car for the day so we could go everywhere. Highly recommended! At present, your Yellowstone Park pass also covers entry into this National Park.
review_title: This park is a "must visit" if you are visiting Yellowstone

review_body: This is one of the most breathtaking national parks in the US that I've ever visited. June was an ideal month because the days were clear, nights cold and crisp and the park was filled with all kinds of wildflowers (and animals). We did a number of lake hikes; most were fairly well used but every time you looked up the dramatic Tetons were in front of you. Would highly recommend for a day hike the 6.5 mile hike around Two Oceans Lake (not far from Jackson Lake Lodge). It seems less used than most, but was spectacular. The trail stays near the lake the entire way, with only one short but moderate climb. I'd recommend going counter-clockwise so you experience the meadows in the morning sun, and the conifer forest in the afternoon sun. Remember, however, there is no access to the lake from the trail and few places to stop to rest. We went crazy over the varieties of wildflowers and butterflies nectaring. -take pictures and ID later. Our major complaint, however -- biting flies and mosquitoes (use PLENTY of insect spray).
The views are just indescribable! Tons of photo ops, hiking trails and nature all around!! Keep in mind that this is a natural habitat for animals and there ARE animals around!!
Majestic, awesome scenery with a lot of geological history. Many photo opportunities.If you are traveling the western National Park circuit, you do not want to miss this one !!!
review_title: Not to miss on a western trip

review_body: The road from Jackson to Yellowstone is lined by the majestic peaks of the Grand Tetons. Allow time for photos and take in a hike or 2! A nice bike path runs parallel to this road and was being extended during our visit.
review_title: From Jackson to Yellowstone Allow Time for Photos, Hiking, Biking (On a Nice Path).

review_body: Great park. I visited the park for four full days in early June.Lots of great hiking opportunities. Several lakes that you can hike around. Other more rugged hiking choices available. Great views of the mountains from many vantage points.Best place to see buffalo (and pronghorn) is at the Elk Ranch Flats turnout on the west side of the main road north to Moran Junction.To see moose, ask park personnel for ideas. One location is off a turnout on the east side of Wilson Road, which leads to the Laurance Rockefeller Preserve. From the main highway, turn left at the Moose Junction intersection. Stay on that road, past the visitor center, and turn left onto Wilson Road. This is before the pay station to enter the park. At the turnout on Wilson Road ask people already there if they have seen the moose or know where to look.Have lunch at the Signal Mountain Lodge, with a view of Jackson Lake. For a more formal dining experience, have lunch at the Mural Room at Jackson Lake Lodge, with its huge windows facing Jackson Lake.
review_title: Great Park. Lots to See and Do.

review_body: Everyone makes a big deal about Yellowstone, but we SOOOO enjoyed this park more. The beauty of the scenery is breathtaking from anywhere you are. The lakes are accessible. The trails are all well marked, and most seem to follow a creek or river for beauty and the sound of water. Accomodations are nicer than Yellowstone. Would love to go back --but it is far from California.
After visiting Yellowstone the two previous days, the Grand Tetons were a bit of a disappointment, mainly because there was very little wildlife. The mountains themselves were very pretty.
This park is great to go on day hikes and enjoy being "in the mountains" - We enjoyed our week in the Tetons! Great place to bring a family!

We just finished a 33 day road trip from Miami, FL and Grand Teton National Park, along with the Canadian Rockies (Banff and Jasper N.P.s), was the highlight of our trip so far as scenic destinations. We enjoyed Grand Teton much more than Yellowstone.
The Chapel of Transfiguration was a very inspirational and peaceful location. Loved it. Every turn throughout the park is a natural photo opp. Lots of wildlife and memorable scenery.
review_title: More beautiful than you can imagine!

review_body: We spent 5 days in Jackson Hole, visiting the Grand Teton National Park. We went rafting, spent numerous hours watching Elk, Prong-horned antelope, Coyotes, Golden Eagles, Badgers, Moose and a couple of Black Bears.The gondola ride up to the top of the mountains at the ski area was great.We saw the Old West parade and a lot of the activities in the downtown area of Jackson Hole.

My family took a road trip across the country and GTNP was our first true destination. It exceeded our expectations in every possible way. From the roadside spotting of moose, grizzly bears, and elk to the absolute grandeur of the mountains themselves, it was all just spectacular! We spent three night in Colter Bay Village and explored the area from there. We walked several trails, including Hidden Falls near Jenny Lake. The kids took a cold dip in String Lake. We picnicked all over the park. We just enjoyed the beauty as much as we possibly could! One evening we drove down to Jackson to watch the rodeo. That was fun, but as soon as it was over we were ready to head back up to the mountains. All the rangers that we met up with were very helpful with helping us determine which trail to take or which wildlife we spotted, etc. Also the park has a great water bottle refill station in many locations. Made it so convenient to keep our bottles filled with some excellent tasting water.We were all sad to have to leave even though we were heading up into Yellowstone. I hope that one day we can come back for a stay completely dedicated to the Tetons!

Grand Tetons are worth a one night stay during a Yellowstone visit but unless you wish to spend a night in Jackson Hole I would spend any extra time in Yellowstone. We did enjoy doing some hiking in the Tetons and breakfast at Nora's fish and in downtown Jackson Hole was wonderful on the day before our flight home.

This is a must do if you are in the area or going to Yellowstone. It is so close and you need to plan one day at least to drive through this park. Don't miss the opportunity. All of our national parks are spectacular in their own way, this one included.
review_title: Another of our great National Parks

review_body: All I can say it gives one pause to appreciate some of the most beautiful sights you will ever see. Some of the friendliest people I have ever met are in Wyoming.

We enjoyed our stay here immensely for its convenience and proximity to Jackson Hole. Through the vast cathedral windows of one lodge we viewed the great Tetons in all its rugged toothed splendor.he lodge's huge fireplace hearth and carved metal moose fixture are conversation pieces.String Lake and Jenny lake are other scenic wonders, silvery glass surfaces give way to aromatic ponderosa pine along the lake's fringes and mountain slopes and gradients with rustic logs lie at every location. The area too is a vasst meadowland of wild flowers in every hue of the rainbow. The mountains are truly quite amazing from both close-up and afar.Grand Teton Grandeur is a never to be forgotten spectacle.

I’ve had the good fortune to visit this national park on numerous occasions, and I’m in awe every time. Some people have told me that naïve tourists have actually speeded by the Grand Tetons on their way to Yellowstone from Jackson, Wyoming. Such a mistake! Absent any hiking, tours or float trips, you could drive every stretch of the main roads (Teton Park Road and U.S. Routes 191 & 89), stop at all the turnouts and maybe even hike a short trail or two, all in one day. Of course, visiting a lodge for dining or gift shopping, plus any kind of trail or tour activity adds time … possibly measured in days. Everything in this NP is simply amazing: the Teton peaks are dramatic, the Snake River Plain is very scenic, as are most of the turnouts. The trails vary from excellent to awesome. Bottom line: JUST GO!Here are some tips/recommendations for your consideration:(1) Area residents tell me that the peak tourist season is summertime, when families are traveling with kids.(2) Teton Park Road is closed in the winter, so my preferred times to visit are in the fall before the road closes (before ski season), and in the spring just after the road opens. Naturally, this can vary from year-to-year, but I shoot for either late-May or mid-September.(3) There’s a 2-mile stretch of Moose-Wilson Road between the Teton Village and Teton Park Road that is unpaved (traversable via standard passenger car, so don’t worry) and also closed in the winter. Even if it is open, the drive will be reduced to not much more than 30 mph—slower over the rutted parts—so try not to get frustrated. Given a closure, the alternate route from Teton Village is to go south to Route WY-22, through the town of Jackson, then north on US-191.(4) All of the roadways are east of the Teton Range, so early morning will provide direct light on the mountains. Teton Park Road will get you the close-up perspective, while Route 191/89 will provide vistas with the Snake River Plain in the foreground.(5) Virtually all the turnouts are worth a stop, which means: get out of the car. The one that should not be missed is called “Oxbow Bend,” which could be the one location where more photos are taken than from any other. Other must-sees are called “Jackson Lake,” “Jenny Lake,” “Teton Glacier” and “Snake River.”
review_title: Supremely awesome; worth designing a vacation around this NP

review_body: First of all, “Thank You” to all the Trip Advisors that provided great information for my husband and I to plan & experience a trip of a lifetime! This trip report is to summarize what worked for us. • Flew to Salt Lake City from California, rented a car. Stayed 1st night at Crystal Inn in Brigham City. Wanted to be able to go to a couple of local cheap store to pick up a cheap Styrofoam cooler, some lunch snacks and a case of water bottles. Staying in Brigham City allowed us to get onto Highway 89 easily and follow Logan Canyon to Bear Lake then up to Jackson – took about 5 hours max – a beautiful drive!• Stayed in Jackson at an Airbnb home! We had a queen-size bed with private bath. Was perfect location, $70/night – about 12 miles from Grand Tetons. Bought the $25 National Park pass for both Tetons/Yellowstone. Explored all of the Grand Tetons and the Visitor Centers, and did daily hikes around the alpine lakes. When weather was rainy, we took car rides to Wildlife museum, Teton Village/tram ride, drove to Mormon Row, Kelly, and Moose-Wilson Road. We spent our last night @ Signal Mountain Lodge. Was beautiful in evening but raining in the morning – so nice to be inside Grand Tetons NP for 1 night. • Jackson has a Dollar Store and several grocery stores – we stocked up on luncheon items, snacks, fruit, bread, peanut butter and jam before we headed to Yellowstone because for the next 8 days we were only going to be in Yellowstone NP and did not want to have to purchase groceries in the park – much cheaper in Jackson. We ate peanut butter and jelly sandwiches for breakfast, had lunch snacks, but had dinner somewhere each night. Coffee was always available at every location we stayed at.• Yellowstone NP: Stayed the whole time within the park.- Stayed 2 nights at Yellowstone Lake Hotel – beautiful! Lots to see and hike in southeast Yellowstone and Hayden Valley.- Stayed 3 nights in Canyon Village – explored Norris Geyser Basin and the area in-between Norris and Canyon Village 1 day. 2nd day – explored the Canyon Area. 3rd day spent from early morning till dark at Lamar Valley. - Stayed 1 night at Mammoth Springs to explore Travertine Terraces. Hiked a couple of short trails between Canyon Village and Mammoth Springs.- Road from Mammoth Springs to Norris was under construction. Spent last night at Old Faithful Inn. Spent time exploring all the Geyser Areas and took some short hikes. Then we left at the end of the next day for West Yellowstone.- West Yellowstone – spent time at Grizzley & Wolf Discovery Center – a nice slow day and stayed another night.- Headed back to Salt Lake City – turned in our car – took airport shuttle to Sheraton Inn. Our flight was at 4pm next day – Sheraton allowed us to check out late. Had time to sightsee downtown SLC and Temple Square.- Recommended books: Lonely Planet’s Yellowstone and Grand Teton National Parks & Yellowstone Treasures (Janet Chapple)- National Park lodging is expensive! Make your reservations 9 months to 12 months to get the rooms/cabins that you want.- Having a cooler, food, and water allowed us to make the most of our days in the parks. Water at National Park lodging is drinkable – so bring a reusable water bottle.- If you can attend a Ranger hike/talk or evening program – they are worth it!- The was a perfect time to go if you are looking for “minimum” amount of crowds – lots on vehicles were coming in when we were leaving – glad to have gone in late May! Still alittle snow on the ground, lots in the Mountains but it did not affect any hiking/car travel.*We each brought one carry-on bag with a day pack which included a raincoat with hood, gloves, hat, and scarf for each of us – only needed the raincoat – hiked in rain one day – not bad, a fun experience. Wore hiking boots most of time but did bring sneakers which was a nice change every once in a while. Weather was more on the wet side in Grand Tetons than Yellowstone – never saw the night sky which was our biggest disappointment due to clouds every night. Saw all the animals/babies except a grizzly – both parks are amazing! Having the time to explore it all was worth all the planning.We tracked all of our expenses for our 17 day-trip – it was around $5K. We felt that we were not extremely frugal nor were we extravagant. The Park Lodging is where we spent most of our money. Car (4-door Dodge Avenger) was about $585 for 17 days. We hope this helps someone else plan their “dream trip” to Grand Tetons & Yellowstone National Parks.
review_title: Tetons/Yellowstone Late Spring 16-day trip of a lifetime! May 21st- June 7th, 2015

review_body: May not be as wild and woolly as Glacier, or as varied as Yellowstone, but it is embraceable. Great hikes, great vehicle trails, lots of wildlife sightings. Around each turn, the three Tetons are visible and the Snake River footnotes the valley. Starting in Jackson, through the Elk Refuge, and up in to Yellowstone, the park offers everything. Boating, wildlife viewing, ranger talks, astromony lessons -- not mush is uncovered.

Visited the Tetons from Yellowstone, and in hindsight wished we would have spent more than a day here, possibly an overnight camping. Really beautiful vistas with multiple easy hiking trails. Would go again as part of a Yellowstone trip.
review_title: Next Time, We'll Spent More Time Here.

review_body: It is great to have two beautiful national parks right together, if you see one you need to see both. We just keep going back.
Amazing! So much wildlife and breathtaking views. You can pay for Yellowstone at the same time and they give a small discount on it.

We stayed at the Jackson Lake Lodge within the Park for four days in early June; this was our 6th visit. Saw three grizzly bears within one mile of the lodge and dozens of elk, pronghorn, and buffalo. Saw several moose just off the back deck of the lodge. The hiking is excellent in this park - did the hike near the Rockefeller Center with friends. It is a fairly easy three mile loop hike that is kid friendly. Lots of bears out so take Bear Spray if you hike in early summer. Rangers are very knowledgeable and helpful. This is a very easy park to get to in summer. American, United, and Delta all fly large jets into the Jackson Hole airport - which is within the Grand Teton National Park. We do the Breakfast Lake Cruise on Jackson Lake each time we come and we really enjoy that activity as well as the hiking and great places to eat. The breakfast buffet at the Mural Room in the Jackson Lake Lodge is outstanding. The mountains are just amazing to watch during the different times of day. Wildflowers are abundant in early summer. Just a beautiful national park!
review_title: Wonderful Park - great wildlife and hiking

review_body: Our 2nd trip to the Tetons and once more, fell in love all over again.How can anyone look at those beautiful mountains rising to the sky and not be overwhelmed with their beauty?Driving the lower road at the base of the mountains really gives you a sense of how big they really are. With their snow caps and distant waterfalls, just beautiful!I can't wait to go again.
I hear some people go to Yellowstone without visiting the grand Tetons. Both have different things to offer and both are national treasures

Unfortunately we only drove through Grand Teton but it is at least if not more beautiful than Yellowstone. There are large meadows, streams and amazing panoramic views. If you have time plan some days in the park you will not regret it.

The Grand Tetons were breathtaking! If you plan to go to Yellowstone make sure to make your way down to the Tetons, it's worth the drive, and you don't have to go all the way down to see them. They are huge, blue, beautiful, and one of the greater sights to go see.
Spectacular views, jagged jet lack, snow capped mountains. Unbound wilderness, moose, bison, deer, etc. roaming all over. Hikers, campers, hunters, fishers alike, this is the place for you.

Grand Teton is our favorite park. We have been coming here for over 40 years, love the slowed down pace compared to Yellowstone. This is a place to come kick back, relax and totally immerse yourself in the beauty that changes with each passing hour. I never get tired of these mountains, don't miss them at dusk it will take your breath away. This park is a place to know that God truly created this wonderful world and we are so blessed to be able to visit His masterpiece.
review_title: The Best National Park in the US

review_body: We had spent the Memorial Day holiday in Yellowstone National Park, which was incredible. We are so very glad that we drove the extra miles to stay at the Grand Teton Lodge and see Lake Jenny as well. The vistas (the Cathedral mountains-7 sisters) are absolutely breathtaking, especially at sunset! They are not to be missed. The boat tour on Lake Jenny is well worth the modest expense. We also hiked the area and enjoyed waterfalls, overlooks, and even a snowball fight. In the area we saw a brown bear, elk, moose, and plenty of buffalo. We did not see any grizzly bears on our trip. Binoculars and a good SLR camera are essential to take all of this in, but my iPad took some great pictures and allowed me to upload them to facebook to share with my friends. Be prepared to get out on foot and climb the hills, a moderate feat, but if you need to be dressed for the elements and climbing moderate terrain. We spent two days at the Grand Teton Lodge. The Wi-Fi was very good. However, we felt, coming from West Yellowstone, that in comparison, the food was expensive and the portions could have been more generous, but, we did not feel as if we were "ripped off" since it was only two of us, but I'd be concerned if we had brought our family of five/ The formal dining area was lovely, and we had a wonderful view of the Grand Tetons at sunset, but once again, very expensive. The accommodations at the Lodge were acceptable, they were clean and slept well, but for $225.00, I have had much better rooms. However, on the second day, we had toilet problems as the Lodge had just opened that weekend and toilets had not been used that winter, so their were explosions as clogged toilets were stressed. The maintenance team could not quickly rectify the problem so they suggested that we move. We requested and received another room. The staff was efficient and friendly. The gift shops in the Grand Teton Lodge had some lovely items, it was well stocked. The artwork was well beyond our budget as tourists, but glorious to behold. We had the opportunity to travel into Jackson Hole, WY from this location for a day trip, which was a great deal of fun. We really enjoyed our stay. God's masterpiece is on display in the snow capped Grand Tetons in May-June!
review_title: Grand Teton National Park & Lake Jenny

review_body: After Yellowstone you think you have seen the most beautiful scenery this side of Mars. Continue onto the Grand Tetons and prepare to be mesmerized! The mountains are magnificent. Wonderful hiking trails, just a place you must see. Non stop beautiful scenery. We hiked up to Taggart lake and it was great. Spend some time exploring here and you will discover magnificent view after magnificent view!
review_title: Wow Wow Wow!!! So beautiful - a must see

review_body: Always heard how beautiful the Tetons were and finally got to visit. They are just that and more, we visited first week in June and the mountains were still snow capped. Jenny Lake was clear and pristine. Saw elk, buffaloes, pronghorn antelopes, but no bears. Just the right amount of commercialism in the park. Don't be in a hurry, the animals have the right of way.

We went from Jackson into Grand Teton National Park with Paul Brown of Teton Science Schools' Wildlife Expeditions on 15 May, 2015. He was a wonderful guide - extraordinary ability to spot wildlife while driving, equipped with scopes and binoculars, very knowledgeable about any animals and birds we saw. Without him, we would have seen little on a dull, rainy day but he made our visit memorable. Highly recommended.
We were travelling to Yelllowstone and this area took us by surprise it was just beautiful.We took the cable car to the top and the views were stunning.

What a gorgeous, impressive, fantastic place ... the mountain views change swiftly in the varying weather conditions and time of day, always something to see differently. We saw elk, moose, mule deer, bison, Uinta ground squirrels, yellow-bellied marmots, a great grey owl, chipmunk, and so many butterflies and birds I haven't even got them all listed yet. I didn't realise before we arrived just how beautiful the mountain range would be or how diverse would be all that we saw. go!

Best trip we have taken with our 5 and eight year olds that was both active and relaxing. Saw so much wild life and great to be outdoors in nature. Must see Jenny lake and go early before the crowds descend. We visited in early June and there were not a ton of people and the weather was still great.

Beautiful mountains and trailheads everywhere....and very little traffic. We visited the Grand Tetons and Jackson WY and were impressed by the beauty and stillness and wildlife. Yellowstone however was cramped, and crowded with traffic jams. We traveled the John D Rockefeller Memorial Parkway and loved every minute of it...using the turnouts to drink in the beauty. Buy bear spray and take off down a trailhead. You won't regret it.
review_title: I Liked The Grand Tetons Better than Yellowstone

review_body: We did 3 days in the Jackson and Teton Village area. What an amazing time with all the beautiful sites. Nature at its best. The only way to descibe the Grand Tetons---amazing!!!
Amazing visit as always! Campgrounds fill fast so grab yours early. Plan a hike, take in the view from the summit of signal mountain, hop on the Jenny Lake ferry, plan to stay a couple days at least!

We drove from Jackson Hole in to the Tetons. This is absolutely awe inspiring. We saw many animals in the area like elk, and deer. The snow capped mountains are breathtaking. I wish I had planned for more time in the area. This is a must see park.

During the three days we visited GTNP, the peaks of the mountains were covered by clouds. The weather was not at its best, but we still enjoyed our stay there and appreciated the beauty of the Grand Tetons. We came from Yellowstone NP and took the John D. Rockefeller Memorial Parkway to enter the park via the Jackson Lake junction. We stopped at the numerous turnouts to see the mountains, view wildlife (although mostly deer, did not see a bear), and had a picnic. We stopped at the different visitor centers to learn more about the park.The next day, we entered GTNP from the opposite direction at Moose junction since we were staying at Jackson. We then visited the other attractions we did not see the previous day like the Mormon row, Chapel of the Transfiguration, and the hike to Jenny Lake.
review_title: Still majestic even if covered by clouds

review_body: Beautiful scenery well sign posted moderate walk through forest track. Additional extras Ie to The Hidden Fall provide optional vistas to enjoy.
We drove from Yellowstone to Grand Teton National Park. The parks are surprisingly different. They are both worth the drive. The tetons have lake and mountain vistas.

The Tetons are something that you must see at least once in your lifetime! We visited everyday while we were there (7 days). The rangers were super friendly and helpful. A real treat for us was that because I was over 62, I could purchase a lifetime pass to all National Parks for $10. Normally it costs $25 for a 7 day access. If you qualify- get in on it! You've made it, so you might as well enjoy it!!!
Visited on a clear day and were rewarded with incredible vistas of the mountain tops. The streams were full and running - everything was green. Just an incredible place to see.

By the Grand Teton, I'm assuming the park, the range and the mountain itself. All are world class, one of the most beautiful mountain ranges in the world. Millions of people come from all over the world to see this. I"ve been coming for 50 years. Come in late spring or early fall to avoid the crush.

We visited the Tetons after 4 nights in Yellowstone. Obviously they are different types of Parks since Grand Teton is much small but there are other important differences. Animal viewing was MUCH better at Teton. We saw more animals closer up than we ever saw at Yellowstone. This included several black bear sightings, bison, elk, moose, deer, pelicans, and a variety of ducks. The park is also much more biker and hiker friendly than Yellowstone and the food options are much more plentiful and better. We did game viewing drives twice a day but the best time was between about 6:45p.m. and 8:30p.m. We stayed at the Teton Mountain Lodge and there is an interesting drive between Teton Village and Moose (1 1/2 miles of which is not paved) that we had to traverse several times. Teton Village is really nice albeit "upscale" and a bit pricey. There are a number of smaller lodges in the Park that you may want to check our if you want to actually be in the Park. Jenny Lake lodge looked interested but we did not stay there. For the sake of some sort of brevity I will but this off but if you have any questions please feel free to contact me.
Breathtaking is all I can say! To see the Grand Teton in person is absolutely amazing! Make sure to get up early one day and see them at dawn. You will not be sorry.

The Teton Mountains are very beautiful. I went in early June, and the snow capped peaks were gorgeous. When the wind is still, you can get some great photos of the reflections of the mountains in some of the lakes. Food, especially good food, is hard to find. I recommend picking up fruit and other food items and water that will satisfy you for the time you expect to be there.

We travelled to Teton in May having been to Rocky Mountain NP and Yellowstone NP. IT WAS DEFINITELY THE HIGHLIGHT. We saw lots of wildlife, black bear, cranes, elk etc but best of all the unique landscapes, stunning.
review_title: Breathtaking views, snowcapped mountains high above the flat plain, reflected in crystal clear lakes and rivers,

review_body: We woke up early to get a good start in Jackson the mountain was socked in with fog. We kept driving towards Yellowstone and little by little the mountains showed their stuff. Recommendation is to not start so early expecially on a late May day.
review_title: Tetons pause and take in the scenery and the fresh air

review_body: This is one of the most beautiful places on earth. I am not exaggerating! I had always wanted to go, but being from Colorado, I had not expected for my breath to be taken away by the spectacular mountains. Just beautiful.

This review is for the park alone, not the valley. I've been going to Teton park for forty years and although I no longer climb there (probably a good thing) it's much the same as it was long ago. Of course there are more visitors and things are a bit harder but it's still one of the most sublimely beautiful and majestic places on the planet. Just don't think you'll be enjoying it by yourself. The town on the other hand seems to be a total loss. I used to enjoy going to the Cowboy Bar but now once you get into town your only thought is to get back out of it.

I came in the latter part of winter. I didn't mind the cold. Just come prepared...like with wool clothes...I stopped at the vista point right after leaving Jackson Hole, WY and then stopped along the way to see the beautiful icy streams. The weather didn't stop anyone from visiting. The roads were actually pretty busy through the park. I went inside to see the Jackson Lake Dam, where there were people ice-fishing. It was around -4 degrees fahrenheit. It's best to see it when the snow is deep. I also like seeing the Glacier stop as well. Marvelously scenic !!!!
review_title: Mostly closed, but I didn't care. It was beautiful

review_body: Alltrans/Gray Lines tour. Jackson HoleIt was just fantastic . Our guide was Mr Jessie O'Connor. He was spectacular, most knowledgeable, entertaining and I highly recommend him. We had almost cancelled but were so thankful we went . Gosh did we learn a great deal about the area and enjoy the scenery

The park is, first and foremost, very different from Yellowstone. It takes more work to see things. The animals are more widespread and not as close to the road, the sights may take a little more hiking, etc. But, this is helped out by lots fewer people. The fishing, to me, was excellent and worth the effort. Sunrise, and Sunset, at Oxbow/Mt Moran are not to be missed. As a caution, in the fall it might be really cold (10-15 degrees) for Sunrise. The Park takes, as I said, more effort to see but it is well worth it.
review_title: Always something new, different, and spectacular

review_body: A bit sad that we not enter Grand Teton from JD Rockefeller highway because he was still closed.The visitor center was also closed.Maybe in the future we will visite again...when we can take the boat to the otherside from the lake&start there the walks
Wonderful place to visit for a vacation! There is so much to do. Hiking, wildlife watching, shopping etc!

It was an amazing day at Grand Teton National Park. We went there as an unplanned trip, cos of weather condition at Yellow Stone. Cannot explain the beauty of this park, the glaciers view of these tallest mountains, Jenny Lake, Jackson Lake and the trails for evening walk, everything is awesome. One must plan to visit this park if you are going to Yellow Stone.
review_title: The best NP I have been so far

review_body: Grand Teton is a beautiful National Park with many activities for the whole family. There are gorgeous mountains, plenty of wildlife, beautiful lakes, waterfalls, and many hiking trails available. I would recommend a visit here
amazing drive from yelllow stone...leeks marina is beautiful . worth it !! the pizza is great here !!!

Spend some time hiking the trails, visiting the Visitor Center, listening to ranger talks and picnicking. Highly recommend getting out early in the morning for the best views of the Tetons and of getting to see animals.

Hiked around Taggart and Jenny Lakes despite the intermittent rain . It was time well spent. The wildlife wasn't prolific but I did see a moose munching in an alpine field. I also had a marmot join me in a jog down the trail which was sort of bizarre. Bear spray is a really good idea and knowing how to use it is an even better one. The boat ride on Jenny Lake provides a lovely view and is worth the ride in one direction . If I did it again I would hike towards the west dock and take the boat back to the south.
Amazing creation of God!!! This is one of the prettiest places I have ever seen. I think everyone should see it in person..

Just visited the Grand Teton National park for 6 days and I'm speechless in a good way. If you love the outdoors and nature. Then this is definitely the place for you. So many beautiful trails to hike and explore. The abundance of wildlife to see is amazing. We saw bear,moose,elk.antelope, and different birds of prey. Hikes can range anywhere from easy to difficult. But there is always something for every level of experience. I can't wait to to go back!!!

Amazing scenery and wildlife. The Grand Tetons speak well enough for themselves. Even with lousy weather, we are finding times usually early in the morning when you can see the whole mountains. Unfortunately, the week we visited was cold and rainy. However, that did not stop the wildlife. The Grizzly Bears and their cubs frequently are easy to find, we are having the best luck in the Oxbow Bend area. We have seen the sow and her two cubs for three days in a row, morning and evening. One time she came with in 25 yards of us. We now carry bear spray which is highly recommended by rangers. They will teach you how to safely use it. Many bison, elk, pronghorns and deer are also easily seen throughout the park. Hiking down along the Snake River provides lots of great vistas with reflections of the mountains in the water. Of course, don't forget Jenny Lake and Colter Bay, great hiking sites (provided you are carrying bear spray).
There is nothing to dislike! I had bad weather and it was still awesome! There is lots of wildlife. The roads meander, but are mostly level.
What an amazing view!. Our bus tour stop along two places so that we can admire the view and no matter which way you see it, it is amazingly beautiful. I will go back again in a heartbeat.

It is worth visiting Grand Teton especially if you are going to be visiting Yellowstone National Park as one fee covers both - when we visited it was $25 for a car (less for individuals accessing by foot/bike). We didn't do any of the walking trails but drove between the various sites. The scenery is spectacular and we tool lots of photos. We had average-showery weather and it was still beautiful to see and enjoyable.
This place features some of the most incredible views you will ever see. The mountains are so gorgeous.
Lake Jenny walk to inspiration point was fantastic, boat over and walked back on shortest route, took about 4 hours not too difficult

Wow the views at Grand Teton was absolutely beautiful! It was a nice drive through the entire park. Stopped by Jenny Lake area and the views were stunning. We really didn't see much wildlife as we had hoped to. I recommend spending a day at the park and enjoy the views while you're there.

We have travelled to Grand Teton every year for the past 34 years. Each time is a new experience and it is always different. From the mountains covered with snow, or clouds to blue skies and green trees. The lakes are amazing, the wildlife incredible and there is always something to do. Every site is a photo op!Grand Teton is one of the most beautiful places in the world.
review_title: One of the most beautiful places in the world!

review_body: The views are absolutely breathtaking! I am so glad that we took the time to explore the park. Make sure to leave some time for some hiking. There are plenty of easy hikes around the park. Took a breakfast cruise at the marina. Highly recommend! Got to see some neat things that we would not have seen otherwise. Get up early if you want to see the animals roaming around.
review_title: A must stop if you are in the area!

review_body: You must see this at least once in your lifetime. Breathtaking. Do as many hikes as you can. And if you can afford to, stay in the park at least one or two nights. There is nothing like waking up in the park to tremendous views.

Bad weather in South Dakota meant we travelled west in our journey to Yellowstone earlier than expected, allowing us an unexpected longer stay in grand Teton. This park is included in Yellowstone NP entry fee (we had our year pass though) but is definitely a standout on its own as well, and because it isn't quite as large as Yellowstone it doesn't feel as overwhelming to complete a couple hikes. It is a different environment to Yellowstone, full of flat land filled with sagebrush (and hence deer, elk and mountain sheep) that is flanked by stunning mountains with crystal clear lakes. We went on two shortish hikes and the Jenny lake scenic drive over the day and a half we were there. The Taggart lake walk was a great fairly easy there and back again trek, with a little tough uphill section that even a whiny thing like me can cope with! We ran into an elk (literally) and a few grouse, and loved the lake view at the end. You walk through a mix of rocky trail, bit of light forest and a meadow, all allowing for lovely surrounds. The Jenny lake scenic drive scored us our first bear, and we were lucky enough to be able to watch him from just about ten or so metres (from our car obviously) all by ourselves for a good amount of time before others turned up. The Jenny lake walk is a little confusing to work out but once we picked an amalgamation of the hikes to make for a loop it was very enjoyable. Mainly wooded sections with a fair uphill (not tough though) with a marshy area to allow for moose sightings and then marmot heaven of meadow with many big warm rocks. Beautiful views of course. Definitely worth a side day trip if you are solely considering Yellowstone.

This was our first time out west, so many things were beautiful. I love the drive into Jackson, Wyoming, even before you get to the park. Visitor center staff were warm and welcoming, and gave us tips on the special places to stop and visit, as well as good photo ops. It took longer than expected, and it was colder than anticipated, but we had an amazing time.
review_title: Chilly gray day - but simply breathtaking

review_body: These mountains are incredibly beautiful. Most definitely one of the most spectacular mountain ranges anywhere in the world.My approach was from Jackson, WY. The drive is wonderful. I almost couldn't believe my eyes when the Teton peaks came in to view for the first time!Make sure to stop at one (or make it two or more!) of the many viewpoints along the highway to take in these majestic mountains. I especially loved the Snake River Overlook. Impressive.I would recommend spending at least one night in this beautiful place.

I try to get out to this area every summer and am never disappointed unless the peaks are fogged in or clouded over. I love staying over in Livingston and then just heading down to Yellowstone, the Tetons, and Jackson. Do not miss!
review_title: Still jaw dropping after many visits!

review_body: This was a nice time to visit the park because there weren't a lot of people there. Also, with there being snow still up high the animals are down low where they can feed, so we got to see large herds of elk and bison - some that weren't even very far from the road. A few bison were right by the road. We were hoping to see some grizzly, but no luck. However, we did see a large old moose in a river on our way back to town. After a few pictures he ran off into the brush. I guess he was tired of people staring at him from the bridge.
Visiting the Tetons brought such great peace over me. Lovely scenery and the mountains are just beautiful.

We really enjoyed our trip to Grand Teton National Park. The drive through the park was nice, the views were amazing, there were tons of places for people to pull off so that they could look at things and there was lots of wildlife. We will definitely go back.

We made it before the snow came in April 2, 2015 then we watched the landscape change in its magic of the late snow! Incredible is an understatement!!! Call or review ahead for peak park openings as the summer season doesn't start till May 1

Don't ask me why but my wife has always wanted to see a wild Moose and where else should she see her first one but a small village called Moose... Grand teton is a fantastic National Park - within a few miles f a car park you're unlikely to see anyone else for the rest of the day.

Yellowstone gets all the credit as being the first national park, and it truly is an amazing place, but a trip to Yellowstone without including the Grand Teton National Park, and in particular a view of the Teton mountains and Mount Moran is simply incomplete. The Tetons are one of the most impressive mountain landscapes in the world. My Idaho friends don't like to hear it, but if you are planning to visit, make sure you drive through on the Wyoming side. The view is that much better. If you are coming from Yellowstone, consider stopping for a snack at the Jackson Lake Lodge for an extended view of the Teton range from indoors. This will be particularly welcome in the colder months. The view from the Wyoming side is east facing so morning and early afternoon hours are generally better than the silhouetted evening hours (though this is impressive in its own right). If you are in Jackson, consider making a lunch stop at The Granary. The food is decent, but the view is unparalleled especially if you get one of the two outdoor tables in the summer months (don't forget to bring a hat!)
So worth a visit as part of a trip to Yellowstone. The most amazing mountains I have ever seen, wish we had stayed longer than one night.

The route was a bit spicy on the approach. But as the herd of MOOSEN went ape we sprinted on the burley pavement as our escape. The rest of the route was sketch. However, the exit was sicky sicky gnar gnar with a little heel strike over the closed gate.
review_title: SIIIICK JAGGED DOPE AS SOAP SAWTOOTH PEAKS

review_body: It seems Wyoming has more wildlife than any place in the lower 48 . Come see for yourself, but come in the off season to avoid the crowds.

If you are going to Yellowstone make sure you take the drive south for a few days. While not as much wildlife as Yellowstone, the view are amazing. We did find two bull Moose that were hanging our in the River and the Gas Station at the south end of the park. There are several visitors centers in the park. Each focuses on different elements of your stay. There miles of walking and biking trails to enjoy, from relatively flat and easy to the very rugged and strenuous. You could easily spend a week here.

It was a cold and rainy day but when it cleared, we saw spectacular views of the snow covered peaks of Teton Range rising abruptly from the valley. It was awe inspiring. The reflection of the Tetons on the pristine Jackson Lake was simply breathtaking.

Yes, go during winter time. You can snowshoe and a great way to do it is to take tour with a park ranger. They even provide the snow shoes. Very relaxing and easy going and great for the kids. Dress warmly, gloves, hat, etc.... Absolutely gorgeous!

I love the US especially for its National Parks. There are som many rock formations we do not have in my home country. In Grand Teton I rented a mountain bike and watched the beautiful scenery. I can strongly recommend this NP - I would go back if I could!!

I always tell people "if you're going to Yellowstone, go to Grand Teton too!" The same is true the other way around. The Teton range is awe inspiring from Jackson Hole. Rising from the valley without foothills is amazing to see. I've been going to the Tetons since I was little and after moving to Kansas City, made it a point to visit almost every year. Even though the mountains don't change, every year brought new found pleasures. The animals are plentiful and varied. The wild flowers brighten any day. The air is clean and the weather is a joy to watch. The best time to go is August if you want to avoid rain. But by August, many wild flowers are past their prime. Likewise, the peaks are usually hazy then. I've gone in all of the late spring to early autumn months (4 days usually) and I've never been disappointed.

The saying goes that the Tetons are named because they look like three large breasts. To be sure a visit to the Tetons will nourish you body and soul. The beauty of the place is breathtaking. We camped at a lake to the south of the Mountains. The time we spent allowed us to catch the changing of the terrain according to where the sun was at different times. Well worth a visit.
review_title: South of Yosemite a view to be cherished

review_body: on our way out of Yellowstone we stopped by the Grand Teton and walked along Jenny Lake and Coulter Bay. It was very pretty and scenic.
We drive through in the middle of the afternoon. I would have loved to take the drive at sunset. You won't regret or forget the views. I can't wait to go back west at sunset.

We loved our trip to Jackson Hole and The Grand Tetons. There is something for everyone of all skill levels and ages - hiking, climbing, rafting, kayaking, fishing, nature photography... We rented a condo overlooking the park in September and when we weren't in the park we shopped and ate in town. One of our favorite trips!
By far one of my favorite places in the states! Get outside! The fresh air and the grand tets make for a wonderful day!
Amazing highway to see the Grand Tetons and great places to hike and have amazing views. If you go to Yellowstone, definitely worth the hour drive to Grand Teton National Park.

The park is not as stretched out as you would expect. We stayed here for a day, which is in fact good enough to get a good impression. If you wish to make some hikes, go for the longer ones. You will get to enjoy more of the nature with less humans around. Great panoramic views from both the lower flats as well as from higher grounds. It can get very crowded during the weekends. We were here in the autumn and could enjoy the changing colours of the leafs. A great plus! Makes things look even more impressive.

Go to the end of the road off Moose junction. you can ski 15 miles in one direction. the park service grooms skate and classic tracks. It's rolling easy fast terrain. great place to get a workout. few people. wonderful scenery. FREE. What's not to like?!

There really is not a bad time to visit unless it's in the middle of summer with all the other tourists. I've lived nearby and visited so many times and it's beautiful during all the seasons. Hiking, wildlife, mountain views, mountain lakes, it's really a magnificent place. We camped and had a sunrise that was indescribable as the sun made its way over the mountain.
review_title: Easily one of the most beautiful places on earth

review_body: Grand Teton is simply the best national park there is. Need I say more? Although take a tip from a local and avoid Jenny Lake. Too overrun with tourist and not anywhere close to the top of most scenic places within Grand Teton. Go to Schwabacher Landing instead.

We arrived at Grand Teton National Park in late September. The Teton mountain range rises majestically into the sky. It was an awesome sight. We spent hours in the park before we saw a single soul and then recruited a mom and daughter to take our picture. We did see bears, bison, moose, elk and many different birds. There are hundreds of miles of hiking trails for all levels of hikers.We hiked around Jenny Lake which was formed by a glacier over 12,000 years ago. The Jenny Lake trail loop is just over 7 miles. The trail was not that strenuous for this middle aged couple ( it took about 3 hours 45 minutes) There were also boat rides, camping. and a very expensive lodge. The reflection of the mountains in the lake was a breathtaking sight that I will never forget. You will not need as much time here as you do in Yellowstone, but you should go to both parks, they are very different. Even Ansel Adam's photographs do not compare to the real thing, it is a sight you need to see for yourself.

Grand Teton... While working in YNP I got a chance to drive through and hike in GT (even brave enough to camp!:)) numerous times. I fell in love like a child. The most gorgeous scenery. The tits just have their power I guess:P Definitely I place worth visiting if you are a nature-wild life, hikes, lakes, flowers sunsets, sunrises, etc.-lover.

Drove through Grand Teton at the beginning of November - weather was fine, just needed a jumper. Had the place to ourselves - as in we spent a couple of hours at a beach on the edge of the lake and never saw a single person or heard a sound. Just us, huge mountains perfectly reflected in the lake and a moody sky (and thankfully no bears). It is indescribably beautiful. Photo's do not do it justice.

We visited the Grand Tetons in conjunction with our trip to Yellowstone National Park. It was a wonderful way to end our trip. Although we loved Yellowstone, the Tetons were different in a lot of ways.The mountains to start are amazing. Although it's only a 15 mile range, it is visually stunning. Similar to Yellowstone, there are wide and varied landscapes and scenery, but in our case, much less congestion. There are plenty of turnouts along the scenic route to stop and take photos or hike, but there are also less facilities available. We had underestimated the distances required to travel in YNP, so in many ways, GTNP was easier to navigate.Although we saw very few bison here, we lost count of the elk and deer that we encountered. Early mornings and dusk were the best times, and Signal Mountain Road was a prime viewing area. We arrived at Mount Moran Turnout before dawn to take pictures of the rising sun rays on the mountains. These are some of our favorite pictures from our entire trip. You can enter the park from the southern part of YNP, but the road is only open from mid-May to around the end of October. You enter on Route 26 from the west at the Moran entrance, and from Jackson on 191 from the south. The good news is that you only have to pay one entrance fee that applies to both Yellowstone and the Tetons. I certainly recommend visiting the Grand Tetons. You won't need as much time as you will in Yellowstone, but it is worth the trip!

On our tour of the mid west, we stopped at the Grand Teton National Park.We took a raft ride down the river, past the beautiful mountain ranges and other scenes of natures best - including bald eagles.It's really breathtaking and serene.. The mountain ranges are awesome.One of the best experiences of our lives. - Spectacular..Enjoy !!!

The Teton range peaks are spectacular. The Teton Glacier sits on the northeast side of the Grand Teton. The Grand Teton National park seemed small to me but I'm glad I had a chance to experience it. If you are short on time, skip this park and spend your time in Yellowstone (just to the north).
Lot's to do and see. They have cool little cottages in the area. Defiantly suggest, especially for the outdoors type.

If you pay to get into Yellowstone, you get into Grand Teton as well. We were very glad we made the trip down to see it. The mountains are amazing and the lake is beautiful. Also be sure to stop by the Craig Thomas Discovery & Visitor Center. We were planning to go out of Yellowstone through West Yellowstone to get home, but we're glad we changed our route and drove through Grand Teton too!

Gorgeous park; very manageable and lots to do. Great hikes, a nice bike trail by Jenny Lake and the Tetons are spectacular; can't take your eyes off them and they change with the light, weather, time of day. Many options for accommodations, dining and activities. A wonderful National Park!

Stark and violent results of a cataclysmic event. It appears to be younger than Yellowstone as evidenced by sheer vertical mountain sides. Beautiful flowers are quite abundant....even during the autumn (September).
My words are so unnecessary... just look at the pictures of wildlife and scenic views. any nature lover would be excited to visit.
the trees and their height was something to be seen as well as the mountains. The drive through was worth the time it took .
The views of these grand mountains, painted in changing colors each day,with the changing weather and the vast arena they tower over, are as clear in my mind as ever.
review_title: An iconic landmark that should be on anyone's bucket list

review_body: After some spectacular days in the Sawtooth NF we didn't think we would find better scenery but how wrong we are the Tetons are phenomenal. We enjoyed our time here more than in Yellowstone, the hiking was spectacular.
Scenery is incredible! Wildlife is amazing!! We stayed on Jackson Lake at Signal Mountain Lodge. Couldn't ask for a better view!
review_title: A great addition to trip to Yellowstone!

review_body: Although I had been in this area as a youth growing up in Wyoming, I shared the experience with my wife's eyes for the first time. From the unmatched views of the Teton range to the lakes and all the wildlife, it's hard to imagine a better place to spend a while. Add to that all the attractions from singing ranch hands, the Jackson Shops and accommodation you can't go wrong. It's also no time at all to experience Yellowstone National Park. A great plus is that you can usually find somewhere to stay on short notice at Jackson, unlike Yellowstone. We will talk about our trip and revisit the hundreds of pictures for many years
review_title: Bears and Elk Buffalo and Antelope oh my!

review_body: The views are the best. I seen A brown bear and the snake river in the fall is really something. A beautiful experience here at the Grand Tetons

This place, in my opinion does have some of the most beautiful views in the US!One cannot get enough of the views over the Snake River towards the tetons. We were so fortunate to have spotted three brown bears in mid November, which made our visit extra special!
review_title: Some of the most beautiful views in the 48!

review_body: We visited the Tetons at the end of the day when things were shutting down for the season. We traveled along the road between Yellowstone and Jackson Hole. Not a lot of traffic but the scenery was spectacular. There is a fee if you come from Jackson Hole to the park.
review_title: Beautiful View on a fall day

review_body: The lakes and the mountain range is absolutely spectacular. We did a hike to inspiration point which is a must.
Picturesque/beautiful to look at, and take pictures in front of from many angles. Saw them on a bus trip. Only thing missing was restroom facilities.
Love seeing these majestic mountains up so close. Watched several beaver for a long period of time, and one moose.
Such and awesome sight! We actually saw more bison than we did at Yellowstone! And we saw a huge Bull Moose at Moose Junction! Breathtaking views! Truly Magnificent!

Although we have been here before, this is one of our favorite places. The scenery is unbelievable and there are many opportunities to get out of your car and get closer to nature. Despite several days of rain, we were able to get in some hiking and it was heavenly. Got to see plenty of antelopes and deer as well as some moose and elk. You really cannot spend too much time here.

Only had time to pass through Grand Teton to get to Yellowstone but couldn't wish for a lovelier route. The Moose Visitor Centre was worth a look too. Really well presented and great features. Great photo opportunities as the views are stunning.

The Tetons are very dramatic. We walked to cascade falls, which is a trail past Moose ponds at the side of the lake. Take bear spray just in case and if hiking in a small group talk loud round corners! Cascade falls was lovely, but beware of the altitude as we are fit but were exhausted when we got there. There is a boat you can catch to return, this was a fun way to get back and gave us a stunning view of the tetons.

We decided to go through Grand Teton National Park after spending several days exploring Yellowstone. Simply amazing, the beauty is not easily expressed. One noteworthy comment is about the time of year we went; this late in October everything is closed for the season. On the up side it was very quiet and have us a reason to spend the the in Jackson Hole, WY which we loved

Second time to Grand Teton National Park. We were here with our kids several years ago at the tail end of a trip to Yellowstone and were too exhausted to really appreciate the park. We gave ourselves a few more days this time to take our time and just love the place. The views are spectacular, the wildlife is amazing and the hikes are great. My husband prefers Grand Teton to Yellowstone and says it's a bit more accessible since it's not so big.

The Grand Tetons are unique ,majestic existing that give a feeling which cannot be really described,you just need to go and have this experience yourselfIf you are driving from Jackson Hole, enter the Park where you can get a close view from the Jackson Lake

The Grand Teton definitely lets you know you have arrived! The mountain towers over the Jackson Hole and is visible from many different locations, providing different views. I photographed in at Sunrise, Sunset with fiery orange skies, hiding peek a boo behind soft clouds sitting just atop it's face...much fun watching it's moods/looks change thruout the day(s).

The Teton National Park is absolutely worthwhile for travelling (maybe it might be overseen as it is by far smaller than the Yellowstone Park) - it has much more wildlife, an absolutely fantastic mountainous scenery and is great for hiking - also there are maybe less tourists, so that you can relaxe better than in Yellowstone.

I had been here once before when I was about 10 yrs old and was way more interested in fighting with my brother than the views. Now a few decades later, I was mesmerized by the Grand Tetons. Simply stunning views plus we came across a moose he was just beautiful. We are planning on coming back for a week in the future because there is so much to see and to do.

This park had been on our 'to do' list for many years. It did not disappoint. Absolutely beautiful place. The park is easy to navigate with park maps and the views are breathtaking at every turn. Love how the lighting and views change throughout the day. We were lucky to have "Indian Summer" weather with mountains having a light covering of snow - just lovely. Just be aware that after September many of the park amenities shut down in prep for the winter. Not a problem for getting around the park roads but not to many places open within the park.
Amazing scenery. Wish we could have stayed longer. Need at least a day here! Start at the gift shop to get great advice on where to go to see animals or the mountains.
