Thank goodness the fog had lifted. It was breathtaking to see the highest Mts. 12,000 plusAs we are used to the height we could feel our breathing taxed when walking.It was very beautiful to see.Down the bottom are trees and birds and at the top snow.We did not get to go up into these Mts. but if sure was cold where we were, needed hats and gloves for sure.
review_title: There was snow on the Mountain in October

review_body: As we approached the Grand Tetons from the west, the sun was setting, turning the Grand Tetons pink. Rising from the edge of the mountains was a huge Hunter's Moon. Words cannot describe the beauty of this place. Aspens turning gold, elk, moose, clear crystal waters, and hikes for all abilities. A must see in America!

The Grand Tetons NP is an amazing place. Many pull offs with over looks that give you a beautiful view of the mountains. Much much less crowded than Yellowstone and has lots of Elk, Moose and Pronghorn.
Beautiful mountain vista even on the overcast day. Wish we could have time to view this sight in the morning sunrise, snowfall or with a clear blue sky.

After visiting Yellowstone, this mountain range may seem just a “view“ from the car. But it is not only monumental, but has far less visitors and you can hike up to many secluded places in which you can see elk and other wildlife.

The Grand Teton National Park is simply spectacular. The Grand Tetons dominate the whole landscape. The range is not very high or huge but it is majestic. We were travelling through Yellowstone and at one point we were unsure we would glimpse the TETONS because the sky was dull and cloudy, then very suddenly the clouds cleared and the Tetons were revealed in their amazing glory.Worth a visit.

An amazing drive through this incredible range of mountain. We saw them snow covered and on a not that fine day but still amazing. There is plenty to do within the park too, or just drive through and pull over at the various view points.

The Tetons were spectacular. After seeing Yellowstone, I don't think the Tetons appeared quite as large as if you would have seen them first. There is glacial ice in the Tetons, which is cool. And the different angles of the mountains is awesome.We saw elk in the yard of a building near the visitors centers. The poor ranger couldn't keep people away who were trying to get pictures. The elk seemed content to allow photos and just kept grazing, but they are still "wild". They had to call in a volunteer to stand there and keep people across the drive.The prices at the gift shops were pretty reasonable, possibly due to it being October, not sure.We drove though Jackson but did not stop due to time frame. We were staying in West Yellowstone and was already going to be getting back late. It looked like a nice area. Will probably stop if we make it back to that area.
A trip to Yellowstone would not be complete without seeing this majestic range. Leave plenty of time for a leisurely drive.

Although there is a lot of hiking and boating available in the area that can keep a family busy for days, the Park can be visited if you have just one day to drive through it. It is much smaller than Yellowstone but has its own beauty and awe. We couldn't go in one area because it was closed due to bear sightings. We did see moose, antelope and elk. We even saw an eagle swoop down to get a fish! "Older" visitors can appreciate the many level walking trails and scenic spots for photo taking. We went in early September so traffic was sparse. There are visitor's centers at each park entrance and two within the Park. Get a map so you can plan your stops. Two lakes right on The Loop make it easy for visitors who want a water adventure. Each stop is worth investigating. Note: if you only have one day and are on your way "traveling through" to Yellowstone's south entrance, take the highway to Moose and then up to Jenny Lake, then to Colter Bay then north to Yellowstone. You could also take the 26 to Moran and then up to Colter Bay then north but you will miss some pretty country around the lakes areas.
If you are in town for Yellowstone, make sure to make time to drive through Grand Teton and explore. It is great.

Driving from Yellowstone to ID we spent the day driving through Grand Tetons. Drive was beautiful. There are lots of turnouts for picture taking. Many have information stands. One of the road we wanted to travel through (scenic) was closed due to lots of bear. Only negative is that it's all pit toliets which means stinky and no water to wash your hands. Some had the hand sanitizer but not all. So make sure you have some with you.

Lots of wildlife, including a momma Bear and 2 Cubs!!! Just an amazing place. Photo opts galore!! Was surprised the last week in September the number of people in the parks, way more than I thought for that time of year. Summer must be jam packed, no thank you. Love The Tetons!!!
review_title: 2nd visit ..... Would go there again!!! Wildlife and mountains
user_location: Big Pine Key, Florida, United States

review_body: No trapped zoo animals here! I loved being able to hear the bugling of the bull elk and watching the moose graze . Took the dinner cruise on Jackson Lake and was surprised by the scope of the food they served; steak and trout were the features. Bring your bikes because there are many places to ride them.

Take the boat ride across the lake to the falls and hiking trails. This will save you time and then if you feel up to hiking back you can or just hope back on the boats and ride back across the lake saving a few hours of walking around the lake to get to the falls. If the summer wear a bathing suit and jump off the rocks right up against the shore. Its a beautiful place to visit and explore.

Nothing to dislike it was so beautiful. We rented the Gaperguide for Grand Teton Park as well and could not have seen anything close to everything we saw if not for our Gaperguide. Went to Jackson Hole and rode the tram to the top of the mountain and had a great view and wonderful day
Breathe taking views, great hikes, beautiful lakes, saw moose, elk...outstanding time. If I had had more time, biking from town would have been well worth it.
Wow. We saw more animals here than at Yellow Stone. Beautiful mountains, beautiful lakes, I want to live here--only if I could.

With many pull-off areas along the road, we were able to get the most beautiful pictures and have wonderful memories of our trip through the Tetons. A definite place to get back to nature with the feeling of relaxation and serenity!

These were the most beautiful mountains I have ever seen and I will be back to see them again more closely. We just went by them stopped for a short visit to marvel at their beauty. I can only say that Mother Nature has done some of her best work here.

We had less than 2 days for exploring. We hiked part of the Jenny Lake Trail, hiked the Moose pond Trail. We had hoped to see moose, but did not. We saw deer, a porcupine and seemed to always find a bat. We had a wonderful time and have put the grand Tetons on our list of places to go back for further exploration.

Hedrick Pond Overlook---you won't find it on any of the maps but it is the best view in the entire park. We like it for sunrise but you have to be careful of the ruts/rocks in the road---early AM would be the best time for your first visit and if you go once you'll go back again. Go north on Hwy 89 and just after the Teton Point Overlook there is a gravel-dirt road marked Lost Creek Ranch Road---travel this road for 1.6 miles and turn left onto an unmarked dirt road (with some ruts and rocks)---bounce along for 1.1 miles and turn left onto a lesser road, bigger ruts and more rock,s but passable---go 0.5 miles and you'll see a port-a-potty and some picnic tables (the Dude ranches use this area for trail rides and chuck wagon dinners). A great photo op is from the ridge with the small Hedrick Pond in the lower right of your view finder, the Snake River in the mid-ground and the Tetons in the background.
review_title: Best view in Grand Teton---Hedrick Pond Overlook

review_body: This is our 3rd trip to Grand Teton, and it's starting to suffer from it's popularity as has happened to nearby Yellowstone. Getting more and more crowded, forcing wildlife and peace and quiet of an outdoor adventure further away. Afraid to think what this place might be like in another 10 years. Go now, while it's still somewhat peaceful.
review_title: Go ASAP... starting to get too crowded...

review_body: There was nothing I didn't like. The skyline is impressive. The moutain peaks just rise up from the lakes below no foothills. Breathtaking.
They don't call it the "GrandTetons" for no reason. These mountain ranges are huge and beautiful. A must see! Lots of wildlife in the park and jenny lake is also a must see as well.

Grand Teton park is a beautiful place to visit. There are lots of trails and hiking you can find depending upon your skills. Go to Jenny Lake to see a beautiful lake surrounded by snow capped mountains. Just absolutely stunning! Also, drive around to the chapels and the old store and have a huckleberry soda. There are restrooms located at these locations as well as trails you can walk. This park doesn't seem to be as decimated by the pine beetle as Yellowstone. I think it was a prettier park overall. Keep your eyes open for elk, deer and other critters!

This is a differtent park, pretty to look at on a drive thru but give it the attention you want and have time for and you will be thrilled. One has to interact with this park, walk into it, climb to inspiration point and you will be inspired, walk up Cascade Canyon, wald up to Phelps lake in the Laurance Rockefeller preserv and you will be hooked, want to see more trails, lakes, peaks and will miss it when you leave.
review_title: Give it your full attention and you will be rewarded.

review_body: We were coming from all day in Yellowstone and I must admit I was tired, And with the road construction it was becoming really difficult to keep up spirits by this point. As such We didn't really appreciate the Tetons. Im sure this is a special place and amazing in its own right, but for us. Yellowstone blew ALL our mind and we just were not that impressed here. Admittedly we tried to avoid construction on the scenic hwy and ran into construction on the main hwy. I would guess the scenic route even if yer tired and in a hurry would be the way to go.

Scenery abounds, and it seems less crowded than Yellowstone. Beautiful enough as a drive-by experience, but the food prices within the park are...more suited to the well-heeled. Bring your own lunch unless you want to pay more for a single light lunch than you would for three full dinners at home.
Smaller than Yellowstone, but well worth a few days here. So many camera shorts of the Tetons and the various wildlife. For the camera bug you should not miss this park
review_title: Great views no matter where you turn

review_body: We only had one day in the Grand Tetons but made the most of it - visited both Jackson and Jenny Lakes and got to see numerous views of the towering peaks. The new Craig Thomas Visitor Center near the south entrance is also definitely worth a stop. We were able to do some short hikes but would recommend at least two days if you want to explore more of the park on foot.

A beautiful, small (compared to Yellowstone) park that has much to see. The dirt roads around Mormon Row, the Jackson "Hole" area could also be called Jackson Cove or Jackson Valley. Surronded by mountains, it has buttes amid open pastures and reminds me of Cades Cove in Smokey Mountains NP, but on a much larger scale. It is cool to watch the jets come into the valley and land at the airport that is actually inside the NP. If you like skiing, you should stay in Teton Village. It has many lifts, gondolas etc coming right into the village. We were there in summer and enjoyed our stay in a condo there as well. It is a few minutes drive to Jackson.As far as Grand Teton NP it was right up there with Yellowstone and Rocky Mountain NPs for beauty and wildlife viewing. I hope to go back someday.
Great time of year for the Tetons! Not to crowded. Did not like some of the road construction in the area but worked around it!
Just love this place - always beautiful! Don't miss this drive thru the park. Up close and lovely. Also be sure to check out Rockefeller center, the gorgeous lakes and the many hiking trails.
and I don't use that term lightly. We were passing from Idaho to Yellowstone through the south entrance. What a beautiful landscape...takes your breath away.

Yet another beautiful location I was able to visit during my trip through the US. We arrived in the early morning hours when it was still chilly at Grand Teton NP. The cold disappeared around noon though when the sun came out and even created a rainbow as we took the ferry to cross the lake. Beautiful national park with amazing hikes and landscapes. I met some amazing people from Chicago whom I had a lovely chat with. Overall a fantastic day out!
review_title: Chilly in the morning and sunny at noon

review_body: Our experience traveling in Grand Teton National Park was that the rangers and visitor center personnel were extremely helpful and kept the visitor center open even at the end of the season past the official closing date. Also in contrast to Yellowstone and Glacier Parks the signage was clear and abundant making it easy to find our destinations. The park and rest rooms were clean and in good repairs.

Our driver/ tour guide Jefferey was great on this tour of the Grand Teton National Park area.His enthusiasm for & love of the history of the area was evident.We saw many of the animals, birds & plants native to the area and Jefferey seemed to know about all of them.He is a natural storyteller and very entertaining guide- Thanks! Jefferey for an exceptional tour!

This park contains some of the most stunning scenery in the world (I have visited over 70 countries). My home is in Scotland and it is definitely worth the cost of trans-Atlantic travel. I was first here in winter of 1990 and returned in early autumn/fall of 2014. The colours were incredible and probably get even better later in September and early October. This area should be on everyone's 'bucket list'!
review_title: There aren't enough superlatives to describe it.

review_body: This tour was truly awe-inspiring and our tour guide Jeffrey was great! He took us to all really beautiful places to see and was very informative and knowledgeable about the Park and the wildlife and history of this area. We'd taken Yellowstone tour day before & thought it was pretty fabulous but the Grand Teton tour with Jeffrey was even better! Definitely recommend!
review_title: AllTrans/Grayline tour of Grand Teton National Park

review_body: When we came out of the tiny Jackson Hole Airport, little did we know, we were already in the Tetons.. The airport is surrounded by this mountain range... from that time, till I entered our hotel room in Jackson Hole, I could not take my eyes away from the Tetons.I believe the most scenic way to enter the Yellowstone National Park, is through the Tetons in WY and both the parks are BEAUTIFUL in its own rights... If you have make efforts to see YSNP- you should absolutely spend sometime in the Tetons on the way.
review_title: Th majestic mountains called the Grand Tetons

review_body: We hiked around the different areas and there was not a view that did not take your breath away. Every turn had another breathtaking view. So thankful for God's amazing artistry!!! I liked Yellowstone, but I think I enjoyed the Tetons even more.
The Tetons always take my breath away. They are simply magnificent. If you've never been - go. You won't be disappointed.

We were fortunate enough to be able to drive around Grand Teton area for several days. This was so relaxing and so beautiful. If you are going to Yellowstone, don't make a mistake and pass up the Grand Teton area.

Take the ski lift ride up to the top of the mountain at Targhee for one of the nicest views of the Grand Tetons. Afraid of heights? It doesn't seem that high on the lift. There are moments at the top, however.
The whole of the Grand Teton Mountain range is really a spectacular sight to be seen by all.The views from the cable car is equally impressive.
The views of the Grand Teton and surrounding areas are exceptional!! Can't wait to go back and spend more time in this area!
The mountains spring up form a lake setting with no preamble, no foothills, and no apologies. Unspeakably gorgeous
review_title: No mountains like this in the world

review_body: Stopped at a lake and a small church on our bus tour as we drove through this area. The mountains were a little shrouded by clouds the morning we drove through, but it was still a beautiful view, and the lake we stopped at was as beautiful with the mountains, rocks, clouds and rays of sun as Lake Tahoe.

GTNP is one of my favorites. The view of the mountains with the lakes or the Snake River in front is outstanding. We took the boat across Jenny Lake and hiked up to Hidden Falls. This was well worth the journey for the wonderful views. We began our visit in the Chapel of Transfiguration. This provided a wonderful way to start the day in prayer with a view of the mountains and the organ being played. The view from Jackson Lake Lodge is also nice as it overlooks Willow Flats. I would recommend driving all the roads and pullouts in the area. We took the road to the top of Signal Mt. for awesome views of the valley below. This park provides a peaceful retreat. One can bike or hike or just sit and enjoy the beauty. Don't miss a scenic float on the Snake River.
Absolutely stunning!!! I would love to go back one day. Beautiful breathtaking scenery. Would love to go back one day.

Wonderful area to explore. Jenny Lake Ranger tour was great. Climb to observation point are then hike further on your own. Be sure to bring bear spray just in case. Views in these mountains are breathtaking.

It’s great to see that this area was also made into a Park, it is different from Yellowstone, Beside the Mountain range, there is more possibility to do outdoor activities for the none hardcore outdoor people. You can hike and bike for miles, there are enough flat plains to cycle and hike.We stayed in Colter Bay Cabins, and got up at sunrise and stopped at the turnout after the Oxbow Bend Turnout, to get the Red glow shining on the mountains, it was great. The fog was lifting from the lake and slowly rising, and the Sun was burning it off. After sunrise we went back and had breakfast at the restaurant, before we continued our journey.Make sure you bring your camera with a panorama possibility or able to stitch pictures together so that you can capture the whole mountain range, because you do not want to lose that memory.

Grand Teton National Park may be like a smaller sibling of Yellowstone National Park with regards to area size. What the park lacks in area size, it makes up for the ruggedness, height and majestic view!I came here with my siblings. We hiked Hidden Falls, Inspiration Point annd Cascade Canyon. Those were 3-4 hour hike that was compensated by the breathtaking views! Sunrise and sunset here are to die for! Make sure you bring your camera! My top 3 favorite photo spots are: Oxbow Bend, Mormon Row and Snake River overlook. If you love to bike, this is one of the best places to do it! Maybe you'll be lucky enough spot a moose and a pronghorn, the fastest animal over long distances!

We stayed here during our Rocky Mountains road trip, unfortunately only 2 days, would loved to stay 1 or 2 more days, as the Tetons were pretty in clouds the first day. Did early (and I mean early!!) sunrise photos and Oxbow Bend, Jackson Hole (which is a super must see and nice small city), Jenny Lake, Mormon Row, I guess these are all the must do's there, Schwabacher, again early morning for sunrise photos, and many Bison crossing the street at Mormon Row, that was an experience. I would plan at least 2-3 full days next time.

The visit to this National Park was part of a National Parks Wonders Tour. The Grand Teton Mountains are very majestic and beautiful. I recommend taking the float trip on the Snake River to really get a close up view. It is a beautiful preserve of nature including plant and wildlife.
Good views and peaceful but cannot beat Yellowstone! Glacier can be seen and quite a lot of wildlife. Seemed to have good cycle routes, although we drove.
The mountain and lake views, trails, picnic spots, and wildlife viewing are spectacular. The route is well marked with turnouts and interesting places to see.Take your time on the dirt road section.

If you just see the Teton's from the highway like we did it is worth it. We y drove from Evanston, WY and bypassed SLC traffic. Our destination was Yellowstone so we did not stay in this area long but so glad I got to see these majestic peaks.
review_title: What an eruption it must have been.

review_body: Traveled to Yellowstone and Grand Teton National Park in August. Grand Teton was absolutely amazing. Took a float trip and horseback ride with great guides. So much to see and do. Stayed in Jackson, which is a little touristy but still a great little town.
The Tetons are majestic mountains easy to view from the scenic hwy. Stop at Teton Village and take the Jackson Hole Tram for the full experience.

At first glance, the Teton range are so spectacular you think that they can't be real. They command a presence. The hiking is incredible for all skill levels. Get a lake front cabin. The tranquility is unmatched.
review_title: You can't take your eyes off the Teton range.

review_body: The Tetons are some of the most majestic mountains I've seen (including Switzerland and Glacier National Park). The hikes around Jenny Lake and up to Hidden Falls are not to be missed. Very nice facilities as well.

One of my favourite places in the America. In hindsight I would have spent less time in Yellowstone and more in GTNP to be honest. We just loved the place and the ability to explore which you don't really get in Yellowstone. Their is moose, bison, bear and great hikes to summit lakes and with the awesome backdrop of the Tetons. Gros Ventre is the place to see moose - don't listen to anything else.

We traveled from the south gate of Yellowstone through to the Tetons, then took the "scenic route". I do not know how the other route could have been less scenic; it is miles and miles of rugged snow-capped mountains beyond scenic lakes. You almost cannot take it in.

We combined a trip to Grand Teton along with our Yellowstone trip. We had three days to cover the Teton and that was more than sufficient time. There are many beautiful overlooks with great views and easy hikes. Do visit the Jenny lake and hike upto Inspiration point.The view from the top is BreathtakingMoreover, Jackson hole is only 30 min away in case you get hungry!

This Park is just awesomely beautiful! My husband and I thoroughly enjoyed touring the Park while we stayed in Jackson, WY. The views are breathtaking, and the opportunity to see Wildlife is great! We would highly recommend Grand Teton National Park to others.

A lot of reviewers have covered most of the things that you can do in Grand Teton, so I'll avoid too many specifics. It's an absolutely beautiful place and you'll be left in awe. In my opinion, if you're planning a trip; make it slightly longer and also include Yellowstone in the itinerary. It's very close and definitely adds to the trip.My personal experience has been that, Yellowstone, given it is more famous, is well laid out for the more touristy stuff. Both in terms of the facilities and trails. Grand Teton is a bit more rough and it's a good thing. You get to mix the well laid out of Yellowstone with the bit more natural Grand Teton. I spent 5 days in the region and can say that a 4-5 day trip is a minimum if you really want to spend quality time here.

A place I have always heard of and read about, but the experience was far beyond our expectations. We spent a day and a half there, arriving on Labor Day and the crowds were already starting to thin our (or they were all in Jackson, which was bumper to bumper) We spent the day exploring the area and took photos that look like the ones that come with the picture frame. We say deer, antelope, a hears of elk and even stumbled on a large herd of buffalo. Every bend in the road offered another spectacular view. This is a must visit if you like wildlife and scenery.
There are many beautiful overlooks and easy hikes with great views. You can spend a lot of money here and in Jackson Hole but you do not have to.

Grand Teton National Park can be crowded, but is still worth a visit. The many lakes are beautiful, and the large variety of hiking trails are great places to explore. The visitor's centers are very informative. Take at least a full day and just drive around and explore the area. There are many pullouts along the way with fantastic views of the Tetons.

We were actually pleasantly surprised to see how beautiful the Grand Tetons were. We didn't know what to expect. We drove through Jackson Hole, WY, on our way to Yellowstone National Park. We were very happy to see our travels would take us right through Grand Teton National Park. The views were spectacular. The Jackson Hole Airport was but a mere spec against the landscape of the Grand Tetons. Digital cameras are the best. How many pictures can you take of a mountain range, really? Don't ask..... Safe travels to you all!

Bring your bicycle; miles and miles of paved, scenic bicycle trails along the river, by the lakes and through the woods. Great food and shopping in Jackson; friendly customer service everywhere we went. However, after about 10 a.m every morning, Jackson gets very busy with lots of folks exhibiting their cultural habits -- loud talking and laughing and crowding out other people. Some groups were made up of 8-10 people; you were kinda forced to get out of their way. Be careful when shopping. If you think an item is overpriced, it probably is. We found some souvenir shirts priced 30-40% lower than the identical shirts in a store directly across the street. -- The sights and beauty all along the Tetons and the lakes is unmatched anywhere we have traveled in this country in the last 30 years. Don't miss it!
review_title: We want to return; super magnificent

review_body: We love this National Park and visit every year for a week. I love the rock and mountain climbing, but the hiking is great too. You can avoid crowds if you know where to go or start early in the morning. The park is busiest from 4th of July until Labor Day, but you can go anytime. The ski resort is popular in the winter and the town of Jackson is busiest in the summer. Get away from the traffic and tourists that just drive around and see the wild areas that are unknown with a little research. We never even go up to Yellowstone, but I'm glad everyone else does. Be prepared for chilly mornings, even in July! I love this place and our girls can't get enough.
review_title: My favorite National Park and awesome climbing!

review_body: I drove through Grand Teton after leaving Yellowstone on my way west. Enjoyed some lovely views as the sun was setting!
Great scenery! We had great photo opportunities. There are fun hikes to enjoy throughout the park and opportunities to see Elk, Moose and even bear.
There is mosquito. Have your bug off ready. Boat on the lake is very good for family with kids, keep you map with you since it is easy to get lost on water.
review_title: Boating at the lake is good here

review_body: The view if this range of mountains is majestic! When just drove through them because of the cold and rain. I've seen them when the weather was beautiful. Indescribable when you can spend time in the park.
We took a nice walk directly from Jenny Lake Lodge along a stream to Jenny Lake. Easy with kids. The weather was much colder than anticipated so we don't stray very far.
liked everything... disliked nothing This is a truly amazing and awesome place for anyone who has the good fortune to visit the Grand Tetons You won't be disappointed. It's a very special place!

Spent 2 days driving and stopping off various places in the Grand Tetons. Mountain range is so beautiful during the day and when the sun is going down it is a totally new look. We stayed at Jackson Lake Lodge over looking this wonderful natural sight. It makes you stop take a deep breath and be gratuitous that I was able to have this wonderful experience. Very relaxing and such a great place to unwind from our hectic lives.

If you want to see the Tetons and have a great meal, please consider the Breakfast Cruise. Started out by seeing a young grizzly along the shore. The boat ride was beautiful with good narration. the breakfast on the island was the best meal of our trip and that is saying something. Viewing the sunrise while enjoying a fantastic breakfast from a picnic table was the top memory of the Teton/Yellowstone trip.

This was a little spend..28.00 per person to go up 10540 ft to top of mountain but it was an amazing sight. Takes 12 minutes to get up there and there is a small coffee shop and potties. It was cool to see the paragliders take off from the top and go to bottom. Tram runs every 15 minutes and you can come back down any time.

I thought I was from the mountains coming from Western NC, but the Grand Tetons are MOUNTAINS. We saw a mother and calf moose grazing in the field behind them snow capped mountains. It made for an amazing experience.

We recently visited the Grand Teton National Park in conjunction with a trip to Yellowstone. We thought the mountain rangers were spectacular as was the wildlife. Also less crowded. We visited July 28-29 2014

There's a reason they are called the Grand Tetons. If you find yourself travelling to Yellowstone National Park (a must do trip) carve out a day or two to see the Grand Tetons. We traveled north from Park City Utah to Jackson Hole WY and into the Grand Tetons. It was amazing to experience the famous calendar photos of the Grand Tetons and Jenny Lake in real life! From Pink and Purple sunsets over the granite peaks to quiet reflections in Jenny and Jackson Lakes, every breath and every sight is one you will want to hold onto forever. I recommend a raft trip down the snake river for wildlife viewing along the base of the Grand Tetons. We saw several eagles and a baby moose. Also, wildlife crossed our paths several times while hiking. The waterfalls are phenomenal and the wildflowers are everywhere. This place is like waking up into a dream! We stayed two nights at colter bay cabins, which was nice and rustic. I would like to try to stay at Signal Mountain Lodge next time (and there will definitely be a next time) as there were many restaurant options, the view was beyond breathtaking from the facility. You just can't go wrong here. If you would like to experience some serenity and be in awe of nature, do not miss the Grand Tetons!!
review_title: Grand Tetons are not to be missed

review_body: We really enjoyed our time in the Great Tetons. Wonderful hiking and beautiful views. Easier to maneuver than Yellowstone, although not as unique. Great places to stay--Jenny Lake, Teton Village, and Jackson

Everyone should see the Grand Tetons at least once. But if you come once you will have to come again. We were planning a trip to Yellowstone and kept seeing reviews that said DON'T MISS THE TETONS! So we added it to our trip and we are so glad we did! In general, it is much pricier to stay in the Tetons than in Yellowstone but it worth at least a day trip. There is abundant hiking, kayaking, horseback riding, relaxation and site seeing to suit just about anyone.

Not quite as picturesque as Yellowstone but you can't help but marvel at the size of the mountains. Would love to see both parks in the winter when they're snow covered. I'm sure the Tetons are spectacular!

While this park is excellent in scenery and most everything else, I highly recommend not entering on the road from Teton village. With no warning from the ranger on duty, about a mile from the entrance the road turned into a rutted pot-holed mess. I would have second thoughts about driving my Jeep more than 5 mph on this road, and I was in a low slung Chrysler. I don't know how far these conditions lasted because I turned around after 1/4 mile.
review_title: WARNING!! Do not enter on the Moose/Wilson road

review_body: Spectacular peaks form the background for beautiful lakes, forests and the Snake River, My wife and I enjoyed walking the trails along Jackson Lake, Leigh Lake, Jenny Lake and String Lake, The most beautiful, in my opinion, of the Rocky Mountain Ranges in the lower 48 along with the ranges of the Rocky Mountain's San Juan's in Southwestern Colorado.
The mountains are spectatular, the hiking is incredible, the wildlife is abundant and it is a wonderful place to visit.The title of this review says it all!
review_title: One of our favorite National Parks

review_body: Family vacation in July with 2 grown kids, 21 & 24 to Jackson Hole, Grand Tetons & Yellowstone. The Grand Tetons were magnificent! I had to keep pinching myself to make sure I was awake. The scenery is spectacular! We stayed at the Jackson Lake Lodge, which was very convenient and rustic, yet comfortable. The room had two Queen beds which was perfect. There is no TVs, no a/c and not much of an internet connection. So plan on playing family games or go to bed early. A couple of highlights for us: We took the ferry across Jenny Lake and hiked to Inspiration Point. The hike is not too difficult, but it wasn't super easy either. The view at the end was worth it. Along the way there is a nice waterfall and we saw a yellow bellied marmot for the first time.We also did the 10 mile scenic float down the Snake River which included a very nice picnic! Hamburgers, coleslaw, fruit salad, cookies, and drinks. If you are looking for a little relaxation, take the scenic float and bring your camera! We saw many eagles and other birds, but no moose on this trip. We didn't care, we enjoyed the ride with Matt and Pat our raft guides. I would recommend spending at least 2 days in Grand Tetons as there is plenty of things to do.

This was our initial visit, and I'm now saying it was our introductory visit. It's such a beautiful location and needs several days to even start to appreciate all it has to offer. If you're looking for photographic locations you'll be spoiled for choice, almost every corner exposes something worthy of a new photo.

We went on a Photo Safari at Yellowstone and the professional photographer Don gave us a list of all the places to take a photo in the Tetons NP and how to get there. He was spot on. The shots were absolutely breathtaking.

Spectacular views of the mountains. Jenny Lake area has lots to offer for hiking and views (try Inspiration Point). Many areas to get off the main road. If you like rustic lodging, check out Jackson Lake Lodge.
Spectacular scenery, lots of animals to be seen, and plenty of activities for all levels of fitness.

The sights and photo-ops are simply endless in this park as the scenery is truly breathtaking. Over a series of days there was an opportunity to visit different parts of the park from the Snake River Basin to open prairies off the road as well as Jackson and Jenny lake to view different panorama of the Grand Tetons range as well as wildlife. Wildlife, including a grizzly bear, was abundant and best seen earlier in the day prior to 10am or mid-to-late afternoon. From a personal perspective to see the entire park and do a reasonable amount of hiking one could need anywhere from 2-3 days - in our case two days were sufficient. Each day began at/around 4:30am/5am to take sunrise and morning photographs and lasted until the late afternoon. In one case a grizzly bear was seen approximately 50-60 feet from the road as well as Elk, deer, pronghorn and other wildlife. One of the more amazing aspects related to the park is how accustomed the wildlife has become in seeing humans and consequently do not automatically run once being seen.Overall a wonderful and memory-filled experience that will never be forgotten.

We loved the Grand Tetons, they're definitely worth seeing. We saw them from the Snake River as well as taking the tram from Teton Village to the top. We enjoyed waffles up on top and witnessed paragliders jumping off the mountain. It was a great trip and I highly recommend it, if you're in the Yellowstone area

Visit the Tetons even if it's the last thing you do in life. I love this park, I can't tell you how many times I've visited the Tetons. I can tell you that there is always something new that I see or experience when I'm there. I only wish I could visit it everyday.
review_title: You have to see this park

review_body: We thoroughly enjoyed this beautiful national park while on our trip out west this past July. The Teton mountain range is simply breathtaking and even pictures don't do it justice. We stayed in Jackson for three nights, and spent two full days driving through the park. One of the major highlights of this park is taking the boat across Jenny Lake. It costs $30.00 for two adults for a round trip across the lake. After the boat docked, we hiked to Hidden Falls and Inspiration Point and the views were awesome. We were told you could also take a one-way trip across the lake and then hike about 2 and one half miles back to the visitor center. We had a couple of really good lunches at Signal Lodge while in the park. i would also recommend visiting the Chapel of the Transfiguration and joining the ranger for an informative session about the history of the park. We were told the best chances for seeing wildlife was either at Oxbow Bend or at Antelope flats, where we did see bison. Of course, the best chance to see animals is either early morning or toward dusk. If you are planning on visiting Yellowstone, make sure you allow yourself enough time to visit the beautiful Tetons as well.

One of the most beautiful places we have ever been in the United States. And you "own" it, which is even better since it's a national park. Spend time just taking in the vistas and not talking. The views more than speak for themselves

People mostly hear and talk about Yellowstone, which is a truly beautiful and stunning park, don't get me wrong, but The Grand Tetons is a simply breathtaking park. My husband and I drive from the North entrance to the South and at every twist and turn, there was another stop or site that literally took our breath away. I highly recommend going to this park. It would be silly to not stop in if you're going to Yellowstone.
review_title: Stunning park that doesn't get enough credit

review_body: We loved it, but it was not much different from our Alps that we have them in Europe,... But we have seen some wild life there and the ranger program for the kids is excellent

This is my favorite park by far, but I'm a wildlife photographer and this place has the 'goods' in spades. There is roughly one grizzly bear for every 500 acres of this park. You can easily see moose, elk, deer and a variety of birds as you traverse this park by car or on foot. Grizzly are plentiful in this park and it behooves you to talk with the local Forest Ranger at the Visitor's center at the Moos Entrance (about 10 miles north of Jackson Hole, Wyoming on route 26). If going in June, be bear aware and don't get around huge willow stands as they are hunting in them for newly born elk calves. Get bear smart by talking to your forest ranger folks.I always go early June before the real tourist glut occurs. A lot less people, you can drive easily around the entire park. There's something for everyone. Easy trails, tough trails, places to eat from down home cooking food to the Jenny Lake restaurant that is upscale (don't come in with your hiking clothes on--you'll be turned away like we were).Jackson Lake Lodge is a fabulous landing pad in the park and I highly recommend it. We like the diner cafe in the lodge. They also have an upscale eatery there. June is the month to see grizzly bear, moose and elk down below the sundeck area of this lodge. Be there with your camera....you'll get nice shots.
review_title: Grand Tetons National Park a Hidden Jewel

review_body: If you are in the Yellowstone area you really NEED to take the drive south to see these great mountains. Many nice pull outs to take photo's and even better if you have time to take a boat tour along them.

A book I 've been reading by C. J. Box, called the Gran Tetons the super model of the western mountains! They are so beautiful! A great short hike is the Hidden Falls off of Jenny Lake. You can also hike around Jenny Lake which will give you several different views of the mountains.
The same problem like Yellowstone! No showers at the campsides for people in tents! The places you get for a tent are great!

I was impressed with Yellowstone until we drove south and saw the Grand Tetons. This is one of God's most impressive creations. Be sure to stop at the south entrance at the little village there, you will see an old general store, old ferry crossing and the most magnificent church with the Grand Tetons as the backdrop. Please see the attached pictures.

I adore the Grand Tetons- having first visited 26 yrs ago. On this second trip- so little had changed which was amazing. The Park has everything you could possible want if you love space and nature. Mountains, lakes, rivers, birds, incredible mammals to find, horse riding, boating, sunsets to die for, great locations to stay, and excellent roads to travel on. It is SO well managed, excellent visitors centres and it's a photographers dream landscape. Plus its next to Yellowstone. Even in the summer high months- its not too busy- compared to European roads! Best to book early before you go if you want to stay in the immediate are if the park as it is so popular. Cannot wait to return some day.
review_title: It has my heart and soul

review_body: We had been 3 days in Yellowstone and chose to "only" do a cookout near String Lake. Our kids took a dip in the lake while lunch was being prepared. I found it so spectacular that I took my camera in with me to photograph them against the backdrop.

We drove down through the Tetons on our way from Yellowstone to Jackson. We did not allow enough time to really stop and take it all in. The river and mountains views are breathe taking. Would love to have spent more time here. either way such a beautiful scenic drive if you have the chance.

Especially liked the hike/view up to Hidden Falls and Inspiration Point, about 2 miles around the lake plus about a 1 mile hike up. Coming back to the Visitor's Center you can either hike all the way back or hike down the trail and take a ferry across the lake. (Of course you can take the ferry over in the first place if you don't want to hike around the lake.)

The most beautiful place I've hiked so far, especially since I went during the fall. The air was brisk, and was the first time I ever smelled the smokey mountain air... And I was in heaven. The trees were yellow and there was so much color it was just so beautiful I can't wait to go back.
review_title: Went in Sept 2011 most beautiful time ever

review_body: As you drive south from Yellowstone Park, there is lots of things to see. Your attention is drawn in many directions.Then, you round a curve and you see the Grand Tetons over Lake Louise and you will be lucky you don't run off the road while you stare (I almost did).See the magnificent mountains from the lodge. See where Ansel Adams took his iconic picture of the Snake River valley. See the abandoned ranch that is in the foreground of so many famous pictures of the mountains. Stay at the lodge, if you can and listen to the coyotes at night. See the moose at various spots around the lodge.Check at the square at Jackson with the Elk antler arches and the raised wooden sidewalks.You won't be sorry if you get there - you will be sorry if you miss it.

My husband and I spent 4 days in the Jackson area and this was by far the best part. This park is beautiful, clean, and packed full of wildlife. The hiking is unbelievable (bring your bear spray)! It is not as busy as the yellowstone area and we so enjoyed the laid back and quiet atmosphere.

We are quite spoiled as we are close to Banff National Park in Canada. As a result many of our mountain touring (here, Glacier, Tahoe, Etc) is often compared to Banff. Well the Tetons did well. The distance of the highway from the mountains, along with great pull outs, provide for wonderful viewing opportunities. Morman row is a definite stop. The old buildings with the Teton background is beautiful. Plus Bison are often nearby for a photo too. Recommend get up early and get out before sun gets too high. Saw plenty of smaller wildlife and the scenery is majestic. Water so calm the mountain reflections were priceless.
All about it. Make sure you have plenty of battery for cameras. Early morning has much better light, as you will view the peaks from east to west.
review_title: Must sit & take in the sight!

review_body: Views were sensational and wildlife abound. We took a scenic boat ride on the lake the first day and this gave us a good idea of what was nearby.

We travelled south from Yellowstone National Park down into the Grand Teton National Park, with many great places to stop and admire the wonderful views. The mountain with the snow and glaciers were fantastic, as were the plants. The lakes were superb, as were the variety of wildlife, including wolf, snow fox, moose and bear.A great place to come and relax after all the wonderful features in Yellowstone National Park.A return visit and still as special

Nothing this place is from another time. Went here with family and friends and don't think I can put into words how incredible this place truly is.I live in Florida so I know something about beautiful beaches and wild life.This place knocked my socks off. Please if you do nothing more in this life get out there and see them.

We visited the Grand Teton National Park, hoping to see some bears. But even a picnic did not attract the animals. As alternative, we walked the track around the lake and were surprised by the waterfall at the end. Beautiful flora!

We have visited a good number of National Parks and enjoyed this one as much as any of them. The reason it is so high on our list is because it has all the beauty of any park with similar wildlife, but is far less crowded. As you travel single file through the other parks it can feel like assembly line vacation. Here the roads are not busy and you can stop or travel at your own speed. There is a place called Mormon row about 20 miles northeast of Jackson that has provided many calendar pictures. I almost hesitated to leave this review because I want to go back and find it just like it was last year. Our method of travel is in a 5th wheel and we might not have felt the same about this area if we were in a motel.
review_title: An excellent place to spend a few days

review_body: Have traveled to The Tetons for several years and the past 2 years we stayed at the Libby Creek Campground on the northern edge of the park. About 35 miles from Jackson to the north, but well worth the scenery. This national park is a spectacular visit during any season, but we prefer late summer/early fall as the crowds have thinned out and the wildlife is starting to come around more. There are many wonderful hikes around Jackson Lake and Jenny lake to the south. Day trips are abundant and with our location, we are only 25 min from Yellowstone Ntl. Park for another great day trip.

Go to Jenny Lake take the boat across to hike to the waterfall and view of the Grand Tetons! There are bike trails from Jackson if you like to bike. The store has a lot of National Park souvenirs and camping as well as outdoor equipment.
review_title: Short hike and a boat ride to a fabulous view

review_body: These mountains are some of the youngest in North America. They pop up from relatively flat plains and pure crystal clear lakes, straight up into the sky. Twilight over Jackson Lake was out of this world. As the minutes passed everything began slowly turning the same color of a soft, periwinkle blue. A crescent moon rose over the mountains and the lake was so still you could see its reflection perfectly in the water. We stayed in the tent-only section of Coulter Bay campground. There was plenty of privacy and shade. I will most definitely be staying there again. We got up at 4:30 for the sunrise over Oxbow Bend and spent sunset down at Schwabacher's Landing. Saw pelicans, beavers, moose. It was spectacular.

What a gorgeous park. How can I give one review?! The entire park is gorgeous, but the most well known and recognizable mountains are the Tetons. Actually named by a french explorer I believe, because they reminded him of breasts, large breasts, Grande Teton. Random history, but fun anyways. Go to Yellowstone, stay a week, take everything in you can.

To us this is the number one National Park...the views are break taking, Jackson is much more than a tourist trap, there a many things to do vs most National Parks. We took a balloon ride, paraglided off the top of the mountain, and did a scenic Snake River raft...we were there for 3 days and barely scratched the surface of things to do. We have been to the Swiss Alps and they have nothing on the Tetons. Jackson Lake Lodge has the best view in the valley (just on AC) and the staff of college students from around the country are bubbly and eager to serve/please. I recommend this park/valley as your top pick.

Everyone needs to see this park. It is so beautiful just to drive by. Wish we had allowed more time on our trip to spend time hiking and exploring. You need more than a few hours to fully enjoy this beauty!

We had a great time at Grand Teton National Park - we took a private sunset tour and would highly recommend this option if you can. Our tour guide was able to take us to see black bear, moose, mule deer and beaver. We also saw some elk. We would have never found these hotspots without our guide. The terrain and animals are amazing and beautiful. Truly is a national treasure.
One of the most beautiful parks to visit! Those mountains are simply breathtaking. Looked like a painting. Put it on your bucket list for sure!!!

Can't beat it. Pure nature and civilization combine to make this one of the best places on earth. Jackson is a great city with anything one would need. Prices are high though what you'd expect from a seasonal town.
Wow! Beautiful view at every turn in the road. Beautiful lake and waterfall. So glad that it was saved from development and became a national park. Some people were very farsighted!
The way to go to or leave from Yellowstone is through Jackson Hole and The Grand Tetons. Stop at Signal Mountain Lodge for a snack and a view of Jackson Lake and The Tetons

Spent a day out of our trip to Yellowstone in the Grand Tetons. Enjoyed a scenic float trip down the Snake River and hear many interesting facts from our excellent guide. My wife is an amateur photographer and she got plenty of shots of bald eagles, osprey, and ducks. Looked like there were fantastic bike trails and hiking trails in the park although we did not get to use them.

Incredible and awesome place to visit! The behemoth mountain ranges are sight to see with some of still sporting snow caps. Inspired by this I yearn to go back to my homeland,India, to confront the mighty Himalayas which I have not seen. Teton Lake was a brilliant sight.the expanse of it was breath-taking being interspersed with many Rapids. Exited thru Jackson Hole, Wyoming.
Road our motorcylces threw the trails great views went on boat at dock great cant wait to go back again in the coming yrs

Wow!!!! The views are unreal..Just like I have always seen in books and on the net. I caught myself taking pics every few minutes. .We came thru Yellowstone which is also excellent. But I cant wait to come back here again. Thanks Wyoming.
The tetons are very majestic. There is a nice visitors center/museum and gift shop we enjoyed . Loved the lake with mountains behind.

I really didn't appreciate the word "majestic" until I saw the Grand Teton mountain range. Photos only being to suggest what it is like to be there. Views from everywhere in the park are amazing. Hiking is fabulous, and the many lodges offer great food and beautiful accommodations (but fill up very quickly). It's expensive relative to many places, especially in Jackson, WY, but absolutely gorgeous. The park is also relatively small (at least compared with Yellowstone) so you can see a lot of it in one day. But I recommend staying longer than that if you can.The only downsides are bears (we didn't see any, but they recommend not leaving anything food or water or scent-related in your car overnight, which is a pain), and bugs. Definitely need good bug spray.
review_title: Even more majestic than the photos suggest

review_body: Prettiest Mountain Range in the United States. Great Trails and services. National Park signs not as good or roads as well marked as other NPs.
Saw tons of Bison....and the roads were in excellent shape. Even if you are unable to walk the trails, the driving trails allow you to see a lot of beauty of the park.

Less crowdy than Yellowstone, which is in itself very nice when you comme from Yellostone park in July.You can rent canoe or kayak at Colter Bay, we enjoyed! The view of the mountains on the lake is fantastic. It is not possible to rent that in Yellowstone, although you can do a guided "tour" with OARS at Grant Village. We haven't done it, but you have to reserve in advanced for these tours in Yellowstone.
review_title: Nice views and rent a canoe !

review_body: The centerpiece of this national park is the Grand Teton, a 4197 m horn that rises abruptly from the plains. No mountaineer can resist its appeal. There are dozens of routes, and each climber will sort her/his approach to the mountain. Unlike many ranges in the US, the Tetons have guiding services that are organized along lines that will be familiar to Europeans. Exum Mountain Guides has a concession with the NP that allows them to guide, and to keep a hut (really, a glorified tent) in the Lower Saddle, from which they escort dozens of aspiring climbers to the summit of the Grand via the trade route every day in summer. That is no different from the herding of novices up the Mont Blanc or the Matterhorn by the Chamonix and Zermatt guides' cooperatives, respectively. For those with more experience, time and money, Exum will provide private guiding at low (i.e., 1:1) guide:climber ratio, on routes of any difficulty. For a climb of the complete Exum (one of the infamous 50 classic climbs of North America), they asked for a climbing CV, one day of private cragging (on Guide's Wall in Cascade Canyon, a 6 pitch route at 5.9 max) to evaluate competence, a day to approach the Lower Saddle, and a day to summit and get out to the trailhead. Logistics were well organized, and the guides were as competent as I have seen anywhere in the world. Also, unlike many guide operations in Europe, Exum is eager to guide technical rock climbs in which each and every pitch is belayed (e.g. Irene's Arete). I strongly recommend this highly professional operation.
review_title: Summit Grand Teton with Exum Mountain Guides

review_body: Grand Teton National Park is beautiful. Once you come here, you will understand how a place can stay in your heart and mind forever. Every time I see this range of mountains they awe me - just like the first time. I never tire of coming here. The line of peaks are something to behold as is the whole river valley. The combination of rivers, lakes, meadows and trails in this park make for endless opportunities for adventure, fun and photo opportunities. It can get crowded in certain parts of the park during summer, but the park is so big, there are always places you can go for solitude. I shall return again.
Jaw dropping views. Without question the most beautiful of the 8 National Parks we have visited. Although there is more wild life viewing in Yellowstone, the Tetons cannot be missed.

The Tetons are filled with hiking opportunities. We barely scratched the surface over a three day stay. The views of the Tetons themselves are amazing and take on different life with different lighting. You can hit the same place twice and swore you've never seen anything like it the second time around. The crowds around Jenny Lake Visitor center spoil that area, but there are many more isolated and less crowded options nearby. Keep in mind the heat can be intense in the summer and you'll need bug spray for just about any and every activity - even sleeping :)

I cannot say enough about this place. We stopped here on the way to Yellowstone for two days. I cannot describe how beautiful this entire area was. We saw a male moose maybe 20 feet away, we watched a 100 member bison herd cross the road right in front of our car, we saw probably 20 different types of wildflowers and many other animals. I live in Colorado and the Tetons themselves are some of the most gorgeous mountains I have ever seen. I love this place and am already missing it a week after I left.
review_title: One of the most beautiful places on Earth- outdoor lover's paradise

review_body: 29-years ago while working in Yellowstone, I climbed the Middle Teton. I made it my goal to climb The Grand Teton someday. I have been to the park many times since then and even climbed the Middle Teton one more time. I came within 700 feet of the summit of the Grand two years ago, but alas it wasn't my time….UNTIL July 27, 2014 when I summited the Grand. It is as gorgeous looking down as it is looking up. At sunset the shadow of the Tetons rises up over the valley. I don't remember seeing this before. An amazing sight you can only see from high above. This park and these mountains are among the World's finest!
review_title: 29-year goal…and I finally stood on top of the GRAND!

review_body: You have never seen anything so majestic & inspiring until you have come to se The Grand Tetons up close. They are beyond awesome - make the time to drive slowly, photograph, ponder, experience - all the sensory experiences you'll encounter on your way in to Yellowstone via the Grand Tetons
review_title: Bucket List - Grand Teton National Park, WY

review_body: One of the most beautiful places I have traveled. The drive through is amazing even if you never get out of your car. Amazing wildlife and the most serene mountain beauty. Take the trails and stop at the lakes. Stay for the ever-changing sunsets. The views change continually as the sun sets. We spent 2 days exploring. If you want the true mountain vacation, spend as much time in these mountains as you can. Plan to go back next summer!!!

We flew into Jackson Hole and rented a car. The Grand Tetons were white capped with snow with yellow wild flowers blooming at the base of the mountains. The pictures we took of the mountains, Jenny Lake, Jackson Lake and Hidden Falls will always be cherished. We are having one Grand Teton picture enlarged to hang over our mantle. The Grand Tetons are well worth your time, be sure to take a good camera.

Tetons are often combined with a trip to Yellowstone but really they stand alone. What a beautiful mountain range. I wish we would have spent more time exploring this area. We did a float trip through the national park and it was great--highly recommend (see separate review). View of tetons from Jackson Lake is spectacular.

We drove through the Grand Teton's on our 48 day West trip in June. I have seen them several times and the are still GRAND. Wow!There are so many places / vistas for photo opportunities. Around every corner is another great view. If you are going to or from Yellowstone then make it a point to see the Teton's on your way.

Stayed just one night in the Grand Tetons but the mountains and lake are a magnificent sight. If you visit Yellowstone make sure you spend some time here. Wyoming is certainly blessed to have such natural beauty in their state.
review_title: Beautiful park that rivals Yellowstone for scenery

review_body: I thought Yellowstone was lovely, but the Grand Tetons are totally different! These mountains are for climbing and skiing--and looking at!!!! Magnificient! It is difficult to pull your eyes away from the snow top, the simple beauty, the awesomeness of creation! Don't miss the Tetons.
review_title: Cried at First Sight of Tetons

review_body: There is a lot to do here. family friendly. Something for every one. We went for views and small walks. We saw some wildlife. Dramatic sunrises!!
The mountains are beautiful and breathtaking. I have never any thing as beautiful as the Tetons. We saw that the best time to go is mid July. The weather was perfect.

We have never seen such beauty. Everyplace you turn is beautiful and so much wildlife, bison, elk, mule deer, moose and more. My husband and I are in our 60's. Most of the hiking in the park are long trails. We would hike half way and turn around. A hike up to Tagert Lake is really pretty, we brought lunch and ate by the lake. We went early June, upper 50's, perfect for hiking, not a lot of people. The most crowds we saw were at Jenny Lake. We took the boat across which I recommend. Hiked to Hidden Falls which was beautiful. Continued on to Inspiration Point. If you are afraid of heights I would not go the full distance. You can get a beautiful view half way up. There is a ledge to get to the top, have to hang onto to the rocks. The Moose Lake trail was nice, no people, lots of wildlife. Beautiful, beautiful place.

My husband and I are "drawn back" to the Tetons each year. This year we brought our grown children/their husbands, and 7 grandchildren. Also, my husband's sister. Three different states were represented: Colorado, New York, and Nebraska.

This is a beautiful, fun park that is not very crowded (quite welcome compared to the crowds at Yellowstone National Park). The mountains are amazing. We had a great time just driving along taking in the mountains. We didn't have time for much hiking (except for Jenny Lake/Inspiration Point), but there seemed to be a lot of nice trails.

We came in near Teton Village the Wilson Mose entrance. It was a gravel road for a distance then became paved. We saw a moose drinking in a pond about 15 yards away. You could hear he lapping up the water. A 1/2 mile later we saw another mooseacross the river. It was great to see so early in the loop. There are plentry of bathroom breaks at the junctions and some overlooks.We saw lakes and rivers. The mountains were beautiful. It wasa little hazy early but cleared up. Would definitely do again.
review_title: Nice easy drive through the loop

review_body: Our drive through this park was in the evening, and the views were spectacular! Went hoping to spot moose munching on lakeside willows, but no luck. The sunset more than made up for this, as the majestic mountain reflections from the water are amazing!

We have been to several national parks with mountains. As my husband, figured out from the Park's visitor center, it just goes straight up without foot hills, an interesting geological formation. There isn't much to actually do in the park, but you do go thru/by it on the way to Yellowstone from Jackson Hole, WY.
Beautiful scenery everywhere you look. We saw bison in the valley on the way to the Park. Lots of hiking trails of various difficulties.

A fun, non-crowded National Park with activities for everyone! A "MUST" in your books of exploring the USA. It has activities for all levels of fitness and even handicap access. Swimming, hiking, boating, kayaking, guided tours, food etc...
This peak is named appropriately. It is easy to pick out from the others and provides a good indication for your current whereabouts. Truly the gem of GTNP!
Loved the mountains! Much prettier than I ever expected. Stayed in Yellowstone and then Grand Teton. Grand Teton was my favorite.

We went to Grand Teton for one reason and one alone. Ansel Adams got my husband into photography and he wanted to walk in his footsteps by going to the barn that is one of Ansel Adams's most famous photographs. He got lost in his photography and we got lost in the beauty of Grand Tetons. We walked through the historic Mormon houses and barns and loved seeing animals even in the short amount of time we spent there. This is a definite "go back to" for us. My husband got his photo's and we got another roadtrip. It seems a win win for all.

We visited Grand Teton National Park over 4th of July weekend. It's beautiful! We saw moose, bison, and deer. The bison were right next to the road! Hoped to see more, but weren't able to. We took the boat across Jenny Lake and hiked up to Inspiration Point. It is a great view from there. Not an amateur hike, but moderate and easily doable with tennis shoes. We also took the scenic drive by Jenny Lake and the Signal Point drive. Both give you great views of the park. It's a beautiful part of the country and I'm so glad we could experience it.

We loved the Tetons. Prior to going to Yellowstone, we stayed in the Tetons for 3 days. Glad we did. We stayed right at Jackson Hole Ski Resort so in less than a mile we were in the park. The mountains and lakes were beautiful. We saw a lot of moose and bear. Great place to go.

We planned a family vacation of 14 people ranging from 8 to 79 to Jackson, the Grand Tetons and Yellowstone. The Tetons are my favorite, not to say that I loved Yellowstone, too. What I loved about the Tetons, were the trails, the views, the majesty of the place. I always caught my eyes going to them. If you like to hike, there is a wide variety of difficulty. Around String lake and Leigh Lakes, easy. Jenny Lake moderate up to Hidden Falls. Inspiration Point is a little more difficult, especially if you are afraid of heights and edges! That's me, but I still did it. So did my 8, almost 13 and 15 year olds. A recommendation from a river guide took us to Phelp's Lake, a great hike where we saw a grizzly bear cross 30 yards in front of us. We did have bear spray. Yes, there is such a thing. We didn't know until we read up on Yellowstone. Overall, one of my favorite places. Would definitely go back. The 79 year old did not hike.

Not as famous as Yellowstone, but just as much of a must-see.We spent a day touring Grand Teton after a few days at Yellowstone. It was stunningly beautiful. The Tetons rise straight out of the plains without foothills exaggerating their majesty and making for wonderful photographs.Our favourite bits were: the visitors centre, Signal Mountain, Jackson Lake Dam, Mormon's Row and a gentle raft trip down the Snake River.
Loved the scenery and the calmness around it. It was so beautiful and grand.I didn't really like the dirty toilets but that's common with national parks.
review_title: Very Scenic and a must visit place

review_body: Stunning views, great drive through and hikes. Just outside of Jackson Hole, Wyoming. Pack a picnic and just relax by a lake in the shadow of these towering giants.

Can't beat the view of the mountains. Much nicer to stay at Grand Teton rather than Yellowstone. The Ranger programs could have been better. The Ranger summer interns just weren't up to the task but the regular Rangers were great.

It's hard to say what it's really like here. You have to experience it in person. Everywhere you look the views are breath taking and spectacular. Take time to drive the speed limit(45 or less) visit the pull-ins for views that you won't believe. A previous writer said he/she didn't like following at 45mph. Seems strange to make that comment as the posted legal speed limit is 45 mph or less in some high traffic areas. One of the reasons why so many animals are killed by cars each year is because people like him don't obey the law. Protect the animals that so many come here to see.
Liked the views. Did not like following multiple RVs running 45 mph. Some did pull over and let us go by. Bless their hearts!

What can be said about this beautiful park that hasn't already been said? Definitely not a park to be missed if you're close by or in need of a good road trip. The drive through the outside of the park is scenic, but a nice hike in the park would do it even more justice. Our favorite short hike is Jenny Lake Trail--you can take the boat back afterwards if you want a different view of the Tetons. A more "serious" hike up to Inspiration Point will also give you a new perspective of Moose, Wyoming. Just can't say enough about this park. We come back every year to see these beautiful mountains. It's one of our favorites!
review_title: A M A Z I N G!

review_body: God's country! Beauty at every turn and pictures just can't capture what your eyes can see. Even in late June there were lots of snow topped mountains. The temperatures can vary greatly, so be prepared and layer, so you can put on or take off, as needed. Lots of wonderful trails, waterfalls, picnic areas and wildlife. We used GaperGuide, a GPS that you rent at lots of points near the Tetons or Yellowstone. It even told fun facts, the best bathrooms, wildlife info, and trail information. It was wonderful and always knew where we were and gave us lots of park information that we would have missed without it. The Barker-Ewing Scenic Raft trip on the Snake River was terrific. It showed the park from a totally different perspective.
Good wildlife viewing and seriously picturesque place. Makes anyone a good photographer. Park is a bit small and roadways limited, so hiking is the only way to really taking advantage.
review_title: magnificent place, not so much to do

review_body: There are many beautiful sights to be experienced. Lakes, mountains, wildlife, and weather conditions. Another beautiful area is the Teton pass, if you have the time don't miss it.
review_title: Excellent addition to a yellowstone trip

review_body: Grant Teton National Park continues to be my choice for having the most beautiful scenery in the U.S. I live in the south, so the lower temperatures and (still!) snow in the mountains, and at times, along the hiking trails, are soooo refreshing. I love the lake trails in particular; there are many "easy" hikes that the entire family can enjoy. I would recommend that hikers ask for specific trail guides at the gates of the park to ensure you know how to access the trail heads and exactly how long those hikes are going to be--it's easy to underestimate. There are several restaurants available at lodges and other park facilities if needed, in addition to plentiful picnic areas.
We spent here our latest vacation and it was great. Everything. Weather, accommodation, food, trails, kayaking, cycling,...

Driving the distance doesn't get any better than this...The drive to Yellowstone through Grand Teton National Park is so beautiful. Plenty of areas to pull off for pictures and lunch. Don't forget to take those back roads, they are worth the time!

The beauty, history, views, things to do, things to see will all leave you breathless! This is a nature lovers dream spot. Elk, buffalo, moose, bears, antelope, horse ranches and more all on a painters canvas it seems. This is close to Heaven on Earth.
The scenery is almost too beautiful to believe. This gem of a national park is a true treasure. Great hiking, beautiful lodges, lakes, wildlife....it has it all!
Both the mountain range, of which Grand Teton is the tallest peak, and the park are well worth the time and effort to see!

I think that Grand Tetons is on of the most beautiful places to photo.You will be amazing each day with the different way they look depending on the sun,clouds or snow. Do Not Leave your camera at home!!

On our way to Yellowstone we allotted one day at the Grand Tetons but ended up spending 2. Park is breathtaking!!!! We saw several elk, deer, a moose and a herd of bison crossing the road right in front of our car. Just a beautiful!!!! Only disappointment was the rude cashier at general store inside Grand Lodge.

We came to this park to do some back country camping at a time when it is less popular to do so. We hiked into the mountains and there was still snow in the backcountry camping areas. The scenery is beautiful and we saw a ton of wildlife including moose and marmots while hiking through death canyon.
Looking at the Tetons will take your breath away! How wonderful it would be to sit in the same spot each day just to see how the clouds and sun change the look of the landscape.

Absolutely beautiful and in May at least, uncrowded. Take your camera, the views are spectacular. Was not at all impressed with the town of Jackson. Very expensive, unfriendly and a "tourist trap" mentality pervades. Stay in the National Park and you won't be disappointed.

Unmatched beauty! Mirror Lake against the Tetons, the rich smell of the pines...breathtaking!! Part of our 12 day National Park tour celebrating our wedding anniversary...34 years with my sweetheart. ; ))

The most beautiful place I've ever had the pleasure of visiting. Words and pictures can't describe the beauty. God's Country!!! From the mountain peaks to the foliage and all the wildlife just an amazing trip that everyone should experience.
Wonderful views and experience. A wonder of God's creation here in the states. The 4-wheel drive trail was truly memorable along the Snake a River.
I love Yellowstone but the Tetons are more beautiful. These mountains are stunning. Mount Moran hovers over Jackson Lake like the Alps over Lake Geneva but in a more natural setting.

Tetons are one of a kind mountain range that doesn't have large foot hills. It stands tall straight and looks very majestic. Its a beautiful park with lots of hiking trail and wild life. I got to see a moose there which was great. Enjoy the beautiful scenery including the arrow leaf blossom yellow flower. Do take the scenic drive and take tons of pictures.

This set of peaks is somewhat unique in the US. They remind me of the Alps. Grand Teton national park is adjacent to Yellowstone and you have to go through it to get to the South entrance to Yellowstone.

Absolutely grand! We camped in the park so had easy access as well as about 13 miles out of Jackson Hole. We had rain, snow, and cold but did not deter from the experience. According to locals June is a rainy month but we did have some days when it was warm enough to wear shorts. Lots of hiking, biking and just about anything else. A photographers dream with mountains, snow and wild flowers. We stayed 6 days and didn't want to leave. Something new about the mountains every day. It's a national park so there is a fee. If you are a senior (65) the life time pass is $10.00

Grand Teton National Park is a splendid placed lined with majestic mountains and filled with amazing sights to see.The majority of our trip in this park was driven, but we did visit and hiked the upper trail around Jenny Lake to Inspiration Point/ Hidden Falls. The hike is about 2 hours one way and we encountered alot of wildlife along the way (marmots, birds, etc). If you are wary of the hike, you can also opt to take the Boat Shuttle, which will take you closer to Inspiration Point (the hike would only be about 30 minutes after you get off the boat). Either way, a visit to Jenny Lake is highly suggested whether you drive or hike. There is an excellent visitors center as well.

The perfect, jagged, snow-capped peaks of the Tetons can be seen from various vantage points in Grand Teton National Park. The Tetons are just minutes from Yellowstone National Park and they can even be seen from Yellowstone on a clear day. They are absolutely spectacular!

We drove through on both roads and came in both the main entrance as well as Moose Wilson. Took the Jenny Lake boat and hike. It was cold and rainy but those mountains look gorgeous in any weather! We saw a moose and her baby but heard others talk of bears, marmot, wolves, etc that they'd seen around. It is a small, manageable park with friendly staff. Yellowstone is so HUGE and tiring that Grand Teton just feels perfect in size and bang for your buck :).

Most phenomenal mountains I've ever seen. Still snow capped Memorial Day weekend, although we had 80 degree weather. Jenny Lake is not to be missed (west side of main road; small sign directs). Pronghorn, their young, moose, elk, coyotes, grizzly and brown bear, wolves, fresh pine scent abounds. At peace with nature. Not so crowded this time of year, and accommodation rates are quite reasonable ($65-80/hs). Didn't have time to hike, since park adjacent to Yellowstone, which we also saw in 2 days, but that would have been fabulous, as well as camping for outdoor lovers. After a winter of 500" of snow, waterfalls were spectacular as well. Jackson has everything you need (gas, restaurants, shops) in the evening.

The mountains just come right into the Jackson Lake and are covered with glaciers and snow. Fast flowing rivers and small lakes can be found throughout the park. Great variety of outdoor things from hiking to mountaineering, kayaking or just taking a boat ride are available. Easy place to cycle. We wished we had more time to spend there.
We did a one day tour and took in the boat tour on Jenny Lake. Beautiful country. Fun and informative boat trip. We were a little early for the spring flowers, bummer.

Internet at the lodge office, also guest laundry. We were gone for 4 weeks and the laundry came in handy. No TV, we read a lot of books at night. Adequate, clean, cabin. Don't miss the drive up Signal Mountain and the drive around Jenny Lake. Be sure to take your camera for sunset pics.
review_title: Beautiful Tetons and Cute little Cabin

review_body: you ride along these for miles going to jackson hole . looks like a picture its so beautiful. seen some wildlife there. the most beautiful mountains in the u.s. in my opinion
Words can´t describe this magnificient mountain range. Every day if it is visable is a won day. Go there and enjoy it!

There is no bad view of the Teton's but Jackson Lake Lodge is an incredible place to stay. There are plenty of people to help arrange activities or make suggestions. I would recommend a car. The new National Museum of Wildlife Art is on the way to the lodge from the airport.
review_title: Jackson Hole's best view of the Tetons

review_body: The large flat valley floor covered in wildflowers, with tall, jagged peaks jetting up straight out of the valley with almost no foothill area. There are a vast number of hiking trails and biking trails for every fitness level, and viewing areas that are accessible by car with just a short stroll to the overlook. I especially love two areas in particular to take in scenery: Schwabacher's Landing and the Jackson Lake Overlook from Signal Mountain Road. These two will take your breath away (if the altitude hasn't already done so :-)

Our first hike in the Grand Teton National Park brought us to the Jenny Lake Loop Trail. At 7.30am we already saw a Moose very close to the visitor center standing in the river. With beautiful weather and well equipped with hiking poles we started off going east around the Lake. At first we were a bit disappointed as the trail was going parallel to a road.
