A couple warned us that they have seen a mother bear and her cubs. Bear spray ready we just continued talking loudly and clapping our hands. Indeed, after 20 minutes we saw the bear and one of the small ones next to her standing approx. 25 meters on the hillside away. We continued with beating hearts - nevertheless what an amazing experience! The trail winds around the lake and we were glad to have our hiking poles with us when we came across a stretch where there was still quite a lot of snow. Later on we came across some dear, marmots and cute chipmunks and another moose just 10 meters away from us. The whole hike around the lake takes approx. 4 1/2 hours but is easy as there is nearly no elevation change. There is also a possibility to take boots across the lake to shorten the hike. Though we found the noise from the boat motor a bit disturbing.Grand Teton has a breath-taking scenery, abundant wildlife and seems to be less crowded than e.g. Yellowstone.
review_title: Jenny Lake Loop Trail - Amazing beauty and wildlife

review_body: Entering or leaving Yellowstone through the southern entrance will automatically take you through the Grand Tetons. If you enter Yellowstone through any other entrance you need to be sure and exit the southern route and spend a few hours in the Grand Tetons. The mountains, rivers and lakes are some of the most beautiful in the country. Be sure to drive as many of the scenic byways that are open, especially Jenny Lake. You won't be disappointed.

This national park is just the best for beauty, wildlife, variety of activities and extremelyuser friendly cabins, tent camping, RVing, gift shop, grocery store.Go here first before Yellowstone and you might just stay.America at its best.

Went to Yellowstone the day before and was in love; I thought. Then I saw the Tetons. Absolutely breath taking! I loved my visit here. Various pull outs with information and trailheads; great picture spots. Great spot to launch boats at Jenny Lake. everywhere we went we saw awesomeness! This is a must see.
Yellowstone has many geographic wonders; but for shear beauty and majesty, the Tetons can not be beat.

In 2012, I spent four days touring Yellowstone and came down to the Grand Teton national Park on a day trip. I knew I would come back one day for a longer stay. If I were to do it over again, I would see Yellowstone in a day trip and spent the bulk of my time in Jackson Hole and the Grand Teton National Park. It's that nice. You can only see a couple of geysers and bubbling mud pots before you decide it's time to move on.
its nice view from top of 10000 feet mountains. We went on Tram to top up the mountains and its so good but its windy and cold.

This is a MUST SEE! Absolutely stunning area. There is a bicycle trail that you can do that has the Teton as you're backdrop and it is breathtaking. You pay $25 to get in but that includes entrance to Yellowstone as well. You have 7-day usage to see both parks! Worth staying a whole week then some to truly take in the total experience. It is worth buying out time for to see such stunning and beautiful landscape.

The mountains are incredible - my visit to the part exceeded my expectations. We saw all sorts of animals - bears, moose, buffalo, beavers. The scenery is just amazing. Everyone should plan to go here once in their lifetimes.

The Grand Tetons are astounding! No foothills -- they just rise up into giant peaks -- beautiful and awesome viewing from the east shore of Jackson Lake. We were there in May - the lake was mostly frozen with most campgrounds and trails closed and snow-covered. However, the views of the mountains along Teton Park Road were awesome.
Perfect time of year - May - not too busy and weather was perfect. Beautiful scenery and well kept roads. Grand Teton Visitors Center was great and had lots of useful information and clean restrooms!
The Grand Tetons are absolutely breathtaking and one of our most treasured highlights of our trip. An absolute must see. We will definitely be returning to do some hiking.
review_title: One of the most beautiful areas in the US

review_body: My husband and I enjoyed a 4 day trip to Grand Teton National Park over Memorial Day. We did a lot of hiking, and were not disappointed with any of the trails. We found amazing views and animal life everywhere we went. We ran into bears on two of our hikes, which added some excitement, but I highly recommend carrying bear spray just in case. Fortunately we did not need to use it, but it was nice to know we had it. I also recommend good hiking boots and poles this time of year. There was still quite a bit of snow, and the poles really helped us manage the snow without incident. I highly recommend this park and will definitely be back again!

Amazing scenery, great hikes for both the adventurous and the less able, water sports, fishing, picnics, pretty much everything you can ask for in the great outdoors. Lodging in the area can be expensive, try Coulter Bay Cabins.
Wow, you have to see the Tetons for yourself. We were blown away by the beauty of this mountain range and all the wonderful views of the lakes. This was a fantastic place to see!!!
review_title: Put this on your Bucket List

review_body: Winter varies. We were in the Grand Tetons on May15.While it is a beautiful, majestic place, much of we wanted to do was still closed.Shuttle boats, tourist boats, aerial tramway., some trails and lookout points all closed for at least another week or more.One fee for both Grand Tetons & Yellowstone.

Grand Teton NP is located south of Yellowstone NP. I would recommend visiting Grand Teton NP. There are breathtaking views, wildlife, lake, river and a Museum that showcases various animals found in the park and Grand Teton's History. I would also recommend visiting both Yellowstone and Grand Tetons at the same time if your time allows. Plan on 1 day to see everything that Grand Tetons have to offer. Avoid the winter time, they do get a lot of snow in the Winter. This is a treasure in Wyoming. Last visit in 2009.
It is an amazing park and the hikes are great. Wish we could spend more time explore and hiking into the back country and of course the sunrise and sunset present awe inspiring views

It is hard to find words to describe something so incredibly majestic. We were on a business trip and our activities were planned for us so we went by bus. We saw a moose, bedded down in some brush. I wonder what he was thinking when a bus stopped and 20 people got out to look at him while he napped. Ha! Ha! He was HUGE with a face only a mother could love. ;)The mountains are nothing short of amazing - the sheer size and stature of them make you marvel at nature in all her glory. Our guide showed us where people had climbed to the top of the tetons and we thought his joke about how many was funny. He said the explorers who named the park must have had too much to drink as there are 3 mountains!! (Teton means breast in French.)While photos do not do this place justice, we took them anyway. Ansel Adams, the famous photographer, took many here and you can see why it was a favorite source of inspiration. We took a few photos in the exact spot he did for fun.We saw some lakes were people were swimming and kids were playing. I guess warm depends on where you are from...that water was way too cold for us to even think about getting in. Ha! Ha! Perhaps they were locals. :)Absolutely gorgeous place to visit in the summer. Beautiful and relaxing.

Most everyone has read about or seen Yellowstone National Park, but to me the Grand Tetons are even more majestic. We stayed in Jackson hole and entered the park through a back door entrance to the park. In under two miles we saw several bears and moose on a small two lane road where you were up close and personal. We visited in the fall where the colors of the foliage is amazing. You are only a few miles from Yellowstone so don't miss it. Oh yes, take a float trip down the Snake River for the best views!

We did not plan on going through the the Grand Teton National Park, but when we had stopped for breakfast that morning we met a tour bus driver...He said that the Tetons were a must...well he was right...it was definitely worth the extra drive!
The Grand Tetons are even more breathtaking in person than seeing a picture! You must see them in person!
Right next to Yellowstone National Park is a must see if traveling through - fall is especially beautiful

Majestic mountains with lots of wildlife. We always see moose, elk and bison and other animals too. There are generally less people here than in Yellowstone which is a bonus. One of my favorite parks!

Absolutely amazing park. We flew into Salt Lake City and rented a car, then drove up to the park. It was a great drive up as well, especially if you haven't been to that part of the country before. Way less people here than at Yellowstone, a huge plus. Recommend the ranger hike that takes you across the lake and up to a waterfall and a great lookout.
Majestic! That's the best way to describe the views inside this park. One of my favorite spots! I love looking at the mountains. One must see to appreciate.
We drove through Grand Teton on our way to Yellowstone. It is nice place to stop by and take pictures and enjoy views.Visited in Jul-10Duration of visit: 1-3 hrs

In my opinion, Grand Teton is often overlooked by the Yellowstone visitors. But this is exactly what makes Grand Teton National Park even better. I have visited both Yellowstone and Grand Teton. I usually only spend one day in Yellowstone and five days in Grand Teton. Why? 1. Less crowded. 2. Have always seen more wildlife. 3. Ease of travel around the area. 4. Easy access to remote hiking trails. In Grand Teton you can see the same wildlife as Yellowstone, with a much better chance of seeing the various types of wildlife more than once. Two Ocean Lake is wonderful for a secluded kayaking adventure. The time I kayaked on Two Ocean, we were the only people on the lake. There are also kayaking opportunities on Jenny Lake and Leigh Lake. Anyone who goes to Grand Teton should hike Cascade Canyon. Another wonderful thing about Grand Teton is the amount of really good lodging locations located on private property within or near the park. This gives you the option to stay at bed and breakfasts, rustic cabins and guest ranches right inside the park itself.

We recently made a very specific visit to Grand Teton NP. We trekked the Granite Canyon trail on XC skis with a guide. Lucky for us, the trail had already been broken by someone, making it slightly easier for us. The entire loop took about 2 hours, including a full five to ten minutes where I fell in deep snow and it took that long get up. (Humbled!) By the looks of it, only one or two people had preceded us in the fresh snowfall but it was enough to tamp it down slightly and gave us the added advantage to having a trail to follow. Our guide brought bear spray, something I might not have known to do. While there were no bears, we did see FRESH bear tracks, unusual in late January I gather, but there they were, demonstrating that the bear spray wasn't just a superfluous splurge. The trail was lovely, winding uphill (sometimes it seems that everything is always uphill) through forest, over streams and aspen groves. There are many other trails and trailheads; we only had time to explore one. The mountains ringing the distant views were constantly changing in the light, clouds and snow. It was quiet, beautiful and perfect.Since we were true newbies there, our guide was indispensable; we learned what all the animal tracks were (came in handy during the rest of the week) and also the types of trees and assorted history. Restaurant verification ad recommendations, too. And, of course, that bear spray.
review_title: Majestic Mountains, Deep Tall Woods, Burbling Streams

review_body: I've heard many people say that Grand Teton is better than Yellowstone for wildlife, and this may well be true.We had limited time in the parks, and the lure of the Geysers meant that Yellowstone was our priority, but we spent most of a day in Grand Teton. We didn't get to see much wildlife, but the scenery was spectacular. Maybe not the wow factor of some areas of Yellowstone, but fantastic in its own way.If you're going to Yellowstone then I'd recommend trying to fit in a visit here as well. It's easy enough if you enter or leave Yellowstone from the South.
With herds of buffalo, deer and elk running it its shadows, the majesty of the Grand Teton National Park is not to missed. The horseback riding is especially good and the hiking trails are excellent.
review_title: One of The Great Sights in North America

review_body: I loved how many trails there were to hike on. We chose the most difficult one, and it was a blast! It was off of Death Canyon Trail to Static Peak --- A 20 mile hike in 10 hours to 11,000 ft. elevation.

I had Grand Teton National Park in my bucket list and it is one of the many places I can never get tired of visiting. My husband and I have camped around this vicinity and waking up early in the morning to the magnificent Tetons is breathtaking! The peaks are magnificent and so are the wildlife viewing, if you are patient. Depending on the light angles, you can take gorgeous photos of the Tetons in its many facets. The last time my husband and I visited the Grand Tetons was in June of 2008.
review_title: It's called Grand for a Reason

review_body: Grand Teton is very accessible from Yellowstone, barely an hours drive. It is a grand nature's creation in itself, though not at par with Yellowstone. It has some very interesting and unique traits and deserves a full day if not two.
review_title: Must visit if you are visiting Yellowstone

review_body: We travelled here in the winter, so the Teton's played peek-a-boo most of our stay. When they came out, they were amazing! We did a ranger led snowshoe trip from Taggart Lake Trailhead. It was about 20 degrees, with 40 mph winds, and snow. We still went and it was awesome! Beautiful and serene. The ranger (Ann? She was from Houston and I forgot her name!) was great! We used actual snowshoes from 1943 when they were scouting the park. We learned about the different park animals and snow (our 14 year old loved it!). Lot's of people were out XC skiing and snowshoeing privately. Everyone we ran into our trip was so nice and helpful!!

We visited in June 2013, amazing scenery, got there just before school holidays rush, after a visit to Yellostone, amazing scenery, take the camera and lots of memory, stayed in Buffalo which is a nice town to wander around and plenty of places to eat and drink but pricey.

This area is very different to Yellowstone. The green trees disappears and makes way for grey grasslands. The land rises up into tall barren mountains. There is a real wildness and adventure atmoshere to this park. There are great hiking trails, scenic loop drives and great photo stops.
Pictures definitely do not capture the beauty of the Grand Teton's. The best pictures can be taken at Jenny Lake. Unbelievable!!!

Overall this is the adventurers park. Yellowstone is mostly driving. Great for a day trip or two.If you want to experience nature and the west... stay here.Jenny Lake hike was nice.. sunset at Signal mountain (but not the top) was good, sunrise as the lake near Signal Mountain, and I stayed at Colter Bay.
One of the most beautiful places I have ever seen. You can spend weeks there if you want. People are nice everywhere. Go see my pictures from there on facebook.com/anttifoto
The Pioneer Grill at the Grand Teton Lodge offers big portions and a large selection of good food. Considering the spectacular location, it is an excellent choice for your meals.
Beautiful nature, wild animals everywhere! Go for a morning safari, that's when the chances of spotting animals are at the best:)

Well, these are enormous, beautiful mountains that are postcard perfect summer, winter, spring or fall. What more do you want? Just driving by is a great experience, having the endless spine out your window with its gentle rivers, long green fields and blue sky. Everyone seems to like the Tetons and with good reason. We didn't get to do much hiking there, but just getting around the foothills was a neat experience and I enjoyed the view from far away (some day we'll go hiking up one).

This is always a beautiful drive we have always just driven threw here on our way to Yellowstone I love the mountains so they are always beautiful to me we have been threw it in the summer and in the fall both are a beautiful time to visit. it all depends on rather you wish to camp and spend a couple of days or if you are just driving threw and looking and the scenery. Allow your self plenty time to stop and take pictures.

We live in New England and have been to NH, VT, and Maine's mountains...but we have long looked forward to experincing the Grand Tetons. They are magnificent! We saved four days after our stay in Yellowstone to allow ourselves to be surrounded by these awesome mountains. Picnic by String Lake, hike up Inspration Point, drive up Signal Mountain road, and stop at Jenny Lake Overlook.
review_title: If you like mountains, you will love the Tetons!

review_body: It is really hard to write a review about something so natural and untouched as the Tetons. It does not matter what season of the year you visit, the beauty and magnificence of nature will be right there. My husband and I visited Grand Teton in late October 2013. We experienced fall and winter in two consecutive days. The Visitors Center has a very nice movie that explains the geologic origins and changes of the area, and a very nice store. Please note that by mid October all the lodges and restroom facilities throughout the park close until the spring. Only a private restaurant and some shops are open. Some roads become too dangerous during the winter and are closed by the park police. Whether you are a professional or amateur photographer, take your time stopping at the different outlooks. It is interesting to see how the character and silhouette of the mountains change with perspective. Enjoy it any season of the year!
review_title: Nature as the first explorers experienced it

review_body: Okay, it may be tied for first place between Zion! The mountains seemed like a dream! I will go back there again. It is not a huge park but its' scenery most certainly is!!!

To travel through the park from the southern boundary of Grand Teton National Park to Yellowstone National Park via the outer Highway takes a little more than one hour not including stops along the way; to travel through the park via the Teton Park Road takes slightly longer.These are mountains of the imagination. Mountains that led to the creation of Grand Teton National Park where you can explore over two hundred miles of trails, float the Snake River or enjoy the serenity of this remarkable place.

For me this place was a Photo Paradise with the mountains, beautifull nature, the lakes, the wildlife and the trails. My nr 1 National Park. I stayed here for 7 days in total and already planned to back.

We spent two months touring the West Coast of America recently and we are glad that we took the time to visit Grand Teton. It is a very attractive park with lots of wild life and a must see and well worth the drive from Salt Lake City. We had a lovely camping spot just beside Jackson Lake and it was wonderful being able to see the stars at night from the camp site. There are many pleasant walks around the park and the walk to Jenny and Taggart Lakes is very attractive. As we visited several national parks on our trip we found it useful to purchase the annual pass to get into the parks because it is more convenient and a saving in costs overall.

From the sparkling blue waters the Tetons rise from the lakeshore to touch the clouds. The Fall colours are wonderful and the Glaciers still cling to the mountain side in sheltered gulleys which all makes for spectacular viewing. A stroll along the lake, a boat trip across it and a drive up Signal mountain for spectacular panoramic views are just some of the options you have to enjoy along with the views. We found it easy to find quiet spots along the lakeshore just to sit and breath in the air and surroundings, it was so peaceful you could not help but feel the 'inner calm' wash over you. Boy I wanna go back right now !

You must include a trip to the grand Tetons when visiting this area. I am always surprised at the people who tell me they didn't go there but, they were in Yellowstone. We actually saw more wildlife in the Tetons than Yellowstone, It is a beautiful park. Don't miss it!

This park is well worth your visit, even if you have to drive 6 hours from Salt Lake City International Airport. I went in August when the weather was still warm and the skies as blue as the finest turquoise. It's $25 per vehicle for a week pass to the park (includes entry to Yosemite) and many of the top attractions are only within a few miles.I loved Jenny Lake, and the hike around the lake from the Visitor's Center to Hidden Falls is well worth the time and effort--and risk of encountering a bear. Rich conifer forest and well-worn trails take you higher and higher as you go, with a spectacular view of the lake as you near the falls. Watch your step in some areas as there's a steep dropoff.Another favorite is Phelps Lake, easily accessible near the Jackson Hole entrance, but also along the narrow, windy park entry road from Teton Village. A 4-mile roundtrip is all it takes. It's not as far as it seems and the peace and serenity of just gazing at the lake does more for your mental health than anything I've ever experienced. The John Moulton Barn with its Grant Teton backdrop is probably one of the most photographed scenes in the U.S., if not the world. Though the barn is not lived in, you almost want to move in here so you can continue to feel the exhilaration for the rest of your life. If you're lucky, you'll get a chance to see grizzly bears, black bears, moose, elk, bighorn sheep and mule deer as you drive the John D. Rockefeller Memorial Parkway, which leads through the park on up to Yellowstone.Truly, there's so much breathtaking scenery here that I could go on for days. You also should spend time in Teton Village (to the east) and Jackson (to the south). But towns are extremely interesting, and Jackson is now one of my top towns I want to go back to.Put this place on your list now.
review_title: One of the best national parks

review_body: You must include a trip to the TETONS in your bucket list. The Tetons offers a lot hiking trails for all different experience levels. There many options of hotels at Jackson Hole and Teton Village, but if you are staying inside of the national park you have a few choices. From here you can travel to Yellowstone National Park.

My wife and I visited the Tetons this past September but my most memorable visit was 40 years ago when I climbed Mt. St. John. I was only 20 years old at the time. As I look back, I can't believe I did it and I did it alone. Pretty stupid. If you have the physical ability, this is a mountain range that you should consider spending some time in. The views are simply spectacular. But even if you are a bit challenged in the hiking dept., you can't go wrong with a slow and methodical drive through the park.
We didn't have time to hike. Just rode through. Fortunately we were not on our motorcycle, because we got caught on the Pass in a fierce storm! Was still a beautiful ride!

We spent four days in Yellowstone and only one day in Grand Teton and everyone wished it had been the other way around. Less crowds, amazing-beautiful scenery just beyond words, and a much more pleasant smell! Our youngest member was disappointed that you had to be 5 years old to ride the boats but he had a good time splashing in the lake. The water was a little cold for about half our party but there was a nice pleasant beach for sun bathing.
How can the high snow covered peaks, broad valleys and roaming wildlife not be a wonder of nature. Mountains mirrored in Jackson Lake make a super photograph.

While on our way to Yellowstone Park we stopped for a side trip at Grand Teton Park; and it was the highlight of our trip. Be sure to visit OxBow Bend to see the mountain range mirrored in the water. The animals are abundant, elk, bears, geese, swans. So many places to photograph and not as crowded as Yellowstone. Well worth the hour drive to reach from Yellowstone....we went twice.
These mountains are gorgeous. The wildlife can be found roaming freely and the snowcapped grand tetons in the background make for amazing photos and memories. Beautiful scenery all around.

This park is drop-dead gorgeous! One of the most breathtaking places I have ever visited. We stopped by the Grand Tetons in May on a cross-country road trip and my expectations were blown away. There was still snow on the mountains and it made for fantastic pictures. I would definitely recommend going to the lakes surrounding the mountains as the views are phenomenal. As many pictures as you take they never can replicate the feeling of standing in front of those mountains. My friend, who was on the road trip with me, and I were pinching ourselves at how surreal this stunning park is. The Tetons are #1 on my "must go back and visit" list.
We mainly drove around and stopped to take pictures. There wonderful places to hike if you want to. Great place to be in the outdoors. We got to see elk and bears also.
Grand Teton is one of the most amazing for taking photos. There are many beautiful snow mountains. Mormon Row Barns is a amazing spot for photos. It is "most photographed barn in America"

We visited here in September. Crowds were not bad and the weather great. The Tetons are amazing. The beauty cannot be described. We stayed in Jackson which was a comfortable commute. I highly recommend everyone see the Tetons.

This is one place to stop just to marvel at the majesty and grandeur of the Rocky Mountains at their most spectacular. Every mile is a slightly different (or very different) view and you want to stop and capture everything with your camera. You can't truly capture the beauty, so please, be sure to stop and pull the camera away long enough to fully take in and appreciate the natural beauty in front of you.

I didn't have time to hike and see the area the way you really should but driving through along the scenic drive gives to an idea of how majestic and peaceful the area.Spend a full day to really experience the national park.

We stayed in Jackson, WY for three days to see the Grand Teton National Park. The US sure does have some beautiful country. Our timing was good because the parks are closed down right now. The best times to see the Tetons are sunrise and sunset. The colors are just out of this world.
review_title: Great Place to Stop on the way to Yellowstone National Park

review_body: We were limited in time. Go to the visitor center (it is very good) and take the scenic loop drive. However it was so much better to see the majestic mountains at different times of the day and take a few hikes. We stayed in Jackson which was OK but next time we will make sure to stay at one of the lodges in the park to get the real experience.
review_title: Easy to see in a day - but you will want to stay longer

review_body: It was a cold, cloudy and rainy day when we drove through the Grand Teton National Park, but you could not miss the grandeur. We couldn't see the peaks of the mountains, but just the way they spring out of the flatland is breathtaking.The Visitor Center was exceptional. The national park system is really a great value, and this one belongs in your "favorites".

It was amazing to see the glaciers on the mountains. Stayed at Glacier Bay campground which had spectacular views of the lake and mountains. The campground was not to nice. Try the off roads to see animal life. We were able to hear the elk and see river otters on an off road.

We went there to see wildlife--and were not disappointed. The person at the main visitor center told us to check Antelope Flats, and the area between the main highway and Wolff Ranch Road. Our lodge suggested Gros Ventre campground. We spotted nothing at Antelope Flats, one lonely moose near the campground, and were heading the last area thinking, oh well, maybe next time. First we spotted the herd but it was far away from the highway, so we took Wolff Ranch Road to get closer. Along the way we were treated to two dozen+ pronghorn antelope, then noticed that the herd was crossing the road from over the hill into the big meadow. Worth every minute! Evidently this time of year the bison hang out there as the next day we once again saw them, this time alongside the main highway near Wolff Ranch Rd. again. As the largest North American land mammal, they are impressive.
We really enjoyed the Tetons. Seen lots of Moose, Deer etc..Jenny Lake is really pretty. Can't wait to go back!!

The scenery in Grand Teton is magnificent. The have a cycling trial from Jenny Lake Area all the way to Jackson village which must be close to 30 miles long. The trail is mostly flat with great scenery all the way

Oh, wow, what can we say! We stayed in the Teton Village area which was simply beautiful. The park itself is amazing. We spent three days there. It's not as large as the Yellowstone Park but if you have the time, don't miss this one.

The Grand Tetons are some of the most beautiful mountains in the world. We approached on a clear day, from the south and could see the Tetons for many miles before we actually got to them. We took the time to use some of the pull over areas before we were actually in the park and the views are spectacular. The mountains against the blue sky and fluffy white clouds were unforgettable.Also take the time to see Jenny Lake. It is off of a southbound one way road but the views of the mountains coming down to the shore of the lake are among the best in the park.

Grand Teton National park combines America's great beauty with the history of the settlement of the West! My wife and I loved the park and would strongly recommend it. The Teton Mountain chain makes up the park's western boundary. Drive Teton Park Road ( the loop road) for breathtaking views from the top of Signal Mountain and the Jenny Lake Overlook. A sense of the area's rich history, visit Menors Ferry Historic District and the Church of the Transfiguration. A visit to this park is a truly wonderful and rewarding experience!

The National Park is a true destination. There is so much to see in the Park it is difficult to make choices. The Visitors Center staff was warm and insightful. The Park Rangers were great and September is probably the best month of the year to see the park. The colors turned from green to autumn in one week.
review_title: A Once in A lifetime experience

review_body: Moose Wilson Road is loaded with wildlife. Black Bear and Moose. But folks this is not a zoo so enjoy from a distance. We had to watch 4 wildlife photographers chase a black bear up a tree and stress it out. I appreciate their art and craft but not at the expense of the animal. Get a longer lens or longer binocs if you have to get closer. Kudos to the park rangers for handling the situation. Plus if you get too close the animals may not like it and you end up on an episode of "When Vacations Attack."
review_title: get up early because the animals do

review_body: Really great park, we have visited many of the National Parks and this is one of the best. Very nice drive which allows you to see almost everything you want to. A lot of wildlife everywhere, mountains are awe inspiring. Highly recommended!

We spent 2 days Sept 10th and 11th at Grand Teton. We love there is not as busy as Yellowstone. Be able to look at the mountain so close is just wonderful. We wish the Jackson Lake can be at a higher level, that will make the view more amazing. However, we still love we did go to Grand Teton as we saw a lot of animals and bald egles. If you are a hiker or love riding bike, you will love love love it.

My family and I (including two boys ages 11 and 13) visited this park along with the lower loop of Yellowstone in June of 2013. If you have the chance to visit, please take advantage of seeing one of the most beautiful places in America. Photos are not the same thing as being there to experience the beauty of the mountains and both National Parks in person. We will definitely be back to visit again.
Views not as great as Yellowstone NP, but that is our opinion. Very nice mountain views. Nice campground ( only one with an available site) at Coulter Bay.

We stayed at Jackson and explored the park from there. There is an excellent loop road that takes you along the bottom of the range through Moose, South Jenny Lake, North Jenny Lake, Jackson Lake Lodge, make sure that you do the Lunch Tree Hill walk at the back of the lodge, takes about 30 minutes and you will not be disappointed, then return back through Antelope Flats, we took the whole day as there are many turnouts where you can take photos.

Another of our spectacular National Parks. There are amazing views, great trails, lots of animals and fun things for just about everyone. We saw a mother moose and her calf just feet from the boat dock. This is a great park to visit.

From Yellowstone, we headed south into Grand Teton not really knowing what to expect except for some mountain peaks. We soon realized that Grand Teton was going to be perhaps just as wonderful as Yellowstone but in a different way.We saw hundreds of bison, some elk, and antelopes. We shot more pictures in Grand Teton than Yellowstone. The everchanging landscape of the mountains on the lakes made the shots unbelievable.
The Grand Teton's are spectacular! We did a rafting trip and it was great. This was part of our 8 day tour with Caravan Tours. The whole tour was top notch. I would travel with Caravan again.
This park is truly stunning. The landscape is amazing and we saw bears, elk, moose, bald eagles and more. A must-see!

The lesser known of the 2 adjacent parks with Yellowstone, this park doesn't disappoint. There are many wonderful viewpoints of the peaks for the less adventuresome including Mormon Row and Oxbow Bend and great photo ops. But there are also many hikes and opportunities to get out into the outdoors including the boat at Jenny Lake. Don't miss the Rockefeller Nature Preserve as well.

I have to admit that I didn't expect much for this spot. I knew this mountain is famous because it's the logo of Paramount Movie. Doesn't sound too interesting to me though. However when I personally saw the view, I have to say it's really worth of the time and effort to get there. It's the view that you'd really want to show your family and friends. It's a must-see!

Beautiful! God's country. Spectacular views. Lots of wild animals to see. I had no idea what to expect and we actually saw more animals here then in Yellowstone. The view of the mountains is amazing no matter where you are in the park. We used a tour guide one day to show us where to find the wildlife and that was very helpful. We will be back again.
Liked everything! this is a "bucket list" destination. Endless things to do and see. Lots of wildlife.
We stayed at Lizard Creek and Gros Ventre Campgrounds, which were clean, hosts helpful and animals abound. We could easily drive to Colter Bay where we could pay to take a clean shower.
review_title: So many grand adventures and campgrounds

review_body: It is absolutely one of the most beautiful places I have ever been. We hiked several trails. We went to Jenny Lake and had lunch and did more hiking.

This place is a special place! There are so many things to see and do! I don't have enough time to talk about everything. Spectacular mountains, awesome hiking trails, unbelievable wildlife encounters, beautiful streams! This place is breathtaking! If you love the outdoors you need to put this place on the top of your bucket list!
Everything: the views, the mountain picks, the valleys, the rivers and the lakes, the Jackson lodge and everything it offers, the wildlife, even the Park rangers!

The best way to see the beautiful mountains is to wait for the sunset somewhere around Jackson Lake and in my case, Jackson Lake Lodge. The view is awesome, breathtaking, actually there is no words that properly can describe it. It just blows your mind.

I absolutely loved Grand Teton National Park, its natural beauty was breathtaking. I entered from Jackson Hole and carried on through into Yellowstone, although I do prefer the natural beauty of the Tetons over Yellowstone, but if you drive through both you get the best of everything.
The Tetons were absolutely Ah~May~Zing. So Majestic! They take your breath away. Every turn you take. Looks like Picture Post Cards. This is a must see

After a day of frustration and minor disappointments in Yellowstone, the Tetons and Jackson Hole were truly " the remedy." The rude and inconsiderate behaviour we encountered ALL day in Y'stone gave way to better roads, (without ignorant people blocking them) magnificent viewsand none of the "me first" tourist attitude of previous wasted days in Y'stone. There arel plenty of lakes and great riding roads and lots of wildlife. Having skied the area before, we were anxious to visit in the summer, and we were not disappointed. Grand Teton more made up for our bad experiences in Y'stone as we continued on our way to Bonneville, Tahoe, Yosemite and the west Coast.

My wife and I had a wedding to attend in this beautiful part of the country Labor Day week-end. We stayed in Teton Village/Ski resort. This is off season according to locals but late Summer and Fall are great times to visit the area. The mountains are spectacular with lots of picture opportunities and the wildlife are abundant. Elk, Moose, Deer and Buffalo are what we saw most of. We had deer and moose come to the place we we're staying. The only complaint was no AC and it got pretty warm during the day(80s mostly). At night the temp would drop to 40s mostly. One day we took a trip to Yellowstone and went around the inner loop. We'll have to go back when we can stay two weeks to see all of Yellowstone. Jackson Hole is a unique city with lots of shops, art galleries and bars. There's lots of other things to do in the area like hot air balloon rides and para-sailing from the top of the ski resort. Great trip.
review_title: Short visit to Jackson Hole WY

review_body: just go is all I can say-they are awe inspiring especially from Jenny Lake Lodge resort -Saw pronghorn antelope, bison, mule deer male & female; aww but no bear oh well still fabulous pictures

The mountains and hiking trails are spectacular. The crowds are a little better here than Yellowstone and the scenery and picture taking is awesome. All of the rangers are very helpful and knowledgeable. The weather couldn't have been better and the wild life is diverse and plentiful.
B E a U-tiful and nice campgrounds, scenery was excellent and relaxing. lots of hiking and Biking trails to enjoy away from cars and close to nature

The Tetons and and the surrounding area are truly some of God's finest creations. We thoroughly enjoyed our time there. It was fairly crowded and camping was a bit difficult to find. However, it was worth it! A wonderful place.

This is a great family destination with amazing views, plenty of wildlife and a lot of outdoor activities including hiking and kayaking. We spent two days in the park and wish that we dedicated more time as there's so much to see.

On a recent road trip, we drove through most of Wyoming. I have to say that most of the state can best be described as desolate, mostly uninhabited and not very welcoming for a road-weary traveler. Shortly after leaving Jackson, however, we arrived at Grand Tetons National Park. What an amazing place. Majestic, breath-taking, and awe-inspiring are certainly appropriate descriptors but they fall short of expressing just how incredibly this place is. In addition to the "GRAND" mountains and natural scenery, the wildlife was abundant and such a treat to see in the wild. We felt like we were truly given a refreshing respite after hours and hours and hours of driving through "nothingness." Truly an oasis for us. I will definitely be back!

Spent 5 days in Teton Village in Grand Teton National Park. Words cannot truly express the beauty of these mountains. Truly spectacular. Early one morning as we were traveling to Yellowstone, the amazing sight of the Tetons was breathtaking, and the herds of bison, moose and antelope. The view of Jackson Hole and the Snake River from the top of the Tetons was a sight to behold. Haven't experienced anything like it. I believe I enjoyed exploring Teton National Park more than Yellowstone.
The mountain views are amazing. Lots of wildlife, and if you know the secret roads, your visit will amaze.

The park service really could do a better job at having enough parking and signage for parking (RV vs. cars). Several cars were blocking RVs in. They really should take a key from Yellowstone and have it better organized. However the mountains are wonderful, so we will take the flaws and enjoy the beauty.
review_title: Beautiful, but get there early to find parking and hope you don't get blocked in

review_body: Visited many years ago when the snow was still on the peaks even in the summer. This summer, barely any snow on the peaks so not as beautiful as it can be in the winter. Still an impressive mountain range anyway.

The park is easily accessible from Jackson Hole, and there are lots of pull outs to safely and easily take in the breathtaking views (and take photos of course). Even though the visitor centers were very busy, the staff managed beautifully and we were served in a timely manner. Don't miss this gem if you're in the area.
review_title: Excellent visitor centers, staff, & AMAZING views!

review_body: Just a short drive out of Yellowstone and you will be in Grand Teton! The mountains are breathtaking! There was actually cell phone service at the Signal Mountain Summit drive! There is a tower up there and I was able to connect FINALLY after 3 days of no contact (not much in the parks). The mountains make me feel soooooo insignificant! The beauty is almost too much to take in!

Amazing scenery and wildlife. The only bad part of this trip was the roadwork delays. Take your time and drive the back roads early in the morning. You'll see more animals closer to the road, and you'll also see some spectacular sunrises.

We toured the park and enjoyed the various pull outs and tourist stops. Enjoyed a walk along Jenny Lake - lots of photo opps. Enjoyed a beautiful sunset as the sun went down behind the Tetons. Enjoyed a wonderful meal of trout and eggs at Nora's.

Touring out of Jackson Hole on the Jenny Lake Loop drive. Clear, quiet lakes, waterfalls and unparalleled views of the snow capped mountains. We drove the longer route coming through Teton Village to avoid road construction in Jackson Hole and the highway to Yellowstone. This added some pristine wilderness tour our loop tour. A stop at Jenny Lake lodge for some excellent scenic pictures and some western hospitality by the fire really made our day. This loop can be done in a few short hours but should not be missed when you are in the area.

Should have spent more time in the Tetons and less in Yellowstone. If you like hiking - go here. It's so beautiful. The Tetons have a presence I can't articulate. The Lakes are clear and peaceful. Plus you're close to one of them most beautiful drives in the US - Beartooth Highway.

Grand Teton National Park took our breath away. Photos do not begin to give full justice - We had no idea how beautiful the region is. We were so happy to spend 2 days in the area and wished we could stay longer. There is plenty to do -We started each day at the lodge watching the local wildlife start their day on the plain. We floated on the Snake River and were treated to a moose and her calf on the water's edge. Hiked some of the beautiful trails (although had to turn back due to bear activity).Went into Jackson Hole and enjoyed this town.We hope to get back here again 1 day soon!

And the mountains are worth viewing from the other side. The lakes are spectacular and the water is clear. The lodge has a spectacular view of the mountains. If you are lucky you might witness someone catching a bat and taking the critter outside.

So very different from Yellowstone National Park, yet not so very far away! Gorgeous drives through the park, lovely mountains and some fun hikes. Be sure to take the boat across Jenny Lake for the views and the cool splash of the water as you go across!
Beautiful, rugged mountains. I've seen the Great Smoky Mtns and the Rocky Mtns in CO, but the Grand Tetons are the most beautiful mountain range I've ever experienced.

This was always on the list of places to see. It was worth the drive through Yellowstone park out the south entrance. The classic view of Grand Teton and the lake with the mountainside reflected in it are a wonderful memory . I was visiting friends in Bozeman and made the trip there and back.

The Grand Tetons mountain range are beautiful and rugged. Go to the park. Go to Jenny Lake and take the hour boat ride. The ranger that gives the tour will tell you about how the park came to be and the intrepid explorers of the area. Worth price of admission!!

We've all seen the photos. They don't capture it. Jackson Hole and Grand Tetons are one of those places where nature conspired to produce a landscape that leaves the viewer breathless, deprived of words. Enough said.
One of the great parks with awesome wildlife. Swimming in string lake was a blast. Make a day of it so you get the chance to see the park and all the wildlife
user_location: New York, New York, United States

review_body: Planyour trip ahead of time. There's so much to do, and don't forget to take a raft ride on the Snake River!

Grand Teton came highly recommended. Maybe my expectations were too high. I saw nothing I have not seen before and find the scenery very average. Saw no animals but that might be just my bad luck. Rather use the extra time on Yellowstone.
Amazing scenery with an abundance of wildlife. Lots to see and do very quiet in May which was great!

This is one of the most beautiful places I've ever been. These mountains are totally gorgeous. I think you have to experience it, because pics don't do it justice. It's such a majestic, serene place. I hope to return someday

Loved everything about this place from the camping to wild life! so much to do and see that there is not much down time! I would have to have several pages to talk about everything there is to do so just research plenty and plan your time! Be crazy not to love it!
review_title: Most beautiful mountains I have ever seen!

review_body: I'm here in mid-August, and there still weren't too may people. Almost half were not Americans either. Why are we missing out on this place?? For viewing, go to 'Jenny Lake' first. Then try Jackson Lake. Try a boat rental on either if you can. No really. Think you can't do that? It's so easy and the tour guides will easily take 5 minutes to show you the way to do it. You'll then be hooked, though.PS. Outboard boat rentals? In Glacier NP, I was showed the ropes for a couple of minutes, and know how to do something I never thought I wish I knew how to do. Cost $25/hour there. Great deal . Learning to use a Moped would be harder.Jackson Lake is larger, but the views won't be quite as good as Jenny Lake. They may have more boating opportunities though, while still having great views.Of what I've seen, and we tried most USA West vistas, this is up there with a few top places here. Like Zion/Bryce, Globe-Showlow (AZ), Glacier NP's 'Going to the Sun road", Grand Canyon/Royal Gorge (seen from the Bottom/river, via raft, rail, or mule), Silverton-Ouray (CO) narrow gauge rail or drive, and there are many more.
review_title: Excellent Park. Not too crowded. "USA Alps", type place.

review_body: Wonderful National Park to visit. We went in August and the weather was amazing. Jackson is a beautiful town to visit and Jackson Lake is one of the best in the country.

Very gorgeous place to visit and you dont need a lot time to visit it. there is the option to do a bunch of trails and backcountry camping. Biker friendly. The Teton NP has lots of info about the park and is very scenic!

We spent a week hiking the Tetons, and loved every minute. We stayed at a condo in the Aspenwood complex near Jackson Hole ski area- and it was more convenient to most of the hiking than the town of Jackson Hole. We are in our mid 60's but in very good physical shape and we were able to enjoy most of the hiking labeled easy to moderate. Best tip is to NOT be afraid of hikes label difficult, as the first hour or so of these hikes is across beautiful terrain with marvelous views. Once you get to the base of the Tetons, tackling the ravines is for a different class of hiker than we are :) There are two very good ranger stations that can provide maps, advice, and some good orientation movies. Would advise packing lunch and LOTS of water - there are few places to buy provisions, and the altitude really dehydrates you more quickly that we generally experience. Early/mid June had beautiful weather, and not too many people yet - a good time to come.

This National Park is such a treasure! The views and wildlife are amazing and there are so many great trails available for hikers of all ages and abilities. We took the Death Canyon trail with our 10 and 12 year old daughters up to the Phelps Lake overlook and then down to the lake for a swim. The round-trip hike was moderate and probably about 4 miles round-trip. Perfect family hike!
rather concentrated in one place. Quite cool in the summer time. many hiking trails and places to visit. Great for family. downside is that it is quite expensive to find a place to stay.
review_title: great place to visit. one of the best national parks.

review_body: After three days in Yellowstone, we headed to the Grand Teton Natl. Park and started seeing the real beauty and wildlife. It was less crowded (Though Jackson Wyoming was very crowded). We saw moose here, lots of elk, and generally more wildlife than we saw in Yellowstone. We found this to have better visitor centers than Yellowstone, better roads, and better scenery. And the scenery was amazing. Moose can be seen early morning along the Gros Ventre river northwest of the Gros Ventre Junction. I'm sure they are other places, but that is where we saw them. We found the Morman row to be very picturesque. We also loved the amazing Craig Thompson visitor center at Moose. You have to go there for sure. When you go to a visitor center, ask them for the driving tour. It is well worth it to get their suggestions. One place we almost didn't go to was the chapel of the transfiguration. We found that to be beautiful. I strongly recommend this park. The mountains are unlike any I've ever seen.

Lakes, Mountains, hikes, wild life, scenic drives.. this has everything you need for a vis-a-vis with nature. We had memorable trip.. If you are planning to visit Yellowstone, do not forget to visit this as well.. This is as good as, if not better than, yellowstone in terms of natural beauty. Less crowd, of course.
Boat on Jenny lake, cascade canyon trail, string lake trail, christian ponds trail, chapel of transfiguration, jackson lake, moose wilson road.

If Yellowstone did not have the geothermal attractions Grand Tetons would easily beat it in terms of sheer beauty. The majestic peaks rising behind the lake was a sight to behold. There are various look out points along the road including one with the snake river in front.Wish we had more time to explore this park.
What a great ride through some beautiful country! If you are up in Jackson take the time to ride through this beautiful park. You will not regret it!!!!

A totally unexpected gem of a park, wasnt even on our list to do but having saved a day travelling we decided to spend a day here before heading up to Yellowstone and so glad that we did as it was by far the most beautiful park (view wise) that we visited on our trip.Fantastic views of the snow capped mountains behind the lake from almost everywhere and the lake itself had lovely walks and picnoc areas along the side of it.
review_title: The most scenic park we visited in our 5 week tour

review_body: We drove down every road, did a few easy hikes. We could not taking pictures. The visitor center in Moose is wonderful, and exibits and view of the Tetons are breathtaking

We like that Yellowstone and Grand Teton NP are in the same area. We planned to first spend most of our time in Yellowstone, then a short time in GTNP. While at GTNP, we decided to add another day to our trip. We found a hotel in Dubois, WY, which is about 1hr. from the park. Besides capturing amazing scenes with our camera, canoeing on Lake Jackson was the highlight of our short time in GTNP. The Marina at the visitor center rents canoes and kayaks. Because of the little traffic in GTNP, compared with the heavy traffic at Yellowstone, we decided that when we return to these parks, we will camp at GTNP.

I think this could be my favorite place I have ever been in the US. The views are absolutely breathtaking, the air is so clear, it smells amazing - I love everything about this place! The weather was great - it was in the 70s every day we were there in July. The wildlife was amazing - we saw a moose, some elk, deer, and even a grizzly bear. The scenic overlooks are great - each one you stop at boasts another breathtaking panorama. It's unlike anything I have ever seen! I think my favorite overlook was the Cascade Canyon one. This trip was life-changing and I can't wait to go back!
review_title: Nothing I say about this place can compare to how amazing it is.

review_body: Amazing views and wildlife opportunities. Hiking and biking trails. Camping. Park admission good for seven days and includes Yellowstone admission too. A must see!

I'm a fan of views that combines high mountains and lake scenery. following reviews here we did the walk to inspiration point- very rewarding. and continued a while on the cascade canyon trail- were we saw a male Moss - so kids were very satisfied.did also the scenic drive to signal point- nice views. NO RV allowed- in case you're planning on it...Very recommended park!
I love the Tetons. There are so many views and I love them all. My one word for the Tetons is majestic.

We visited the Grand Tetons as part of a 13-night Globus bus tour from Rapid City to Las Vegas. Before the trip, everyone I know who had seen the Tetons had raved about their unbelievable beauty and majesty, and so I had high expectations going in and was not the least bit disappointed. The youngest of the Rocky Mountain chain, the Tetons stand out for their glacial, angular peaks still snow-capped in mid-summer laid out before a pair of pristine lakes and the Snake River -- their stark shadows clearly visible in the waters that lie at their feet. We had two very different opportunities to view the Tetons -- from afar and up close at several lookout points and from the Lodge where we enjoyed lunch while on our way to Jackson; and the next morning on a float trip along the Snake River. Visiting the Tetons, even in these ways, did not grow tiring; it was hard to take your eyes off these majestic mountains and cast them elsewhere.There's only a couple of places to stay or eat in the Park itself; with close proximity to Jackson, it's probably best to stay there and spend time in the Grand Teton National Park as a day trip or two.

The Grand Tetons have to be the most photographable place in North America just from the road! Sharp peaks just 'over there' that are awesome in every meaning of the word. Nothing gets in the way of your view except maybe a grazing elk, or moose in the meandering river. Hiking, climbing, exploring, eating, meditating, all inspired by the views.

We flew into Jackson Hole, WY and drove to up to Yellowstone National Park. On the way, we drove through Grand Teton National Park. What a beautiful drive!!! There are incredible vistas and wildlife everywhere along the road. We also stopped in Moose, WY at the visitors center...definitely worth a look. If you are planning on traveling to see Yellowstone, highly recommend taking the time to drive through and see the Grand Tetons!!

We actually visited in 2011 but just getting around to sharing. Well worth the trip. Amazing views! Awesome! I can not say enough about this place!! I do hope to go back some time soon to spend more time taking the beauty in. The drive in from the West (Idaho) is great. Steep drop down into Wilson but he views form the top are spectacular! If visiting Yellowstone, this is must see.

The Rockies get all the press, but the Tetons are much more beautiful. Sit in a canoe on Jenny Lake and marvel at the vista. The Trois Tetons are exquisite. The mountains rise directly out of the high plains with few foothills to detract from their drama. Their proximity to the beautiful Snake River yields an incomparably breathtaking combination.
review_title: The Rockies get all the press, but . . .

review_body: I was not prepared for the visual assault I received when I got to the Grand Teton's. We went in early June and the snow was still bright on the peaks. After driving from Minnesota through the Badlands to Rushmore and Devil's Tower, through Big Horn Mountain.....I had no idea of the beauty and size of the Teton's.There are several pull overs all along the park from Yellowstone down to Jackson, WY. Take advantage of the different places you can stop and see it from a different angle. Take advantage of the smaller roads in the National Park where you can see all forms of wildlife. A slow drive, but beautiful.

The Tetons are one of the most beautiful places I have ever been and there isn't much that compares in sheer beauty and serenity. I have been visiting the Tetons for almost 30 years and each year I love coming back and enjoying the scenery and park. I feel like I'm stepping back in time here at the Tetons as the park hasn't changed much in over 30 years. It doesn't get much better if you love the mountains, lakes and wildlife.

Definitely worth adding the extra day. These sharp peaks 'appear' out of nowhere as you drive north on the highway and into the vast valley below them. It is hard not to find a great view on any point along either of the two highways going north. The Craig Thomas Visitor Center has excellent displays and is a must-see before you explore further in the park.

It may not have the geysers but it has the wildlife and far, far less people. The mountain scenery outshines its bigger brother and it is altogether a more relaxing experience. We saw larger herds of bison, elk and pronghorn here as well as a moose - most of which have apparently moved south to GTNP. Take the Wilson- Moose road at dusk for a chance to see these animals, Bear also sighted in the same area. The view from the top of Signal Mountain (you can drive up) is stunning and you can watch elk move across the grasslands below. Some interesting old buildings as well to be viewed at Mormon Row.

We stopped at GTNP during a cross-country trip in the summer of 2012. The park was less busy than Yellowstone and the beauty was breath taking. GTNP offers tremendous hiking. We ended our trip with an upscale dinner at the Mural room at sunset. A perfect ending to our visit to GTNP

There's no other mountain range like this in the continental US!As the youngest mountains they have the sharpest peaks!As you drive through the park they are constantly in view.Lots of interpretive pull overs to enjoy the views.Just stand in awe in front of them and breath in the clean, fresh air!It's good for the soul!

This is one of the best places i have ever been to. Being at the valley of the great mountain range offers unique views. the rivers and lakes provide awesome reflections early in the morning, chance to see wild life etc etc makes this one of my favorite places.I am photography enthusiast, this place made my endeavor perfect!!! given a chance, I will go back

My husband, son, and I hiked around Phelps Lake and took some random off-shoot trails, including Death Canyon, for an amazing 12 mile hike. It was incredible. We saw wildlife and were alone for most of the hike. All of the trails are clearly marked, and you are really out in the wild, which is what we wanted. We heard about Jenny Lake, but for us that was just too crowded. You don't have to hike for 6 hours like we did, and can make it a shorter hike if you want. If you don't like crowds and want to see some incredible landscape, this is the hike for you!

After enduring Yellowstone at the busiest gaper time of the year, Grand Teton felt like a more natural and relaxed National Park. In my opinion, the scenery is more impressive too. The Teton Range views are incredible. There's so much to do but one of the highlights of our trip was renting a boat from Signal Mountain and spending an hour or two cruising Jackson Lake. After a hike, reward yourself with a cocktail on the deck of the Blue Heron at the Jackson Lake Lodge. The backdrop is unbelievable!
Wonderful national Park. We enjoyed the slow drive through the park. Views of the Grand Tetons are great.

This park should definitely be on your bucket list for it's outstanding beauty! In just a couple of days you can enjoy hiking, canoeing, and seeing lots of wildlife. We were lucky enough to see a grizzly cub, moose and bison on our trip. In addition hiking to Inspiration point,I would recommend renting a canoe at Doran's and taking it over to String lake for a great day on the water (and be sure to go for a swim here).
review_title: Spectacular scenery from every vantage point!

review_body: Beautiful wherever you gazed. The Tetons have everything and a must for visitors out west. The views are remarkable.

I've been flying out to the Tetons for the last 14 years for family vacations. We've never been disappointed, always have plenty to do, see lots of animals, have great hikes and overall have a blast.Don't be afraid to ask around for good hikes or photo locations. Many of them aren't advertised heavily, and it can take a little research to track them down, but they are there.People are friendly and traffic isn't too bad (unless you hit some dreaded road construction). Don't count on getting cheap food, but there are some decent places to eat.
review_title: Without a doubt, my favorite location for a vacation

review_body: Took the bus tour from Yellowstone. Took a whole 8-9 hours for the trip. Stopped at just about every overlook from Jackson Lake to Meanor's Ferry. Had lunch at Moose Junction with outside dining and a great view of the mountains. A must see.

Only was able to spend one day here, but it was gorgeous! A waitress at The Lift in Jackson recommended taking the boat trip across Jenny Lake and then hiking to Hidden Falls. It made for a perfect one day visit! Be sure to wear good hiking shoes, bring lots to drink, and your camera! Trekking poles were also helpful - especially if you have wonky knees, like I do!

We are 2 adults, 2 kids, 10 and 11. We visited Grand Teton NP, Jackson Hole, WY and found a place for $100/nt at the Hostel in Teton Village, saved alot by staying there. We arranged to eat our breakfast at the hostel (an old ski lodge-from Olympic trials or? .. it seems), and ate dinner we prepared there. Saved alot of money, saw incredible animals, did alot of hiking, went to top of Jackson Hole Ski Resort (a little spendy but well worth it). the Hostel was pretty sparse, it had small bathrooms, the rooms were narrow, dark, with only one window, might be some dust in the corners, no desks or swimming pool here, but they were comfy. It had bunk beds, the floors creak --creaks alot, a large rec room in basement with a large frig for all to keep their groceries (all were labelled) and rec room included a toaster, a microwave, lots of tables and a tv, a ping pong table, and more games that i can imagine, a table just for checkers and chess. OK..it wasn't the Marriott, but neither were the prices. Alot of younger college age kids working at the place, my kids made friends with some at the front desk, and they liked their dog Cinch. I saw quite a few families, and older couples who look like they were in good shape and maybe retired but saving money while visiting the area, also saw plenty of Foreigners who know how to stay in hostels. Grand Teton NP is just up the road from the hostel, as well as Jackson Hole which has a cute historic downtown- our kids did a stagecoach ride, short and sweet for $4/each, and check out the Million Dollar Cowboy Bar, too. We did alot of hiking in Grand Teton, ate lots of PBnJ sandwiches, baby carrots, string cheese, beefsticks, and always brought our own water bottles. Loved this area!!
review_title: Grand Teton NP, Jackson Hole, stay in Teton Village @the Hostel- if on a budget!

review_body: Stunning, spectacular, amazing...there's really not enough superlatives to describe the pristine beauty of this place. Take the time to stop in the visitor center to get information, maps, etc. the bathrooms are cleaned and well maintained, the staff are super helpful and there's also a nice gift shop. Take it all in! You'll be glad you did!!
review_title: A must for your bucket list!

review_body: Fewer crowds, a nicer drive, wonderful views. I do suggest that you get a guidebook to this national park otherwise you might miss a few of the hidden treasures. A pair of high powered binoculars with a tripod would enhance the experience as some of the views are pretty far away.
review_title: This was a pleasant change of pace after Yellowstone

review_body: Just finished a day long tour of the park. Our favorite spot was Jenny Lake with the boat ride to the Hidden Falls. Be sure to take water and good hiking shoes. Lots of turn-outs to stop and take photos and just soak in the views of the mountains. We also rode the tram at Teton Village, which is a must do when visiting the park. Be sure to take water and a coat as the weather can change quickly. Fantastic visit, I so glad we made the long drive from Kansas.

Grand Teton had been on my list of parks I wanted to visit for a long time. I am so happy we included it in our trip to Wyoming. It is a fairly small park, so you can see and do much of the park in a visit of a few days. Except for the hike to Hidden Falls, which you can get to by boat, so it attracts a lot of people, most of the trails were very quiet and we saw few other people. We stayed in Teton Village just outside the "back" entrance to the park, so we were able to get into the park very quickly. Great hikes, beautiful scenery and lots of animals--elk, deer, moose. We saw several beaver dams, but no beavers.

We visited the National Park and the Grand Tetons cannot be adequately described or shown in pictures. It is truly stunning. From the first view of the mountain range visitors will be impressed with the beauty of the place. We took the ferry at Jenny Lake across to the Jenny Lake trail head. We then hiked up to Hidden Falls and Inspiration Point. Those are .5 and 1.0 miles from the ferry landing respectively. The trail was pretty busy all the way up. Once we were past Inspiration Point the number of hikers dropped of to very few. We proceeded all the way up Cascade Canyon to the crossing and then took the trail toward Lake Solitude. Due to the lateness of the day we only got about a mile up that trail (just past the tree line) before we needed to turn back to catch the last ferry back across the lake. Our total distance was just about 11 miles. The ferry is $16 per person and if I recall a good bit less for seniors. Veterans can take it at no charge. The last ferry is at 7pm but if you miss it you can hike the trail around Lake Jenny which will add 2 miles to your total hiking for the day.The views were spectacular. The trail ranges between moderate and strenuous; with most of it being moderate in terms of difficulty. Along the way we saw moose, deer and marmots and fortunately no bear; although we saw bear scat on the trail. Hiking in the Tetons is quite safe provided you have good boots, lots of water and carry bear spray with you. Bear spray is an absolute necessity. It runs about $40 for a canister, which may seem expensive until you stumble upon a grizzly or black bear. Then it can seem pretty cheap! Bear encounters are pretty rare but if you are one of those rare occurrences you will be glad that you have it. Traveling in a group is also a great idea because the noise of several folks can spook a bear out of the way. I wouldn't hike alone in the Tetons (or Yellowstone for that matter). Seeing the Tetons from the base on the east side or west side is quite impressive. Hiking up for a closer view is and experience that is rewarding for first time or many time visitors. If you love the outdoors, impressive natural views, running mountain streams, wildlife and nourishment for your soul, the Grand Tetons are for you!

Took a day and drove to this park, the views of the Tetons on the Lakes is unbelievable beautiful. Must go to Jenny Lake and take the ferry to the other side and hike up to Hidden Falls. Not for the weak or timid so be prepared for a short but strenuous hike. But it is worth it.

travelled through the tetons on the way to Jackson hole. took some fantastic photos. Passed the lakes, some lovely mirror images. Snow capped mountains, impressive. Grand teton shows well above the other peeks.

Have you ever been to heaven? Well right now I think I'm there. Around every turn and the steep inclined roads there is a beautiful mountain vista to stare at in awe. when we hit the Continental divide at 9500 feet above sea level the view was just jaw dropping. Its July and the temperature went from 76 degrees to 43 degrees just by reaching 5000 more feet above sea level. the air smells of pine and sagebrush. I never want to leave. Never!
Fantastic view, must see, awesome. The Rockefeller Resturant  is good, take your Time, see this, close to Jackson Hole Wy, nice town, nice drive into ID, Bear Lake, on the Utah, Idaho, border.

Since we were staying at West Yellowstone we thought it would be great to take a full day and travel the 42 mile loop in the Grande Tetons and as much else as we could fit into a day. It was about 3 and 1/2 hours to Jackson where we entered the park at Moose and traveled a rough road a few miles until we it turned to pavement. Stopped at the Visitors and then headed up the Grand Teton Park Road stopping at Jenny Lake, Signal Mtn,and Willow Flats. By this time it was clear the loop would have to wait for another day and we continued on to Colter Bay and then to the south entrance to Yellowstone. Nine hours well spent in a most beautiful National Park which is very different from Yellowstone. I would recommend others who plan a similar trip to stay over a night and break the trip up over two days. We stopped and took pictures at all of the turnouts, so that added to the time. Used our senior pass.

This was just so awesome! We hiked the Grand Teton Mountains. The wonderful thing is that they have hiking trails for the amateurs and for the most skilled hikers. We hiked the easiest trail and the mountains were so picturesque and beautiful! I loved it!
I was speechless....The mountain is breath taking....This is a good place for photography enthusiasts. It's a nice drive all trough out the park.
The roads in the tetons were so well maintained, pleasant people throughout the park, the food in the eateries were priced well and you always had lots of choices of places to stop off and explore
We chose to rent a canoe to row Lake Jenny. We thoroughly enjoyed it. We also enjoyed hiking trails around the lake.

This is a stunning national park, and a less hectic alternative to Yellowstone. I found it to be extremely easy to get around, and the signage was very good. I also liked that there were multiple places to eat and stay within the park. I'm only rating it a 4 instead of a 5 because I felt like even though the scenery was gorgeous, I felt like I could only spend a limited amount of time here due to the park's lack of diversity. If I had been a rock climber or such I would have had more to do, but for hiking I felt like I was seeing similar things after a couple of days.

Beautiful park. Loved the mountains and wildlife. Smaller than Yellowstone, so you don't spend all day driving to get to something.Close to Jackson, if you need anything. This city has it all. Take the boat or hike to Hidden Falls, accross Jenny Lake (and inspiration point, if you are up to it). Well worth the 4 hours (we hiked half and road back on the boat). The mountains are majestic.
review_title: Gorgeous park, and close to Jackson

review_body: We're hiking the top 20 National Park hikes, and this one was in Grand Teton. Take the Jenney Lake ferry from the east to west side. It's $12 per person, but saves 2 miles of hiking around the lake (free for military!). Hike .7 miles to the waterfall, and then another .3 miles to Inspiration Point. Many people turn around here, but don't! It's another 6 miles up Cascade Canyon to Lake Solitude, but well worth the moderate hike. We saw bear, moose, marmots, etc. along the way, all the while enjoying countless waterfalls and rushing water from the melting glaciers.
review_title: Grand Teton Top 20 hikes in National Parks

review_body: We drove through and past many miles of the snow capped Tetons through and beyone Yellowstone National Park. Yellowstone Lake shows them in its background and it is quite a sight. Any route that takes you past these mountains is worth it.
cool little airport,great car rental service,stayed in Teton village for 4 nights,visited Jackson daily for restaurants and hanging out with family. Enjoyed the great scenic land scape and hikes

This Nat'l Park is a gem and you can easily see it inna day. The mountains are awe-inspiring - Galcial (---I never knew that!) We learned so much.Our warming trends are really compromising this Range......
review_title: Don't skip this Park - it is a gem

review_body: After traveling through the Rockies, visiting both Yellowstone and Glacier and then also the Canadian Rockies--the Tetons remain my very favorite! Their beauty is beyond compare! Jenny Lake and all views and vistas among the most magnificent in my opinion! Love this area!
A trip thru the Grand Teton National park is soooo worth it! Wyoming is such beautiful country. Stop by in Jackson, Wy for a taste of a true western town if heading back West to California.

On your way to Yellowstone National Park, you must stop and visit Grand Teton National Park as well. Its south of Yellowstone NP and has, in my opinion, beautiful relaxing lakes to visit and to hike to. the short hike to Lake Leigh is well worth it.
We thoroughly enjoyed our visit to The Grand Teton Park. So many things to do if you like the outdoors. Gorgeous views of the mountains. Will come back.
review_title: Fabulous park area with lots of hiking trails.

review_body: We were in the Grand Teton National Park for four nights after our 8 night trip to Yellowstone. We loved it. It was beautiful. We were there from June 26th to June 30th and the wild flowers were in abundance.I want to thank BlueBirdDay and PeachBelle for all their suggestions and the help they gave me to plan our trip to the Tetons. The rugged mountain range was beautiful. We followed the Park Map supplied by the Grand Teton National Park Service and covered most of the sites pointed on the map. Stayed at the Signal Mountain Lodge for 4 nights. 1st day took a drive to the Signal Mountain Summit. It was a beautiful drive with good lookout points and the top of the summit was beautiful with wild flowers in abundance. Drove on the main road south towards Jenny Lake and took the one way road to Jenny Lake overlook and then to the Jenny Lake visitor center. Parking was full. Had to change plans. Drove to Laurance Rockefeller Preserve. Waited not too long to get a parking spot and hiked to Phelps Lake.Unfortunately weather turned out to be in the mid 80's and it was just a little warm for the hike. Also visited Craig Thomas Discovery and Visitor Center.2nd day got early to Jenny Lake Visitor Center and took the boat across Jenny Lake and hiked up to the Hidden Falls and Inspiration Point and covered some of the points of interest on the Park Map.3rd day took a hike to Taggart Lake, beautiful place with the Teton Range in the background. The trail was not too crowded as we went early being worried that we would not get a parking place. After the hike went to Teton Village in Jackson and took the tram to the top of Rendezvous mountain. On our way saw a glimpse of a moose. It was worth the trip even though the ticket was a little pricey. $26.00 per person. Views were amazing. We had waffles at Corbet's Cabin. They were yummy with butter and brown sugar in between. Visited Jackson Lake Lodge and viewed the Lake from their Mural Room. We also had great views of Jackson Lake from the Signal Mountain Lodge.Had a great 4 night stay in the Tetons. The day we left we had a beautiful view from the Oxbow Bend Turnout. It is a beautiful place for photo opportunities with the reflection of the Tetons in the Snake River. Snake River Overlook is also a good place to take pictures. Took a drive over Antelope Flats road and took some photos of the Mormon Row and took the loop to Kelly and got back on the main road. Plenty of wildflowers. A few bison.

We spent 2-3 driving through the park and found it difficult to spot wildlife. We did finally encounter the moose several times, both mom, calves and bull moose. The scenery is gorgeous with the mountains. 2 days in the park is plenty of time is you are just driving around and seeing wildlife. Highly recommend crossing Jenny Lake and taking hike to Inspiration Point.
review_title: Pretty Park, Wildlife Hard to Spot

review_body: If you are visiting Yellowstone, be sure to drive another 90 minutes to Jackson Hole, Wyoming and see the Tetons. Their rugged beauty will take your breath away. It is smaller than Yellowstone, but it still packs a punch for activities and hiking. Your Yellowstone pass will get you into the Tetons for free. Be sure to see Jenny Lake, Inspiration Point, and Lake Taggart. If you are more of a hiking enthusiast, Amphitheater Lake will leave you breathless (literally). You have a 3,500 feet change of elevation in about 4 miles. Keep going because the pay off is worth it. Be warne that the trail will be covered with snow in higher elevations even into mid June. Just follow the footprints ahead of you. Be sure to pack plenty of water. My girlfriend and I LOVED the Tetons.
review_title: Just a stone's throw from Yellowstone.

review_body: If you are going to Yellowstone DO NOT miss the Grand Tetons. We enjoyed our trip to Yellowstone but LOVED the Grand Tetons. Jenny Lake was beautifully clear and hiking in the mountains was unforgettable. Also ride the Jackson Hole Tram for a fantastic panoramic view of the area

We visited the park in late June and spent two days there.
