I found the most pretty views of the Teton range to be from the following: the back of the Jackson Lake Lodge, the Jackson Lake itself while boating, the String Lake trailhead or the Leigh Lake trailhead, Snake River Overlook, the Park Road around the Taggart Lake trailhead, and the Oxbow Bend. We also got a great view of the mountains with a blanket of spring flowers from the main highway 2-3 miles north of the Moose Junction.
review_title: Beautiful views of the Teton range from different points in the Park!

review_body: It may be smaller than Yellowstone, but it is every bit as grand and beautiful. I love the lakes and the hiking trails. And I never get tired of looking at the mountains. Definitely worth many visits!

I travelled to Jackson, Wyoming to do some real hiking and bond-building with my 15 yr old son. We do some hiking back home in NC, but were looking for something a little more challenging. We found that and lots more! We started with a moderate hike around Jenny Lake and up to Hidden Falls and Inspiration. Immediately, we knew we were onto something special - the hike around Jenny Lake was beautiful - and then the Falls and Inspiration Point were amazing. The next day we decided to try a tougher hike - and so we selected the Garnet Canyon trail starting at Lupine Meadows Trailhead. The hike starts with mountain meadows in full bloom and keeps getting more rugged and beautiful the further you go. It is a strenuous hike, climbing over 2000 feet. About 2/3 of the way to Garnet Creek, you round a corner and are awestruck by the view of Middle Teton (see attached photo). We continued up to the creek crossing - and somewhere around 9000 feet we ran into snow and couldn't go further. We did some free rock climbing, took lots of pictures, had a well-deserved snack, and then started back down the mountain. It's definitely easier going back down! Overall, the hike was about 5-6 hrs and about 8.5 miles roundtrip.For our last hike, we decided to hike up into Death Canyon. This was also a very beautiful hike, along the way you get a great view of Phelps Lake. One bad thing is that after climbing about 500 ft, the trail goes back down towards the lake (dropping over 500 ft) before turning back upwards towards the mountains. It's tough to "give up" that hard earned altitude - but if you press on, it is worth it. About halfway up, the trail meets up with Death Canyon Creek and then follows the creek all the way up the valley. At around 8500 feet, the terrain flattens out (for awhile) and there is a ranger cabin and some flat water. From here, you can hike onwards higher up the canyon, but we decided to turn back. The walk back again was alot easier, but this time, there was some "unexpected" uphill - which just seemed wrong for the return trip! Overall, another great hike of about 6 hours and almost 8 miles.We initially thought about taking the Jackson Hole Tram up to the top and hiking down Granite Canyon, but there was still too much snow at the top and so we decided not to press our luck. Later in the year, I suspect this would be a terrific route of something like 10+ miles (but mostly downhill) with duration 6-7 hours.There are lots of traile we never made it too - and so we hope to make it back to explore those... but for the trails we did see, we rate GTNP a superstar!
review_title: More stunning around every next turn

review_body: We really loved our hike around the North end of Jenny Lake, up to Inspiration Point and on into Cascade Canyon. I recommend parking at the String Lake lot and hiking the North end if you prefer a less crowded hike. The parking lot is small, so I would get there early! We spent over 6 hours and hiked about 11 miles, taking frequent breaks and stopping for lunch. We had Bear spray, but never saw any bear, tho I have heard they are more abundant in July and August when the berries are ripe. We saw lots of marmots, a fisher, osprey and deer. The hike was not very difficult, tho the climb to Inspiration Point is a bit steep, but well worth it! We started very early in the morning and had only a few other hikers, but in the afternoon, it got crowded by the Ferry for the South end of Jenny Lake. There are many breath taking hikes in the Tetons! Cascade Canyon is relatively flat, following a stream between the Tetons, it is very beautiful, and you can go as far as you want, we only went a few miles before turning around.
review_title: Jenny Lake, Inspiration Point and Cascade Canyon

review_body: Grand Teton National Park is spectacular. The views are unbelievable with many auto pull outs along the roads. Didn't see any wildlife and that was disappointing but the mountains were glorious. The Rangers were a cut above other parks and the gift shop had many selections. A Post Office was walking distance away. A super place to visit.

Loved the park, the few animals that we saw (everyone said you don't see any animals anymore because the wolves have chased them off, bummer). But we did see a lot of cars and happy campers traveling thru. Jenny Lake was amazing, I could have spent the entire vacation right there, I'm happy to know that this park is preserved for all to see, just wish we could have seen some animals.
review_title: And this park belongs to us?

review_body: The views are SO beautiful and amazing!!! We took so many pictures so we can remember our trip forever. We left Jackson, Wyoming heading for Yellowstone and went to the Grand Teton Park. We had lunch in our car beside the National Elk Refuge and sat and watched wildlife. It seemed like we turned the corner in our car, and there were the mountains..... We just were speechless. They are so tall, and gorgeous. Breathtaking. We stopped at Jackson Lake for great pics along the drive. It was gorgeous. They have a $25 entrance fee which is also good for Yellowstone. Glad we were there and have this memory, everyone should see it.

Can never get enough of those views. I would love to wake up every morning looking at those mountains. They're unlike any mountains I've ever seen before. Yellowstone is awesome, but the Tetons are by far my favorite!
review_title: My Favorite Place in the Whole World!

review_body: In a nutshell, if you're gonna visit Jackson Hole and/or Yellowstone, exploring Grand Teton NP is a must-see, even for only a day or two... The mountain range has to be ranked as one of the most beautiful in the world---right up there with the Alps, Banff/Jasper and the Drakensberg.... Also, good for game watching, paddling, biking and hiking......

The stately and majestic peaks of the Tetons are breathtaking. Our first stop in the park was the Craig Thomas Discovery & Visitor Center to view exhibits on the park's geology and wildlife. There was a movie as well. We picked up maps and the park's newspaper. The park's newspaper has the most current road conditions showing road closings and repairs. Traveling through the park north on Hwy 191/26/89 there are various turnouts for views and picture taking.  When you reach Moran junction turn left to continue north on Hwy 89/191/287 passing Jackson Lake. Before reaching Jackson Lake Lodge you may want to take a short detour to Signal Mountain for great 360 degree views of the valley. Then you may grab a bite at the Jackson Lake Lodge if you wish. A bit further on at Colter Bay Village, there is an Indian Arts Museum. You can return by taking the road to the left to pass Jenny Lake stopping at the many turnouts for views of the Teton Range. Be alert for wildlife such as moose, elk, and pronghorns. Also you will see many water fowl by the lakes.The Jenny Lake Lodge is another great place to grab a meal. In fact, it's my favorite lodge in the park.The scenery in the park changes as you change your elevation.Most hikes in the park are all day or half day hikes. We toured mostly by car.If you a senior, the Lifetime pass for $10 is a great bargain and allows one other person in your vehicle to enter as well.

There are trails, lots of wildlife, a gift shop, Visitor's Center, and sites to see. I also recommend anyone visiting several sites in this area to purchase the National Parks Annual Pass for $80. It is good for a year and grants you free entrance at the National Park/Monument Sites. This place will take your breath away.

Teton offers awesome beauty on a scale unimaginable unless you have been there. It doesn't have the Geysers that make Yellowstone so special but it does have knockout scenery which rivals and if not betters that if Yellowstone. Make sure that you put a visit to Grand Teton on your agenda when visiting Yellowstone
review_title: If visiting Yellowstone then you must go here too

review_body: There is no way to describe the beauty of the Grand Tetons. They are so majestic it takes your breath away and just when you think it can't get any better it DOES! I fell in love with those mountains. Just couldn't get enough of the beauty of the area.

GTNP was beautiful and calm. It is covered with trees and snow. We had half a day in the park and it was not enough to see all. Two days should be good to see the whole park. The restaurant at the visitor center was great. We stayed at Jackson which is very nice.
One of the most gorgeous parks in the world! Many places to stay in the park. Great restaurants too!

My wife and I visited the area in May. There was still some snow on the ground and the lake was still frozen. Some of the turn arounds/parking areas were closed but the views were great. I would highly recommend a visit to the park. The visitors center was very nice and informative. Worth the trip. Would do it again.

We drove the highway from Jackson to Yellowstone early in the morning. This has to be one of the most beautiful stretches of road anywhere in the world. Sunrise on the peaks across the valley was quite breathtaking.

This was my first visit to this national park. We live in Oregon, with our own mountains and lakes, so I wasn't really expecting to be overwhelmed, but the peaks rising steeply above the lake filled valley were incredible. We spent most of one day exploring the roads and trails in the park, seeing bison and elk and taking hundreds of pictures.Very highly recommended!

So glad a friend told us to spend 2 days of our week visit to Yellowstone in Grand Teton. What a surprise! This must be one of the best kept secrets of America. A unique mountain range towering into the air right in front of you. Highly recommended.
I love this place. It is so beautiful. We were there in May and loved it. We saw a bear and her cubs, elk, pronghorn and so much more. Loved it so much!
These mountains are wonderful . The float trip was great. Not the greatest place for a person with a soft cast.
These gorgeous mountains are still growing into their adult shapes! Just an amazing place to take photos and wonder at nature's paintbrush!

We traveled here in May prior to Memorial Day Weekend to avoid the large crowds. We pretty much had the park to ourselves. The scenery here is majestic but the wildlife was not as plentiful as it was when we continued our journey into Yellowstone. We did manage to see a few moose (on the Moose-Wilson Road) and just outside of Dornan, a grizzly, a few bison, and elk, beaver and pronghorn. We also saw several Bald eagles and osprey. This is a really beautiful park and I would suggest about 3 days to capture as much of it as you can. Camping and lodges are available.
I've seen moose, bison, elk, beaver, otters, and eagles soaring overhead - all with the gorgeous Tetons as the backdrop. This park is a photographer's paradise! I love hiking in this park.
We enjoyed see the wildlife in the park and hiking the trail with spectacular views. This is a place that you must stop at when going to Yellowstone National Park.

We live not too far away, and I never tire of seeing these magnificent mountains! We had a great opportunity to bike ride along the Teton Park Road while it was still closed to traffic in April, and I highly recommend it! It's awesome when we drive along the road in summer, but what a different and more stunning experience to be able to go slow and really enjoy the views in depth. Grand Teton Nat'l Park also offers so many beautiful hikes, kayaking/canoeing, camping and so much more that there is never enough time to see it all! Add in a bit of great wildlife, and you can't go wrong no matter where you go in the park!

There are simply few words that can adequately describe the breath taking scenery of the 310,000 acres of the Grand Teton. From the mirror like surface of Jackson and Jenny Lakes reflecting the jagged magnificence of —les trois tétons the whole area is a must for the outdoors man or woman. Access to this beauty is easy for everyone, the only spoiler can be the weather. Even cloud shrouded the lakes nestled between the mountains and the surrounding valley of unquestionable aesthetics can still be a spine tingling treat. View from the valley floor around John Moulton Barn the Teton Range is an excellent example of the geological and spiritual metamorphosis this country has endured. It is well worth the visit. In fact it is worth a stay and a walk along it's trail.

HiWe drove to the Tetons from Idaho Falls and the range was gorgeous but very dry and ugly everywhere else. No green anywhere. Saw some bison but little else in the way of wildlife. There is a wonderful visitor center though. The park was not open so could not drive to Jenny Lake.
review_title: Beautiful Tetons - not the best time to go (April)

review_body: This is a not to be missed place. It was our second visit, and we saw incredible wildlife, despite the cold weather and season.If you go in April, I recommend bringing snowshoes. We did not, and regretted it, as the snow was still too deep to take any of the hiking trails. I wish I'd read about the Grouse mating ranger-led trips. they go off at 5:30 am, but it sounds awesome and I wish we'd known about it.The Teton views are incredible, and plenty of places to hike and take photos. Expect crowds in the summer, but you can also probably avoid some of the most popular trails.This is a must-see on any National Park lover's list.

Probably there at not a good time (June) but it is still absolutely amazing. I couldn't really do anything as I was on a business trip, but the views are absolutely stunning. Jackson is just a very beautiful area.

Some of the finest mountain vistas you will find in the world; if you love mountains and if you want to experience the vastness of the american wilderness.You must come here.Hikers will love it. Car travelers will love it too but will not be able to experience it as much.Make sure you are prepared for bears here. I grew up at 7,000 ft in Colorado, been to the Alps of Switzerland, the Dolomiti of Italy and Austria. Seen Mt Rainer, the Canadian Rockies and the Karakoram and Pamir ranges of Northan Pakistan. The Tetons are a must to behold.
review_title: Switzerland of America - Add at least 2 days to see this on your Yellowstone Trip

review_body: Grand Teton National Park is named after the tallest mountain in the Teton Range located at the northeastern edge of the Rockies. The jagged snow-capped peaks and their reflections on pristine alpine lakes are the principal features of the park. Add to that vast wilderness and abundant wildlife; you get a heavenly feeling all through your stay. True to our expectations, we were blessed by countless interactions with permanent residents of the park, namely bears, elks, bisons, mooses, deers and antelopes.The mesmerizing beauty of the shimmering waters of Jackson Lake was enhanced by its awesome backdrop, a cutout of a portion of the Teton Range. Snake River, which enriches the biodiversity of the park, can be best explored along the scenic Grassy Lake Road. Being a dirt road, this is not so popular among tourists, but offers serene sunset view along the Glade Creek.The other popular scenic drive around the south of Jackson Lake leads to the top of Signal Mountain, which tenders 360° panoramic views of the four mountain ranges: the Tetons, Gros Ventres, Wind Rivers, and Absarokas.Oxbow Bend and Blacktail Ponds Overlook are the best bet to watch a number of wildlife. Pronghorn antelopes were abundant in the nearby Antelope Flats Road and the Mormon Row dirt road.Teton Village is located just outside the park boundaries and offers a spectacular ride on an aerial tramway to the summit of Rendezvous Peak. The view from the top, to say it mildly, was captivating.

I loved seeing the mountains in the snow. The crispy sunny day added to the enjoyable visit. Viewing the elk feeding in a large herd from a distance gave me hope for the efforts for sanctuaries that are trying to save our wildlife.

This is definitely one of the most amazing places I have ever visited! My husband and I went on some of the shorter hikes (1-5 hours), and it was magnificent. The Tetons are very dramatic and paired with the tranquility of the lakes and meadows, it's paradise on earth. Even the shorter trails are not too crowded and the whole experience is just excellent! Can't wait to come back one day!

We actually did just a kind of drive-by in July 2012 on our way from Yellowstone to Jackson and then again on our way out of Jackson. There was a rain storm off in the distance when we came in, and it was just beautiful. If we were back in this area again, I would try to spend some more time here just looking at all the natural beauty of the whole area. We really did not think it would be a big deal after exploring Yellowstone for 4-5 days, but it was just a mesmerizing experience. We did manage to stop at two visitor's centers and enjoyed those very much, but just taking in the area is a serene experience that you have to check out if you are anywhere close. Even just driving by was amazing. Neither words or pictures can describe it, but I am adding a few pictures and noting that they definitely do not do this area justice. I can't imagine what exploring the area would be like, but I do plan to do just that at some point in the future if I am able. Just amazing!!!

I came to "Seuss-Like" Tetons to enjoy the scenery and find (hopefully) moose. Touchdown! Grand Slam Home Run! Slam Dunk! Moose lovers unite at the Tetons. Five moose in one day...including an almost nose-to-nose encounter with a three or four year old bull with a full "Bullwinkle" set of antlers. Saw more pronghorn antelope than I could have ever imagined. And...as much as I loved the moose...the most fun was getting caught by a herd of bison charging down the road right at my car. Cool!
review_title: Best Animal Sightings in the Lower 48

review_body: It was amazing to see those beautiful animals in there natural habitat! I was on a guided trip! Natural Habitat out of Colorado, our tour leaders know we're to see the wildlife ! It was a joy to get up early to spot a great variety of animals! We also visited Yellowstone Natural Park with all his attractions!

Skiing was amazing. As someone from the mid-west it was great to see the Tetons. The blue's at Jackson Hole are like Blacks in the mid-west. However, there were enough variations on the green that I hardly went down anyone way more than once. I can't wait to go back!!!

Cannot express such wonderful scene with word, all snow covered mountain, frozen lake, iced trees and grass... There is one of the most beautiful places I've ever been, and it is the best Christmas I've ever experienced. Will have to be there another time!! Spring, summer or autum??See the pictures please.圣诞节去了怀俄明州的大提顿公园，完全被白雪覆盖的冰雪世界征服，老婆说是过的最美的圣诞节，也是女儿玩的最开心的一次，比加勒比海的圣诞节更过瘾。决定还要再去一次，夏天、春天、还是秋天呢？。。。。。。

Grand Teton is a true natural wonder. The mountains, the lakes, the flora, and the wildlife all make this a very special place. It is very easy to drive through and not notice how great this place is. Take your time, get out of the car and walk as much as possible, you won't regret it.
You just can't but into words what you feel when you see the Grands. I live here and they amaze me every time I look at them.

Depends what you want, I suppose, but for me it is all about scenery. The Grand Tetons are just more spectacular in my opinion. Yellowstone is bigger and has more features, but for sheer grandeur, I found the Grand Tetons altogether a better experience. But they are both definitely worth seeing. As they are on the same entrance ticket, kinda dumb not to... Must do the boating thing on Lake Jenny.

What brilliant place! We drove south down to the Tetons after we had spent 3.5 days in Yellowstone. The drive in on the John D. Rockefeller Parkway was awesome, the view accoss the water to the Tetons is unforgetable. We have some brilliant photos. When you view the Tetons they look unreal because they just rise straight out of the prairie. We saw moose both male and female, beaver colony and dam, Prong Horn Deer, Byson and many other types of wild animals. We did a private 4 hour wild life tour in the Tetons, it was absolutely awesome. I will post a separate review in regard to the tour we went with Brushbuck Tours. Don't miss this place!
Our home faces this view 24/7 from 12 miles across the valley. They are still rising up as the valley floor slides under the Tetons.
Loved the natural beauty of Grand Teton National Park and all the wildlife! Signal Mountain, String Lake, Lupine Meadow, and Oxbow Bend are some of my favorites !
It's not a huge park so it's easily traveled and you can certainly see alot of the park in one day although you'll will want to spend more time exploring all the hidden gems and trails.

Grand Teton National Park is beautiful! I didn’t see wildlife on my hikes or while I was driving through the park, but the mountains are certainly a sight to see. The mountains, wide open space, and fresh air (and lack of humidity!) were certainly a treat for this Houstonian. I definitely recommend a visit to Grand Teton Park!

I don't know how to describe Grand Teton National Park. Most parts of the park were shut down. But nature works its mysteries 24/7. And they did for us. One day, we took the northern loop drive, from Jackson Junction (I think), going west and then south to the visitor center and Moose. The weather was threatening and it did rain at times. Some of the mountain areas were visible, much was not, and when we took some side roads, the rain and wind continued to make the visibility poor. Still, we continued and we finally returned to our accommodation - and then experienced a thunder and lightening storm, hail, rain and slush - and had about two inches of slush on our windshield!!Then came the next day. The sky was bright blue, and the mountains were glorious with newly-fallen snow. We repeated the journey of the day before, then continued, at Moose, down on the road to Teton Village ski center. This time, the mountains glowed in all their glory. I think Mount Moran was special, but the most spectaular peak, to me, was Grand Teton, approaching from the norhtwest. Shadows made it possible to see the "horns" - spires and cliffs that somehow are not seen from the typical views looking from east-to-west. There is something about the side hidden them, the north or northeast side, that has the unearthly appearance of parts of Torres del Paine, in southern Chile. The spires and jagged edges in of Grand Teton certainly, to me, make this a unique mountain in the Lower 48 states.

Brought my wife and mother in law to see the Grand Tetons and we weren't disappointed. The evening we arrived it was low clouds and drizzly so we couldn't really see them. We woke up the next morning to a dusting of snow and an absolutely spectacular view of the mountains!!

Our second trip through the park and almost had the place to ourselves due to snowstorm and Yellowstone south entrance closure. Always a pleasurable feast for the eyes no matter the weather. We managed to photograph river otters and a moose without even hiking on this excursion.
review_title: Always A Feast For The Eyes

review_body: We love coming here in the fall and avoiding the crowds and since we don't camp in the campgrounds, but only do backcountry, we don't mind if any are closed. It's so beautiful and we love canoe camping on Leigh Lake and hiking the Paintbrush Canyon loop, over to Lake Solitude and down. Not for the faint of heart, though! It's tougher hiking than Yellowstone. We saw Moose and bear and all sorts of other creatures. A fabulous National Park.

I wish we had, had more time to explore the Grand Tetons. The drive through the Grand Tetons is on the same scale a Yellowstone National Park, especially in the early evening as the sun is setting and it sprinkles it's magic charm on the forestry and lakes. It's a drive of ups and downs and slow moving because cars are stopping to watch the wildlife. It's an amazing drive and I can not find the words to describe it. If I thought driving through Yellowstone National Park hold beauty and amazement, then the Grand Tetons is on the same level. Don't let it slip you by!
review_title: Pictures can not describe the drive....

review_body: this time , on the wilson/moose road..what a treat. a pasture full of elk and then a bear..you don't have to wonder if there are animals that you are missing on the road. just stop when you see cars on the side of the road, and ask what kind of an animal that they are looking at. this bear, we heard, has been here all summer. loads of people and large cameras..so fun.

My husband and I spent a week in Jackson Hole, WY and thoroughly enjoyed meandering through the park each day we were there. If you visit, make sure you drive the Moose-Wilson road to see wildlife! There are many pullouts and places to hike. On a gorgeous, sunny day we hiked to Phelps Lake Overlook - a beautiful vista! On another day, we hiked to Hidden Falls and Inspiration Point. It was overcast and drizzled for most of the hike, but we had fun anyway. (If you visit in the off season like we did when the ferry is not running across Jenny Lake, drive down the Lupine Meadows trailhead and take the boat launch turnoff and you can cut off some of the walking distance from the South Jenny Lake parking area.) The week we visited the park, we saw moose, bear, elk, deer, and pronghorn. Although the fall folliage wasn't at its peak, there was still color and it was beautiful! If you go, make sure you visit Jackson Lake, Oxbow Bend, Jenny Lake, Signal Mountain and Mormon Row. While we were there, the weather ranged from sunny to overcast to rain. BUT although it rained in the valley, we discovered snow on the mountaintops! The crowds were light since it was the off season and some of the attractions had shut down on Oct 1, but we preferred this time of year over the crowds of summertime. If you love clear blue sky with white puffy clouds that look suspended in air and wide open spaces, then this is the place for you!

I can't explain how much I regret spending a week at Yellowstone before driving down to the Grand Teton National Park for a day. We were in heaven! Actually stayed an extra night just to do another two hikes. It won't matter the season this place is amazing. We are already planning to come back here next summer.
review_title: Why have I not visited here before?????

review_body: Just beautiful!! My Hubby and I have visited (from Ohio) 3 times! In May, September and October. May was nice, not a lot of other people. It was a cool and rainy with some snow showers, which is typical for May. The mountains were snow covered and just beautiful. Hiking can only be done in the valleys due to snow cover. We saw elk and bision calves. The fall is also very nice. The weather is usually sunny and cool. We just missed peak fall folliage, which is about the 3 rd week of Sept. The animals were active and in rut. The crowds were not bad, but more crowded than spring. Lodging is cheaper in the off seasons, but many of the lodges were closed. All roads were open in the fall, in the spring, the road to Signal mountain was still closed. Anytime if year would be an amazing time to visit!! Of course Yellowstone is just to north and also a definite 5 rating!! If you love the outdoors, and want to see one of the most beautiful places on earth, do not skip the Tetons!! Add to your bucket list, I guarantee you will not be disappointed!!
review_title: The most beautiful place I have ever seen!!!!

review_body: Stunning scenery, well marked trails, wonderful wild life, enthusiastic and helpful rangers - loved it!!

If you are just a sight seer, and not a hiker, boater, climber etc. you will need about one day to see all that you want to at this park. The Tetons are pretty spectatular, and the main visitor center (near moose junction) is truly a must see for all. We watched a movie there that made us appreciate what we were seeing more. There are also some nice chances to view wildlife, depending on the season and time of day (if you want to see moose, you evidently need to get out there pretty early). If you are trying to visit Yellowstone and the Tetons just to sight see, and want to base out of one hotel, I would recommend getting one in West Yellowstone. You are then only 3 minutes out of Yellowstone, and maybe 50 minutes out of the Tetons.

I was there in late september 2012 to avoid the crowds...Ok but because of winter shutdown of the park only 2 campgrounds were open. Lots of wildlife, mostly bisons...nice autumn colours. Campgrounds without showers i found overpriced at 23$ and 20$ . Side gravel roads are open and in good shape. Lots of access to lakes and rivers for fishing and canoeing.

During our visit the Tetons were shrouded in smoke haze but nonetheless are magnificent and the drives and walks were peaceful and, with no long distances to travel, unhurried. Excellent cycle tracks as well. A lovely place to linger and close to Jackson for accomodation and restaurants, cheaper than in the park lodges.
review_title: Compact park with stunning views and peaceful walks

review_body: Smoky air hindered views and made hiking less enticing, but the park is always beautiful. Jenny Lake Lodge is an escape from reality and very relaxed, yet elegant.
user_location: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States

review_body: To say that Grand Teton National Park is magnificent is an understatement. Just about anything one wants to see in the great outdoors is here. How's this for starters? Within 20 minutes of our entry into the park on our first day, we saw a bear (within 15 feet of the road and apparently oblivious to us), a bull elk, and a bull moose. More elk and moose 'posed' for our cameras in other visits. And the scenery! Lakes so clear that even on a hazy day, the abutting forests shimmered in reflection in their waters. Forests and meadows. And of course, those mountains. Whether dark and brooding in the dusk or rising and triumphant in the morning sun, they inspire awe. I wish that the Tetons were our backyard.

didn't like the smoke this year, but the fall colors were fabulous. Jenny Lake Lodge is our favorite family destination in the continental US. We have a yearly reunion at JLL and will return next year for our 7th year. There is something very special about this place...and then add thegreat food and we are ALL happy campers!
review_title: The most beautiful mountains in the US

review_body: When you enter the park you pay $25 dollars for a weeks pass which includes Yellowstone Park. We drove in to the park and within 5 mins out of the mist a stag appeared!! We then drove up the valley wow you can see the glaciers still in September.
review_title: Great drive through Teton with in 5 mins a Stag

review_body: The new Visitor Center is gorgeous. And be sure to watch the video in the theatre and stay will the end... I don't want to be a spoiler...
review_title: Don't miss the Moose Visitor Center

review_body: Late September in the Tetons is quite beautiful. We traveled throughout the park, some areas more than once. The vistas and animal life are extraordinary. We particularly enjoyed the Moose-Wilson Road and Gros Ventres Road areas for wildlife that included black bear, moose aplenty, pronghorns, bison and elk.We'll be back.
review_title: Breath Taking Views and Animal Life

review_body: No one we know had heard of Grand Teton until we went there, but it is mind blowing...you get off the plane at Jackson Hole and step into another world, with really dramatic scenery all around. When we first arrived it was really clear, and fortunately we took lots of photos in the first few days, unfortunately they do have wild fires in the area, which did cause some haziness from the smoke, but did not hamper our enjoyment of the area. We walked several of the easier trails, Phelps Lake, Jenny Lake and visited the National Museum of Wildlife Art. All highly recommended, saw moose in the river, a golden eagle, a bald eagle and several osprey. I'd love to go back there one day. When we were arranging our trip to Grand Teton and Yellowstone an american travel 'expert' recommended at least two days in Yellowstone, and a day in Grand Teton...we spent four days in Grand Teton, which was probably about right, and eight days in Yellowstone. With only two days, you would not have a chance to get your walking boots dirty! Needless to say, we did not take any notice of the 'expert'.

The Grand Teton National Park is unsurpassed in terms of mountains, plains. trees, walking, hiking, biking opportunities. Closest place to it is Torres del Paine in Chile...a must visit for anyone who wants to experience nature. More spectacular and interesting than neighboring Yellowstone National Park.
Beautiful scenery got to see lots of wildlife. Saw pronghorns, grizzly and moose, a photographers dream.
You can get a multi pass for both parks definately should. We wanted to be able to go in to use as a short cut and had to pay again. SO much wildlife in the area.

The park was beautiful. We hiked, we saw animals, we saw how the west looked before the settlers came. And those mountains. Those gorgeous mountains. If you like the outdoors you will like this place.

What a beautiful sight! It's hard to believe you can see moose eating bushes at the end of someone's driveway, bison roaming the ranges, elk with a full set of antlers while going for a hike and if you are not lucky - grizzly bear! We hiked many of the easier day trails (Phelps Lake and Taggart Lake) in Grand Teton and was so impressed by the "grandness" of the scenery. We stayed one night at the Jackson Lake Lodge. Had dinner in the Mural Room watching the sun set behind the mountains and got up early to watch the sun rise right out our bedroom window.We hope to return next summer and share this majestic place with our children.

Lovely vistas all around. Not as "tourist-trodden" as Yellowstone. We loved the Inspiration Point (and into Cascade Canyon for another mile) hike. Also views from Signal Mountain road were great. Lovely little Two Oceans Lake was a nice surprise.

The Grand Tetons are truly majestic. The views of the mountains are breathtaking. We saw lots of wildlife throughout the park including bison, mule deer, prairie dogs, and several moose. The park was not that crowded during September which made it even more enjoyable. There are several hiking trails throughout the park.

The view of these mountains across Jackson Lake is stunning, enough to make you wish you owned a panoramic camera. Unfortunately the week we visited the skies were obscured from smoke due to a forest fire south of Jackson Wyoming.

Places we enjoyed here: the chapel of transfiguration, where the baptismal has a window framing the view of the Tetons; then walk across to visit the historic ferry and take a ferry ride across the river and visit the historic buildings; visit Jenny Lake and take a boat ride across the lake to hike to Hidden Falls (take a picnic lunch with you!)01
scenic as can be expected! Just like in Yellowstone, i find that road signs that are meant to direct visitors to scenic points are poorly placed and sometimes they are even not there at all.

Grand Teton should be relished for it's variety and compliment to it's big brother Yellowstone. I'd never visit YNP without also paying tribute to this glorious location. I would recommend camping to lodging as the park is dry most of the time and is just serene and easy to manage.
The views were incredible, lots of wildlife and great weather. It was a little smoky at times from the wildfires in Idaho but it clears up with the wind.
Fabulous scenery , brilliant wildlife really worth the visit, Jenny Lake was beautiful. We only had 2 days in the park wish we had more

I did not know what to expect from Grand Teton National Park. When I arrived, there were wildfires in Idaho dumping smoke into the Park from the West, and the Grand Teton Mountains were barely visible. The next day the smoke was less, the day after even less. When they finally appeared, nothing could prepare me for their impact. The Grand Tetons are a fairly young range, still stark and craggy. They rise swiftly from the valley floor and top out at over 13,000 feet (I believe that is 3,939 meters if my math is correct).. The Park has abundant wildlife viewable from the road, or during hikes off-road. You can rent a boat and fish for lake trout, or several other species of trout. Fly fishing is very popular in the Snake River both in Grand Teton Park and on the Snake River to the south of Jackson, Wyoming. I took a gided hike with a Park Ranger to Inspiration Point and had a wonderful time, and was rewarded with an absolutely beautifull view of Jenny Lake when we arrived at that point. The Park is fairly big, and there is lots to see. My recommendation is that you spend several days there in order to enjoy your experience. Go out at all times of the day, which will give you the best chance to see wildlife. I would go back to this Park tomorrow if I could.
review_title: Lots to do, lots to see, stay awhile

review_body: The Grand Tetons took my breath away! I was visiting Yellowstone NP but Our guide told us to just take a drive through because my husband wanted to see a bear. Well I think we went 3 times. I especially loved the Jenny Lake area. Wear walking shoes and be prepared for weather temperature changes in the springtime.

I didn't know about Grand Teton National Park until my local guide suggested giving it a day. What an amazing, beautiful place that turned out to be my favorite scenery in all of the greater Yellowstone area. 4 bears, 4 moose, GORGEOUS lakes Jackson and Jenny, streams, eagles, osprey -- and those utterly magnificent peaks in the background. it was like falling into paradise around every corner.
The views are spectacular. The Snake River carves through the center of the Park offering an opportunity to see animals.

Not too far from Jackson so you can stay there if you don't like to camp. Beautiful to drive. Make sure to go to a marina such as signal mountain or colter bay and rent a small motor boat so you can see the mountains from the water

The tent cabins at Colter bay are spacious, clean, easy to 'live' in. They have a wood burning stove to heat the inside, a firepit and picnic table outside. Reasonable price. There are 4 fold down bunks, or do like we did, and bring your air mattress for the floor. The park is stunning, with rivers and lakes. Simply beautiful.

It is easy to simply pass through Grand Teton Nat'l Park as the main highway offers nice views of the jagged mountains. However, it is well worthwhile to take the short road that runs along Jenny Lake as that lake is among the prettiest we have ever seen. One of the parking areas there allows incredible vistas of this beautiful lake with the impressive mountains as a backdrop. Trails lead down to lakeside and there is a great view just steps from your car. The lush trees in the area invite artistic views of the mountains and lake framed by the trees. Definitely worth a visit.

If you are going to Yellowstone be sure to go to Grand Teton NP.First - It is included in your Yellowstone fee.The views are the best. One of the best in USA.Comparable to Yosemite valley or Glacier NP.Looking at these mountains will take your breath away.We live in Houston but travel alot. We have no views like this in our area so we really appreciate a view when we see it.Drive slow, stop often, take plenty of pictures.We found the lodges and food to be better than that of Yellowstone.Grand Teton should not be missed.It is a few miles South of Yellowstone.Fires were far away and not an issue when in late August 2012.

We drove through the entire park and stopped at all the stops. We did not do any hiking. I would have rated the trip excellent if it was not for the smoke from the wild fires hiding the mountains in the smog.

This was our first trip here and we thoroughly enjoyed our hike to hidden falls and inspiration point (moderate exertion). The crisp dip in Jenny Lake was the icing on the cake. My husband noted how fun it was to hear all the different languages spoken by fellow visitors. Next time, we will be sure to add the Canyon trail to our hike, as everyone said it was incredibly scenic.
review_title: A wonderful place to relax and enjoy Americana

review_body: I spent a few days with my family exploring this spectacular park. Anyone silently standing at the foot of these magnificient rocky peaks will fall in a state of contemplation, a sense of humbleness in the presence of giants. For the sporty ones, there are superb cycling paths (paved), and for the walkers quite an array of hiking trails. Be prepared to dodge often though, because horses have left behind an impressive amount of dung in the trails (not cool). I must say that my hikes, although benefical for my personnal health, did not permit me to develop more awe than from the car windows. In Yellowstone, one MUST walk to see the best of the geysers, but this seems not to be the case in GT. The best points of interest CAN be seen from the road, or short hikes.
review_title: Spectacular vues, not so good trails

review_body: The Teton National Park is one grand place to take a vacation. The mountains are majestic. The scenery is breathtaking. You can bike. You can hike. You can picnic. You can do all kinds of boating activities. Places to eat. Lodges to stay in. You will never regret going there
One of the most beautiful mountain ranges in the western U.S. Something everyone should see. I will go back to spend more time here in the furture.

May be it was just our bad luck -- but we came here to get some fresh air and cool alpine scenery - and were met by hot dry weather with air quality worse than san fernando valley, thanks to idaho wildfires. overall the place is ok to drive around for a day or two -- but yellowstone a lot more scenic in my opinion, and better from a wildlife perspective as well. this area seems more like a rich winter playground, along the lines of vail, etc.

I recently did a 3 night backpack trip at the Grand Tetons National Park. I parked at the Leigh Lake Trailhead and hiked up the Paintbrush Canyon Trail the first day. A challenging but worthwhile hike. I saw a big black bear midway up the canyon eating in a raspberry field next to the trail. I set up camp just below the end of the upper paintbrush camp zone. A beautiful view all around. The next day, I went over the Paintbrush divide and also summited the peak to the north of the divide. 10820 ft. Great view and easy climb. Then down to Lake Solitude. This area is full of flowers and the lake is wonderful. I continued down and saw the largest moose I have every saw. It had 8 points but another 10-12 points that were about to complete. A sight. The South fork Cascade was fully of waterfalls and cliffs. Going to the end and climbing Hurricane Pass is well worth it to see the perfect view of the 3 Tetons and the valley where the South Fork Trail runs. I stayed two days in this area. Well work it. Lastly, I hiked down early the last morning down Cascade Trail. A very easy slow decline. I will go back.
review_title: Utmost Beauty with a good challenging hike

review_body: The park is beautiful! Get out and hike or bike. They have great bike trails in this park. Go on at least one hike in the area. Youl will be glad you got out of your car. Better yet, go on a Ranger led hike. They are very interesting.

Even if you're not doing serious backpacking, the mountain vistas are fabulous from so many vantage points and perspectives. Some of ours included from a very early morning float trip on the Snake River. We saw bald eagles on that float trip also. Views from Blacktail POnds Overlook and Schwabacher's landing also gorgeous. Several short hikes are also pretty accessible. We saw plenty of moose near moose junction. Surprisingly, we saw no elk or bison, though we saw plenty of bison in Yellowstone, as well as a bear. I would recommend doing both parks in one trip - we've done that twice. Our grandkids participated in the Junior Ranger program, and it definitely enhanced their experience, I think they learned a lot about both Parks, and begain to develop a real appreciation for them.
The views and the food were exceptional. Excellent accommodations? Get a reservation at Jenny Lake Lodge for dining. it is worth it!

The mountain views are the best in the lower 48, hands down. The worst part is driving because you want to just gawk at the incredible sights but you can't because you're driving. We saw several moose, a grizzly and lots of bison in our short 2 days there. Make sure you catch sunrise at the mormon row barns and at the Snake river overlook. These are the two best spots to be at that time and it's the best time to photograph these beautiful mountains. The inspiration point trail is well worth the trek and don't miss the taggert lake trail too. Look for moose by the Snake river at sunset near the visitor center in Moose.

The views are beautiful. We went on five different hikes. We saw all kinds of wildlife, including moose. The glacier is amazing and the different lakes are nice and a little cool when you go swimming.

I underestimated the beauty of the Tetons. Boy, two days was not enough to explore this gorgeous area. The hikes, lakes, canyons, vista points, and wildlife are incredible. We saw several moose and a grizzly in one day (in Tetons) and never saw these animals in Yellowstone in an entire week. While Yellowstone is interesting, the Tetons are breathtaking!!!

Went in early June before the big crowds but the seasonal staff had arrived and all was open. We loved the proximity of all of the hiking and lakes. We could hike a few hours and relax for a few. Saw so many animals we had never seen before! I didn't want to leave!

My favorite mountains. My 2nd visit to the area, and these are by far my favorite mountains in the USA. They truly are majestic. Be sure and take the Snake River float tripfor more fantastic views and photos
Lots to do and see including game watching, rafting down the Snake river, just looking at the magical scenery. Should not be missed.

In planning my trip to Grand Teton National Park I had scheduled and paid for a dinner lake cruise on Jackson Lake. The first day at Jackson Lake Lodge I check in and picked up my tickets and was told to be at Jenna Lake at 5:15 PM on the day of the cruise. I received a cell phone call the day of the cruise and was told that they had overbooked the cruise and they would have to cancel my reservations. Needless to say I was very upset. My activity tickets had printed on them that they had a 72 hour cancellation policy if I had wanted to cancel. Obviously Grand Teton Lodge Company does not have to adhere to their own rules.Be aware that booking far in advance does not guarantee you a seat on the dinner cruise
review_title: Don't assume that your reservations for dinner cruise on Jackson Lake will result in you taking the cruise.

review_body: WOW what a place to see. We spent 2 days wandering the park and every turn was a new view to be amazed with. We rented a boat and went out on Jackson Lake with our 2 teenage boys this is something we will never forget.

Should be on everyone's bucket list. We camped and hiked all around the Tetons. Also recommend the boat across Jenny Lake to the various hiking trails. Trail is moderate strenuous so make sure to wear good shoes and bring water. Fantastic view from above.

The mountains are every bit as amazing as you would expect! I originally had our trip planned so we would see the Tetons via the Mesa Falls Scenic Byway. But the locals told us the ONLY way the get the view we wanted was to go down to Jackson, WY. They were right! It was truly the mist beautiful & majestic thing I have ever seen. If you are ever near Jackson, WY, go see the mountains up close.

Grand Teton is another area of impressive scenery and abundant wildlife.The views are so fantastic that I can not express the beauty of ths area in words. The area of Colter Bay in Teton Park is just extraordinary in every way. I am so glad to have this experience. Make sure to put this on your list to experience what America has to offer.

We drove 4 days from Baton Rouge and can honestly say it was the most worthwhile road trip I've ever made. We stayed a few nights in the Colter Bay campground (be sure to get there early in the day to secure a spot!). We also backcountry camped one night on the Paintbrush trail, which involved trekking across glaciers, which were incredible to see in July. We hiked to Inspiration Point and through Cascade Canyon, which was absolutely stunning. We white-water rafted the Snake River, made stops for grub at Snake River Brewery (LOVE Pako's Beer) and the Bunnery in Jackson Hole, and kayaked Jackson Lake out of the Colter Bay Marina. Trip of a lifetime! Some of the most breathtaking sights I've ever seen.

Undoubtedly, this is one of the most beautiful places on earth. If I could wake up every morning to this sight, I'm sure I'd never have a bad day. The Tetons are grand from afar or up close and somehow in modern times it has remained very wild. Although it may lack the large number of animals seen in Yellowstone, it has those majestic mountains and lakes that will run your camera battery dry.

We stayed for several days in Grand Teton National Park. I was struck by what the park ranger said as we came in. He said, "Enjoy YOUR park." And as supporters of the NPS, it is partially our park, and how fortunate we are to have them.

We spent four days in Grand Teton National Park. We camped in two campgrounds (Gros Ventre and Colter Bay RV Park). We also did a rafting trip in Jackson and a horseback riding trip through the park (Colter Bay Stables). It has to be one of the most amazing parks I have visited. It needs to be on everyone's list as a must see. We headed up to Yellowstone afterward and I hate to say this, but I thought GTNP was more scenic! We did several ranger programs while we were there and the presenters were passionate about their work and the park. We did not hike as much as I would have liked and it was quite crowded in the end of July, but I would do it all again in a heart beat. The horseback ride was peaceful and brought us by some incredible views. The visitor centers were well done and very informative.

We didn't spend alot of time here due to the many places we wanted to see on our month long road trip. We just passed through on the main route on the way to yellowstone stopping at one overlook and Moose Junction visitor center. But what we did see was beautiful, with the snowcapped mountains in the background. We will definitely be back next year to see more of the park along with Yellowstone.
Traveling into this landscape of beauty is something everyone should experience. We have a beautiful country and the Grand Tetons are a perfect example of that. A must see!!

We loved GTNP. We stayed for four nights at Signal Mountain Campground in late June. We saw lots of wildlife, including grizzly bears, elk, bison, moose, and marmonts. We took a couple of hikes that were awesome. We also went to Jackson Hole ( Mangy Moose ) and the town of Jackson for dinner. The visitor center from the south end was brand new and very nice, Can't wait to go back

I grew up in the foot hills of the rockies. I skied the Alps. The Tetons are are some of the best mountains and scenery I've seen. We loved this trip. The people were friendly, the sights were amazing. My favorite thing was to drive around the park and watch the sun rise over the peaks. We hiked to the hidden falls. Take water. Great trip. My son later said he'd rather hike to the falls without water than sit in a car for 8 hours. Its about 3 hours round trip with kids. Worth the visit.

From either the main road between Jackson and Moran Junction or Teton Park Inner Road wonderful views can be had of the mountains towering way above you.From every turnout you can't fail to capture the fantastic photographic opportunities of the peaks and glaciers.

Grand Teton should be on everyone's bucket list. Jenny Lake is fantastic and is the location where we often see black bears (not this time). When you cross the bridge heading into Jenny Lake, may close attention to the stream - there are often Moose in the stream. Try to either go early in the morning or in the cool evening. The Grand Tetons make a person feel really small. The mountains are absolutely incredible and beautiful. Plan to spend some time, instead of just driving through on your way to YNP.
review_title: We love everything about Grand Teton National Park

review_body: Compared to many of the National Parks (they are all fantastic), GTNP appears to be more developed with many bike lanes, paved trails, facilities, etc.... It didn't have the "wilderness" feel of Yellowstone or Rocky Mountain National Park. However, we still loved the views of the mountains and Jenny Lake. We also had a great hike up to Inspiration Point and took some great pictures.There are an abundant number of Park Rangers to assist if needed. We asked one if he could direct us to a location where we might see a moose. He gave us directions to a place where one had been spotted and he told us how to watch for them. Sure enough, after following his guidance we found her standing in a small pond just as he told us we might. If you have time, you can rent a boat or kayak on Jenny Lake and we wish we had of had the time to do so. This is a beautiful National Park and so close to Jackson Hole, Wyoming.
review_title: Majestic Views, Well developed, bike lanes, etc....

review_body: They have the most wonderful visitor's center - very beautifully designed and informative!I'm an artist and this was such an inspiring area - definitely a must see destination! and you never know where or when you'll find wildlife - moose, deer, coyotes - just keep looking and you'll find something!The Rockefeller Preserve nearby is also a beautiful place - I really recommend stopping by for a bit of serenity.

I visited the Grand Teton Park as a child and knew the mountains were beautiful. They are not just beautiful they are spectacular!My cousin who lives in Jackson gave us a guided tour through the park.We were on a limited time schedule so we did not do any hiking or camping.The Grand Teton Naional Park is more beautiful than Yellowstone.There are several Visitor Centers with lots of souvenirs and informative exhibits. Tip:my cousin told us to come the first part of June to avoid the crowds. Have layered clothing. We had light snowfall in June.

You can really get right on top of the mountains here. While different in scale and in other ways from its sister just to the north, Grand Teton is a must. Jenny Lake is stunning and the views around every corner are great. We didn't get to encounter any wildlife besides the stray bison and a moose off in the distance, but the views of the tetons make it all worthwhile.
Beautiful mountains and NP. Jenny Lake is pretty. Wonderful way to see the view before going to Yellowstone NP.

I love the west and this is the best of the west for sure! We saw a moose 50 feet from the visitor center down by the river. I had never seen a moose the whole time at Yellowstone. You must make this a stop if not a destination.

You simply cannot describe the beauty of this NP in a review. In some ways, Grand Teton NP is far superior to Yellowstone. I highly recommend the drive along Jenny Lake and getting out for some hiking if you are able. Although we did not ride the trails, I was extremely jealous of those who enjoyed the park from their bike. DO NOT leave yours at home!
Our family loves the beauty, hiking, and overall scenery of Grand Tetons. Highly recommend everyone taking at least one trip there in their lifetime.
Incredible views, beautiful mountains, lakes and sightings of wildlife - not a single thing not to like about this National Park!

We took the shuttle across Jenny Lake and planned to hike to Inspiration Point. Every step was beautiful, but if you have young children be prepared to turn back. We are regular mountain hikers with our 5 year old but this trail wore him out before we hit the top.Also, get there early if you want parking, we drove around for 20 minutes waiting for a spot at 10am.

Don't pass up the grand Tetons this is just as good as Yellowsnow take the road to Teton Village to grand Tetons it's a narrow road right in the wilderness and that is a drive not to be messed a wonderful park as good as Yellowstone lots of wildlife up close

The Tetons in Jackson is where I live. I get to see these beautiful mountains every day, & yet do not grow tired or awed by their sight. Stay in the National Park or in Jackson & spend a few days hiking, biking, fishing or rafting this magnificent National Park.
review_title: I seen the Grand Teton from my porch

review_body: While finishing our trip from Yellowstone we decided to drive through the Tetons. It was the best decision we took and we will never regret that. The park pass for YNP also works for Grand Tetons. The views are awesome with many overlook points for taking pictures. We just wish we had some more time to spend here.

With such great mountain views it is definitely worth the drive. Part of the Tetons remind me of the Kootenai's up in Canada - but the Tetons have more greenery and life about them. We just drove through but there is plenty to see and do.
review_title: If you visit Yellowstone - Include the Tetons

review_body: Grand Tetons are adjacent to Yellowstone and your entry pass works for both locations. Jenny Lake is beautiful. Find the stop offs that over looking the lake and the pictures you take look fake!!! Fresh air, sight seeing, wildlife are all areound. Just beautiful!
review_title: A must see if in the area

review_body: Our first mistake was in not allowing enough time to explore the many facets of this amazing national park. Though we had only a sampler, it whetted our appetite to return someday for more. The physical beauty of the ever-changing landscape literally took our breath away. Even on the approach the vistas are stunning; I had to delete about 30 pictures of the same mountain range from my ipad at night! I also highly recommend getting a guide book or taking a guided tour as roaming on your own, at least the first day, could be counter-productive. We stayed outside the park in Jackson Hole, Wyoming, and loved this town as well. We were there early June and the weather was delightful, and crowds minimal.
review_title: A Grand Time in the Tetons

review_body: We drove from Yellowstone Park to Teton Village/Jackson & stayed in Jackson. The Rockefeller Parkway connects Grand Teton and Yellowstone national parks. As we drove along, we saw the jagged Teton mountain range rising majestically over Teton Lake. The natural beauty is simply breathtaking. Great photo opportunities. We spotted moose, elk and bear.There is plenty to do here while enjoying the natural beauty of the area; hiking, fishing, horseback riding, rafting & fun shopping & dining venues in Teton Village.Fees: $25 per vehicle (good for 7 days in both Teton & Yellowstone national parks) -- if you want to hike on the trails/pathways, you need a separate pass. This trail pass can be purchased at the station at Moose entrance. The trail pass is $12 per person & is good for 7 days,

We travelled down from Yellowstone to have a look at Grand Teton (pronounced teeton) and wow! What a beautiful park - the mountains are the backdrop and more majestic than anything in Yellowstone, wonderful to see and reminiscent of Austria or Switzerland. There are lots of outdoor activities to keep those who enjoy hiking, fishing, etc. very happy. We were there in June when the spring flowers were out and it made the wonderful scenery even more spectacular. Wildlife was in short supply for us but we did get to see 2 huge bull moose considering whether they should fight or walk away - they walked away after about half an hour. A definite must see if you are in the area.
Beautiful and inspiring. I wanted to move as soon as I got there.
Hiking, fishing, boating, sight seeing, relaxing. It is so beautiful.

We just got back from a wonderful trip out to Montana and drove down through the Tetons to Jackson Hole. What an amazing park. We pulled over and had lunch at Jackson Lake and let the girls play in the water. We hope to come back when we can spend more time. The Town of Jackson Whole was a fun place too. Great Shop & Eats!!

It is yet another reason why we are "America the Beautiful"! We stayed in Jackson 1 night and explored the park for about 1/2 day for 2 days. We saw herds of elk, pronghorn, and bison. We were also lucky enough to watch (close up) 2 moose in the river! The mountains, lakes, and rivers are so beautiful! You do not want to miss this park even if your main destination is Yellowstone.
review_title: It is not to be missed!

review_body: Utterly fantastic! So beautiful and peaceful. Great hiking trails and a photographer's dream.

Everyone will tell you to visit Jenny Lake when you go to Grand Teton National Park and it is gorgeous. However, the crowds in the summer months are large. A less busy and still beautiful lake is Leigh Lake. There is a short, easy hike along the lake that is perfect for families. While a drive through this park is better than no visit, it is a park best experienced by getting out into it.
review_title: Beware of large crowds at Jenny Lake

review_body: The whole park is wonderful with the background of the mountains. Do not miss any of the attractions and you will remeber the visit of a lifetime.
My wife and i took pictures of the family at Tetons. At the base of the mountain, it looks like we are standing in front of a fake background because it is so beautiful.

I haven't been everywhere on the planet yet, but this has to be up there with the very best nature has to offer. Yes, go see Yellowstone too, but when you've seen both parks, maybe you will agree with me that GT is even more beautiful and unforgettable -- as well as being less crowded and having better services than Yellowstone. I want to come back here again and again. Every trail we hiked seemed more beautiful, and more crowded with wildlife, than the last.
review_title: Most beautiful spot on the entire planet?

review_body: Beautiful mountains and great hiking trails where you'll see plenty of wildlife. A must stop on the way to Yellowstone National Park!
review_title: Wonderful park with gorgeous views of the mountains

review_body: We had a great vacation in the Tetons and in Yellowstone. If we go back, we probably spend more time in the Tetons. We did the Jenny Lake Hike and the String Lake Hike. We floated the Snake, went to several visitor centers, spent a day in Jackson, and much more. When my kids are older, I would like to try some backcountry backpacking here.

The Tetons are so beautiful that words or pictures can't do them justice. You must see them with your own eyes. Take time to hike, explore, go out at night to see the stars, visit the visitor centers, take a float trip, see the animals, just be in nature.Roosevelt and the Rockefellers and others were so right to preserve what is a precious piece of the U. S. Take yourself and/or your children to see what the US was like before man got hold of it.Children's activiites are abundant. The forest and park rangers are ready and willing to answer all questions. The area encourages preservation and recycling.Go with your patience intact. People stop to view wildlife and the gorgeous scenery. You won't be going anywhere quickly. Just slow down and enjoy.I visited before during the first week in June. There aren't so many people then and some things aren't open yet, but you will avoid people and lines if those are problems for you.
This may be the USA's best views of the Rockies. Just gaze and appreciate what you are seeing!!
Some of the most spectacular mountains in America with wonderful hiking trails, and biking trails, canoeing, white water rafting, etc.
Great views and trails for hiking - interesting visitor centers and general stores. We spent a lot of time there this trip and did not even go to Yellowstone where we have been twice before.
review_title: Spent our time at this park - so much to do!

review_body: Great views of the park and the mountain. Take the Cascade Canyon trail for better views!

GOING TO SOUTH ENTRANCE AND GRAND TETONSHeld up by bison wandering on the road at Alum Creek! After about an hour Lewis Lake pull-in which was very pretty. Then Lewis Falls was difficult to park – roadworks - following the Lewis River and still snow here. Views of the Tetons ahead.Moose Falls – pull-in at Crawfish Creek about 50 yards down a very uneven path to the top of the falls and view into the gorge, then 50 yards of rocky steps down to the bottom for a very close view. 2 mins to the South Entrance from here.We chose to the take the US 191 through Teton National Forest to get a panoramic view of the Grand Tetons. After 20 mins we had our first photos of Jackson Lake with the Tetons in the background. Absolutely beautiful, stunning views again. At the Colter Bay turn-off there are proper toilets and general store first. The Visitor Centre is another 900’ down, but you can park here as well. This was only a small shop, with a couple of Indian ladies with their jewellery and a small display of Indian culture. There was an auditorium, with no sign of times, and a marina.Bear cubs crossing the road sign. I wish! Chance would be the thing. 5 mins down the road there is a pull-in with picture opportunities. Elk Ranch Flats, Snake River Outlook and Glacier View have wonderful views all along the road.About an hour from Colter Bay there is Moose Junction Craig Thomas Discovery & Visitor Centre. This is a new wooden building and well worth a visit. There are lots of exhibits, impressive bronzes, 3 sections of glass floor with videos under your feet.Half an hour on we turned off onto Teton Park Road (Moose-Wilson Rd). Needed to go through the Park Entrance at the base of the Tetons to see Jenny Lake. At Cottonwood Creek here there was a moose with her baby.Jenny Lake is very pretty. It is a 10 min walk down on a paved path. $10 return on a shuttle boat to the other side.Here I consider we made a mistake because we decided to carry on down the Teton Park Road, because the main view from here is obscured by tree covered hills. It is a narrow road with thoughtless drivers coming the other way. About 3 miles and nothing to see until you reach Granite Canyon Trail. There is no stopping for miles. I wished we had gone back to the main road instead because the Tetons are so beautiful, but then we would have to have come back the other longer route.We finally got to Teton Village and Jackson Hole ski resort in about half an hour. Here they operate an aerial tram ride (cable car) to the top of the 10,000+ mountain. This is an absolute ‘must do’ as there are incredible views in a complete panorama, with explanations of what you are looking at. You can see for miles. The cabin holds 60 and runs every 15 mins until 5.30 pm. It was 48F at the top, so need a jacket, but not freezing though, more fresh, but sunny. It boasts the highest ski run in the US. $23 in June, $29 in July. No disabled access.We stayed in Jackson 20 mins away at the Virginian Lodge (see separate review) and ate at the Gun Barrell 2 blocks down. According to a local, Jackson Hole is a nickname as the whole area is surrounded by mountains and Jackson, the town, is deep in the middle.I will remember the stunning views of the Tetons and Jackson Lake for the rest of my life.

I've just driven past Grand Teton on my way to Yellowstone NP the first two times I was in the area, stopping for a short 10 minutes along the picturesque Jackson Lake. It's not until I started hiking seriously along the Wasatch Front in Utah that I started paying more attention to this smaller, much less famous, yet much more scenic national park, and I soon fell in love with it. Idyllic lakes, plunging waterfalls, rugged mountains, brilliant wild flowers, abundant wild lives, Teton has it all. You can take an easy 1 mile round trip hike, flat, around a beautiful lake; or you can rough it and backpack in to climb to the highest peak; or choose any of the dozens trails in between. With so many lakes, big and small, fishing and boating are good too; but I don't have time for those yet, I'm not quite done hiking!

We love driving through the Tetons but this is the first time we stopped at the Visitor Center and took a few minutes, then came back and did some horseback riding and even saw a moose. Thanks Tetons!

Our experience in the Grand Tetons was great. I read about the area before our trip which was good background material. The park is very user friendly and has something for everyone. The scenery is extraordinary. We spent a couple of days in the area hiking and taking in the scenery. Next time I will have my bike. The bike paths are flat and run parallel to the roads of the parks most of the time. The hiking paths vary in length from1 mile in a paved area to over 15 miles through the mountains .The trails are designated by length and the level of difficulty. We chose a3 mile of medium difficulty through the woods by the falls and then down to the boat dock - you may choose to take the ferry back - IMO good choice. For the photographers the photo opportunities are endless. There are lots of places to pull over so you can get that shot of the mountains or the wildlife. On the second day we hiked in the morning and went for morning shots of Jenny Lake. We worked our way through the park to the north entrance and on to Yellowstone. We did not spend much time in Jackson Hole but it looked very interesting and the downtown is a mecca for shopping. As we drove through one evening there was a native American demonstration in the city park which was drawing a lot of attention.
The park was very beautifull with good roads. Nature is overwhelming . you have to take the small roads to see the animals.

This park is so beautiful. If you are planning a trip to Yellowstone put aside extra time to visit the Tetons.Amazing views. Colter Bay is a great place to hike amd kayak to see a different side. Do a float down the snake river , early morning or night to see wildlife.
review_title: The mountains are right there, in your face.

review_body: Our home state of Georgia has mountains. This big guy is a MOUNTAIN.Our recent trip had only a little bad weather, so the views of Grand Teton were spectacular. We have photos from a variety of places, since we entered the park via the Teton Village - Moose road, went up around Jenny Lake, Signal Mountain and Jackson Lake, and finally exited toward Yellowstone. The views from the Moose Visitor center and from the Jackson Lake Lodge were the best, since it was a nice angle with the flanking mountains in the same photos. Overnight snow gave the photos a different look from day to day.

What a truly incredible place. I've seen a lot of America over the past few years. But this place really stood out. It really is difficult to put the beauty of this place into words. All I can really say is "go there". We arrived in early June and the weather was pretty much perfect. Lots of sun so the mountains were refected in the lakes. Amazing.
My husband and I enjoyed the Grand Tetons. Beauty on every curve in the road. Awesome.

Grand Teton National Park is astoundingly beautiful. We spent 4 wonderful days there and the scenery was breath taking, the wildlife viewing spectacular, the lodging very nice and the staff was so friendly and helpful. In our FIRST 45 minutes in the park, driving in from Jackson after a long day of travel, we were completely revived by seeing a mother moose and calf, a grizzly bear, a coyote catching and enjoying his dinner and countless bison. The next days did not disappoint. The rangers are knowledgeable and helpful with advise about recommended hikes -- and those NOT recommended due to increased bear activity. There is so much to see from your car, the overlooks or any hike you choose, you will not be disappointed!
review_title: Until now Yosemite was my favorite....

review_body: There are beautiful drives through the park, but there are numerous trails into the mountains (and one around the mountains if you are really serious). There are plently of peaks to climb--but if you haven't been here before, be sure to do a guided trip if you are climbing. Floating the Snake River (scenic trip through the park--white water to the south of the park) is fun way to get a totally different view--and very educational. Day hiking is my favorite way to see this park.

Explore the outstanding majestic mountains, lakes and stream beauty in this park! Abundant wildlife such as buffalo, wolf, and even a coyote could be seen as well. Take one of the many trails. Boat rides available too. Don't miss the visitor center. Be sure to have your camera along.
The views are unbelievable. The wildlife crossed in front of our car on three different occasions. Everyone was friendly.

We could not have enjoyed this vacation any better. The Grand Tetons are one of the most spectacular mountain ranges in the world, viewed from either hiking trails or the well-maintained road system throughout the park. Thank you John D. Rockefeller, Jr. for having the vision to save this jewel from development in the 1950s.

Have to say this was fantastic. Drove up to have dinner by the Jenny lake vistor center. Great food and well priced. The view from to top deck area of the mountains was the best with snow on the tops made this so special. Drove back to Jackson and saw buffalo and moose , and pronghorn. Worth visiting.
review_title: Grand Teton the place seethe wild life.

review_body: Grand Teton has some quite amazing views as you drive around the scenic loop.Views to take your breath away. We are fortunate to have some of Europe's best scenery on our doorstep in Scotland and although lucky enough to be able to enjoy that, the scenery in Grand Teton was breathtaking and at another level.It looks wonderful from the Idaho side as you head towards it with the top of the range easily visible from 50 or 60 miles away but the full grandeur only becomes obvious when you head in to the park on the Wyoming side.At all points along the road the scenery draws you in and stops you in your tracks.The favourite place for us was Colter Bay with the yachts and cruisers sitting in the marina against the backdrop of the Tetons - simply wonderful.Only when you drive through an area like Grand Teton do you wish you were a better photographer to try and capture better the landscape and majesty around you.
The Tetons are gorgeous! I could look at the sun setting over the mountains every day.

I wish I brought my bike, as I saw there were a whole bunch of road bikers on the bicycle path all the way to Jackson. Driving on the main road, we can see the majestic views of the lakes to the great mountains in the back. It is a natural sight to behold. I personally felt the views here are way better than Yellowstone. The feeling of this national park is different from its counterpart up north. It doesn't feel as crowded, yet there were still plenty of people. You'll see plenty of wildlife, yet I didn't get the chance to spot a bear when I was there. This is definitely a place to see at least once in your lifetime.
We liked the variety of wildlife that we were able to view, as well as the beautiful scenery!

I think amuzedbydeath is just that. Hawaii vs Grand Tetons/YS...hmmm, ridonculous. You're not in Wyoming to surf, dodo, and you're not gonna find moose grazing on the beaches of Oahu. If you don't like amazing mountain vistas and lots of wildlife, even the chance of getting to see one eat another, then dont go to Wyoming. If you'd rather kayak in the Pacific than a pristine mountain lake, then don't go to Wyoming. If you want to see the same forces of nature that have turned Hawaii into a tropical paradise, but on a much much much grander scale, then go to Wyoming. Amazedbydeath, todeath, whatever, may be disappointed b/c he flew all the way from Cali (whoopie), but me and all the other Florida ppl I ran into, found Grand Tetons/YS to be exactly the amazing destination we have all heard, seen and dreamt so much about. Btw, did I mention that a huge hawk flew down into the river just 20-30 ft from me to snatch a trout from the river...while I had my vid camera on??? Did I mention that it snowed while I was there...in June??? Did I mention that one guy with a huge camera saw a pack of wolves chasing a herd of elk???
Lovely place , just make sure you have your bear spray with you just in case. The lake views are waw!

We passed by Grand Teton National Park en route to Ogden from Yellowstone. The mountains are as towering as they are portrayed in the movies. There's a road side viewpoint that offers the most picturesque area. Only a few parking space is available. It's worth a short stop.

Like the awe of the Grand Canyon, but your looking up. It's really amazing in it's majesty, rising up from the plains. It's so powerful an image. Your looking at it and you cant believe it. Go see for yourself. WOW!

This place is amazing. I have only been home a couple days and I miss it already. This park is just beautiful. The weather can change quickly, so I would highly recommend a light jacket (I was there the last week of May), and a sweater. The rangers and staff members in the visitor center are really nice and informative. I really liked how if they weren't sure on something, they would just check on it, and not try to stumble through not knowing. It was just a great experience!I cannot say enough about this amazing national park. It's well-worth visiting over and over. I loved it!

The views, the scenery and the wildlife are certainly not to be missed. For all, this park is a "must see". It's easily navigable - by foot, by bicycle (the bike trails are incredible) and by motorized vehicle. The photo opportunities are boundless!Thank you, Misters Rockefeller, for working so diligently to protect and preserve this wonderful natural resource.
review_title: How many times can you say "Gorgeous"?

review_body: My husband and I have traveled to all of the National Parks except about 10. In our opinion this is the most beautiful park. the sight of those mountains rising up from the meadows and the Snake river is just spectacular. If you are not a hiker it will only take one day to visit. You can even do a drive through on your way to Yellowstone.
