It only takes 1-2 hours to drive from one end of the park to the other depending on how much wildlife you see and how many stops you make to read the signs. We can't get enough of the views so we spend the night in order to wake up the next morning and see those mountains again.
The tetons are towering and pointy, as mountains should be, hovering over a series of lakes. The landscapes here are breath-takingly beautiful.
review_title: Some of the most majestic mountain scenery I've seen

review_body: Definitely take the loop drive so you can appreciate Jackson Hole
Most amazing mountains views! Really is a special place, with great hiking and great mountains.
good view from several places and easy to see since it wasn't the tourist crush of the summer good to go out early if you want a clear mountain view mts similar to glacier but glacier has it beat

Enjoyed our drive to see the Grand Tetons--the snow covered peaks were interesting, but not as spectacular as the Rockies in Canada. Enjoyed photographing the dam that we passed. Glad we visited on our way to Yellowstone.

We met a Park Ranger as we walked to Lake Jenny and he was a Cherokee from Oklahoma. He works summers at Grand Teton and maintains the out back trails. He was very interesting and loves his summers at the park.

We decided to take a last minute trip here in mid September. Awesome time to go, a lot less crowded, we were even able to get a cabin at Jackson Lake Lodge.The park it amazing. The views are unbelievable. Though quite a bit smaller than Yellowstone, there is still a lot of area to explore. I feel like GTNP is more for hiking, biking and rafting. Yellowstone is so crowded, it is more of a drive through and ohh ahh. Animals were out all day, but we have some amazing shows from the Elk around dawn each day. Favorite hike was up to inspiration point at Jenny Lake. A lot of people take the boat but the hike is where it is at! Hidden Falls is a gem, take some time there. The view of the lake is fantastic from the top of inspiration point, we had a great time relaxing up there taking it all in.We were only there 3 days and saw a lot but could have used a little more time. We will probably go in September again to avoid the crowds.

Girls weekend was in Idaho, and a weekend trip here was the icing on the cake. We drove through at a leisurely pace. Took pictures that didn't even look real - that's how beautiful everything is! We saw a few animals, but it was the mountains and the clouds and the sky that were just stunning.

There is just no way to describe the majesty of the Grand Tetons. Words fail. Photos do better. Beautiful in or out of the clouds, with or without bright sunshine, in all seasons.I'm so thankful that we have this park available to enjoy some of the most marvelous creation on the planet.I'm also thankful that the park staff had several restrooms open on the barely-open road! (and they were clean and non-smelly)I only wish that the connecting road between Tetons and Yellowstone had been open, but it wasn't yet. We lost a lot of hours driving around, instead of through.The park is gorgeous. Simply gorgeous.

You can't help but be in awe of these beautiful mountains. We spent 2 days enjoying the park and were delighted to see to a black bear and her cub, a mama moose and her baby, pronghorns and a bull moose. The mountains even treated us to an amazing thunderstorm. Nothing like a clap of thunder in the mountains. Take your time to visit the little chapel and make sure to visit the visitor center. We stayed on the Idaho side of the Tetons and driving the Teton Pass was amazing. Take your time to enjoy these stunning mountains.
Great times. Great views and great service. for sure 4-5 star. This is a great experience.
Beautiful scenery, great hiking trails for totally "get back to nature" experience, exhibits and movies at visitor centers.

A really nice park. There are trails all over and if you don't take a trail you have shorted yourself. There are hidden little lakes in the park, and if you are willing, you can go up the canyons and enjoy some spectacular scenery. Because the most common trails (Jenny Lake) are busy in the summer, go to the information center and ask for trails less commonly used. You will not be disappointed.
This overall area around the Tetons was one of our favourite location throughout the USA

We travelled into the park for an afternoon of snowshoeing, and it was just lovely. We rented from Skinny Ski's in Jackson and received great advice about where to snowshoe and also where to see wildlife, if we wanted. A great experience, and a vista not to be missed!
review_title: Lovely location for snowshoeing and x-c skiing

review_body: This was a beautiful park full of wildlife. We visited in the winter while everything was covered with snow and the whole family thoroughly enjoyed our time there.
review_title: Beautiful in the winter, saw bear, moose, elk and bison.

review_body: This was one of the most beautiful places I've ever been! Equipped with Andrew Nystrom's "Yellowstone and Grand Teton Must-Do Hikes for Everyone," we visited all the sites -- staying in a turn-of-the-century cabin at Jackson Lake's Coulter Bay complex (for those of moderate means, this is the ideal choice for both campers and non-campers). From here, we tried a double kayak for the first time, took a ranger-led geology walk up to Inspiration Point (must see!!) that began with a ferry ride across Jenny Lake. Don't stop at Inspiration Point, though, because Cascade Canyon trail takes you nearly to the mountain peaks. We took a 6-8-mile hike every day--Bradley and Taggart Lakes, Phelps Lake, String Lake and Two Ocean Lake. Driving up Signal Mountain on our last day in the park gave us our final awe-inspiring experience -- taking in a 360-degree view of where we had just spent our last two weeks -- the Jackson Hole, Snake River, Jackson and Jenny Lakes, and Yellowstone to the north.
review_title: Awesome vistas from the ground and the mountain tops

review_body: I dare you to name a more scenic range of mountains. Mt Moran is my favorite! whats yours?

If you are in the Yellowstone area, take the time to see the Tetons. You can enter the park going south from Yellowstone or you can go north from Jackson, Wyoming. I've been to Grand Teton National Park 5 times now and I always stayed in Jackson. It's a very touristy town. You can blow a lot of money there, so be frugal and think ahead.The park is accessed by a Hwy that runs right through the park with incredible views of the Teton peaks. The speed limit is 45 mph and some people push that even higher. If you want to get closer to the base of the Teton mountains, you drive on the Teton Park Road. You must pay an admission fee to drive that road. The Hwy is free to drive.You can access several trails and lakes from the Teton Park Road. Taggart Lake trail is a very popuar trailhead that takes you to a couple of gorgeous lakes - Taggart and Bradley. Jenny Lake is extremely popular. Stop there and pay $20 to take the ferry across the lake for a great hike up to Inspiration Point. In the same area, you can hike around String & Leigh Lakes. String lake was a very fun hike.I highly recommend you take the road up Signal Mountain. It's a great area to view wildlife and you get an incredible view of the mountains and the surrounding area.Further north on Teton Park Road, you can go check out Oxbow Bend for great photo opportunities of Mount Moran and more wildlife viewing, or you can go check out the enormous Jackson Lake. Jackson Lake is well-worth a visit. Take the Lakeshore trail for a pleasant hike with more mountain views. We saw a mule deer right on the trail!On your way back to Jackson, don't forget to take Antelope Flats Road and look for the bison herds. We had a big herd cross the road right in front of our car! Just make sure you give them plenty of space (at least 25 yards) and stay in your vehicle. Pronghorn are also often in that area.Grand Teton is a great national park. It clearly needs to be protected from development, however. This park's history is blemished by repeated attempts to commercialize the area. It's easy to get a sense that there is a pressure from Jackson trying to move north closer to the park. The National Elk Refuge helps prevent that. Let's hope and pray that the National Elk Refuge continues to receive immense support. That is another INCREDIBLE wildlife area, especially in winter.Let's keep Grand Teton a wilderness area! Support those who are working hard to ease the flow in and out of the park without destroying the natural environment. They were building bike paths along the Hwy this year, which is a great idea. Trying to reduce vehicle traffic is paramount. Please drive slow and plan ahead when visiting. Follow the signs and rules in the park so that we can all enjoy this park for years to come.
I could live here! Can't get enough of the landscape and animals. We saw moose, deer, pronghorn, elk, fox and of course buffalo. So many great memories
review_title: The most beautiful place on earth

review_body: Upon visiting Grand Teton national park I did not know what to expect. The park was so beautiful that the pictures I took looked like post cards. Jackson lake and Jenny lake are awesome places to take pictures with beautiful back grounds. I thought I would be able to go for a swim in the lakes but the water was so cold. Even for August. There are options for boating. The only draw back to the park was that there was lots of road construction going on. There could have been more wildlife but the park is right beside Yellowstone where there are tons of wild animals

Anyway you drive into the Grand Teton area is great but may I suggest route 20-26 if at all possible. We stayed overnight in Casper, Wyoming and decided to take the route fore mentioned to the Teton's. What a fabulous drive, neat little towns, mountains, mesa's, and unusual rock formations. Then as your being mesmerized by the drive you see the Grand Teton's in the distance. What a sight, the most grand range in America(in my opinion)! Anywhere you go in the area the Grand Teton range is always in your sights. Be sure to have your camera ready!

Usually you have to get up early in the morning to see wild animals wandering around. Not here. And there were everywhere, even though we were there in the middle of the summer. I cannot wait to go back in the fall one year. I cannot imagine what all we will see then. The scenery of the mountains and river are mind blowing. We saw: moose, elk (herds and herds of them), bison (tons of those too), bear, antelope, deer, birds of all kinds, etc. We went into the park many times at different times of the day and saw wild animals every time. Oh and going driving into the park, we were able to see snow. Being from Georgia where we are lucky if we see snow each year let alone in the middle of the summer, we were happy. Don't miss the Chapel of the Transfiguration. It is amazing to see the mountains behind. Overall a scenic and peaceful place and not as crowded as at lot of the other national parks this time of year.
Loved everything about this place. Lot's of things to do. Horseback riding was fantastic. Fishing was a blast. Siteseeing was a good as it gets.

The park is always a gem. There weren't any facilities open, except the stellar Craig Thomas visitor center near Moose, WY. The architecture of the center, the exhibits, the fine art, the film, the store all were outstanding. I actually spent about two hours in the building. Don't miss the steel markers that start inside the building, pointing at each mountain peak, and then outside explain factoids about the peak.Scenery in the park was good. At the end of October 95% of the leaves had fallen, but the mountains looked wonderful against the amber backdrop of the scrub,
review_title: Grand Teton good in the off season, too

review_body: It's one of my very places to visit. Try to stay at Jackson Lake Lodge...it is the perfect spot to see all the beauty of the Tetons. Even if you don't stay there, you still can enjoy the lobby area...very large window looking out at the Grand Teton and eat at the restaurant. When looking out at the back patio, you might see Moose...
Nice day hikes but we didn't see any wildlife. Jenny lake trail to the waterfall was awesome. About six miles RT and not too difficult.
this was an awesome place to go ..the fall colors were amazing. There was so much to see. A Photographers dream ! We plan on going back again !
The pictures say it better than can I. It may have been the weather, but the contrast of the lake, mountains and sky are beautiful a scene as you could ever imagine. Heavenly!

Twenty-five years ago, one of number-one hits on the Billboard Hot Country Top 100 was a song by Mickey Gilley called “Don’t the Girls All Get Prettier at Closing Time?” If you ask the same question about Grand Teton National Park during late September and early October - when the campgrounds and lodges are shutting down for the winter and a gold and orange carpet of aspens and cottonwoods blankets the banks of the Snake River and the foothills beneath arguably the most distinctive mountain range in America - the answer for many travelers is a resounding “yes!”  It’s not only the Tetons’ towering peaks (a dozen over 12,000 feet in elevation) and luminous leaves that beckon travelers this time of year. There’s rare solitude in places you would least expect it, such as the Snake River Overlook, a popular turnout off Highway 191/26/89. During the summer thousands flock to the spot where Ansel Adams’ shot one of his best-known photos in 1942. On a sunny morning in the first week of October, I had the entire parking lot to myself.  The following day I navigated the narrow, five-mile, corkscrew-shaped road to the summit of Signal Mountain, where the reward for the white-knuckle climb is the most panoramic view in the park - the Tetons, Jackson Lake, and the Snake River meandering across the sprawling valley 800 feet below. There was only one other couple at the observation area.  The window of opportunity for this precious privacy is very short. “The first three weeks of September are [booked] to the wall,” according to Heather Falk, tourism manager for the Jackson Hole Chamber of Commerce. “The occupancy rate for September is more than 90 percent.”  This includes 6,800 rooms spread out through the 55-mile long Jackson Hole Valley, including Teton Village at the base of Jackson Hole Mountain Resort, properties on the highways leading to the park, and lodging within the park and downtown Jackson, which is 10 miles from the only commercial airport in a U.S. National Park and four miles from the south entrance to the park.  Accommodations are more likely to be available after the annual Jackson Hole Fall Arts Festival from September 8-18 that will attract as many as 15,000 people. An anticipated 500 runners plus friends will be in town for the first Jackson Hole Marathon on September 24, followed by Destination Fall Wellness Week, a local initiative that attracts far fewer visitors than the Fall Arts Festival. Most hotels and motels lower their rates either after the Festival or on October 1. Last year Grand Teton National Park ranked seventh in attendance among the nation’s national parks with nearly 2.7 million visitors. Most of them, however, are gone by the end of September. August attendance soared to nearly 600,000, dipped to 421,830 in September, and dropped to under 150,000 in October.  Fall in the Tetons generally lasts from the beginning of September to mid-October. Temperatures hover between the 60’s and 20’s. If you’re lucky, there will have been sufficient rainfall and cool evening temperatures to create the colorful foliage that historically peaks in the third week of September. The weather, however, is capricious. Last year a sprinkle of snow fell on August 29, but it rarely accumulates much before November. Only 0.5 inches fell in September, 4.4 in October, and 25.2 in November.  In the fall, aroused and sometimes aggressive animals abound in the park during the rutting (breeding) season for the deer species, including the elk and bull moose. In the early evening, you might hear the haunting bugle of a male elk letting females know he’s dominant and available. On occasion, elk will literally lock their huge racks of horns in a skirmish to determine the leading man – an extremely rare and unforgettable sight. With only a few weeks before hibernation, bears in the park are gouging themselves with berries and other sources of food to build the fat that enables them to survive the harsh winter. There are 61 species of mammals found in each of the four major habitats in the park: the alpine, coniferous forests, sagebrush flats, and wetlands. Your odds of undisturbed time with the Grand Teton animal kingdom increase significantly from the end of September to mid-October. My serendipitous moment came when I stumbled upon a small herd of bison off of Antelope Flats Road in an area called Mormon Row, one of the most photographed settings in the park. In the foreground, an abandoned wooden barn from an old Mormon homestead conveniently posed in the tall golden grass poking up through frosted snow. The Cathedral Group, adorned with eight of the highest 10 mountains in the Teton Range, bestowed the breathtaking backdrop.  Had my chance encounter with the bison in the midst of this stunning scenery occurred a month earlier, a horde of rubberneckers likely would have invaded my spot within minutes. However, not a soul was around this time of year! It felt like a private viewing of the changing of the guard at Buckingham Palace. I lingered ecstatically, shooting every conceivable angle of my 2,000-pound subjects until they got bored and walked away.  A word of advice, though. It’s best to take pictures of capricious bison from inside your vehicle or very close to it, especially if you are lucky enough to be alone. Their size creates an illusion of sluggish docility, but if riled they can charge at 30 miles per hour, exceedingly faster than you can sprint. This strategy applies to bears, moose, elk, mule deer, pronghorn, or any large species of mammal you might run into. There’s a good reason they’re called wildlife. One of the most spectacular settings in the park for beauty, birds, and beasts is Oxbow Bend, one mile east of Jackson Lake Junction where the Snake River forms a U-shape that looks like the ox collar used by western pioneers. In the summer and early fall, tourists cram the turnout and shoulder of the road to photograph the reflection of 12,605-foot Mt. Moran in the slow-moving water. During autumn, brilliant aspens add another layer of color on the western bank of river. White pelicans, osprey, and on occasion, and bald eagles dive for fish in the shallow water. Moose occasionally roam among the willows. My wife Susan and I soaked in this scene on a late afternoon…by ourselves!  If you’re searching for an exclusive engagement with moose on a scenic road - and don’t mind a bumpy 1.5-mile dirt interruption – try the otherwise paved 15-mile Moose-Wilson Road in the southwest corner of the park. It winds through aspens and across streams near the Snake River between the park headquarters in Moose and Wilson, Wyoming, eight miles outside the park on Route 22. Bear, deer, and other animals also frequent the area, There’s even a Moose Habitat turnout. We watched a pair of moose foraging in the grass and flopping along in a stream.  Only one other couple was there to enjoy the show. That’s what makes Grand Teton National Park so special this time of year.
review_title: Tetons are Prettier at Closing Time

review_body: I cannot convey how amazing beautiful and serene Grand Teton National Park is. The airport is located within the park and when we arrived and saw the mountain range while grabbing our suitcases and buffalo wandering through the parking lot it was immediate awe and wonderment - and it only got better. We were lucky enough to see several moose including a day old calf, buffalo, coyotes, bald eagles, elk, mule deer, a black bear, and a grizzly bear with two cubs. I highly recommend taking an Eco tour with Jackson Hole wildlife tours. We went on the sunrise tour and learned so much about the area; we were the only ones on the tour, and our guide stayed with us past the time we were due back because we were lucky enough to find a grizzly with her two cubs. There is so much to see and do in the area and the people in Wyoming are the nicest I have met anywhere. I would happily pick up and move there! I think the beginning of June is the perfect time to go because it was not crowded at all, the weather was lovely even when it snowed (very lightly), and our guides said the wildlife viewing is abundant because the animals move up into the mountains as the weather gets warmer in the summer months. Visit Wyoming - you will not be disappointed!

We loved the Grand Tetons. We took the boat trip out on Coulter Bay and learned a lot about the mountains and the area, a good idea. We drove all the roads, loved the Craig Thomas Discovery Center, saw moose there and in Moose, and did a white water float......skip that...it's not through a very pretty part of the river. You could stay in Jacksonville and easily see all of the park. Avoid Jackson Lake Lodge.

When you arrive in Grand Teton National Park from the South you see the Mountains rise from a plain. There are wonderful lakes in the National Park where the mountains are reflect themselves. You can take boat-tours to waterfalls or for a breakfast on Elk Island (what we did - wonderful!).There are many hiking trails and lookouts all over the Park.You should carry a cagoule or umbrella with you even in summer as the wheather can change rapidly.If you are lucky you can see a lot of wildlife. We saw a bold eagle, elk, chipmunks and deer; there are moose, pronghorns and bear, too. Many people just cross the park to reach Yellowstone. We were happy to stay over night!

The Aerial Tramway Ride in Grand Teton Village was fantastic! The cost was $29.00 per person. At the summit of the ride, you can HIKE and visit Corbett's Cabin. Corbett's Cabin is at the "top of the world" and sells tasty waffles. The staff at this eatery is friendly, engaging, and entertaining. This cafe is located in a small cabin that is next to the tram terminal. Waffles are $4.25 or $4.50 depending on which topping you choose.

we visit the area several times a year and are always finding wonderful pleasures to keep us coming back. we floated the snake river on oct. 1st and the weather was over 75+..wow, and the scenery of the tetons, the grasses , gently blowing , the moose bogs, the geese, the occasional people, quietly fishing the river, the billowing clouds, and the quietness of the world. heaven.

The views from the road and the outlook points are spectacular, especially those of Jenny Lake. The road network is excellent and there are no sharp curves or major ascents or descents like those at Glacier, nor any major road closings.
review_title: One of our most beautiful national parks.

review_body: We stayed in the park at Signal Mountain Lodge. It was very convenient to for the Teton's and Jackson, Wyoming. The cabin was comfortable but without TV or internet access except in the reception building, my wife and I ended up playing a lot of gin rummy. We booked thier float trip down the Snake River. It was a great 3 hour trip with a guide named Peter. He was very knowledgible and interesting. Even though we didn't see any moose or elk we did see several species of birds including bald eagle, golden eagle, ospry, etc.Even though we are city folk, this area of the the US is beautiful country. Everyone needs to see it and Yellowstone at least once.

Some of the best hiking and camping I have ever done. Try staying at the Jenny Lake Campground (central location, fills early) or the Gros Ventre Campground (less convenient, but incredible views and fills late).Some of the best hikes are Jenny Lake to Lake Solitude (7 hrs) and Taggert Lake to Amphitheater Lake (5+ hours). Give yourself a day to adjust to the altitude if you coming from sea level.

Once inside Grand Tetons National Park (GTNP) take the boat ride from South Jenny Lake Junction across Jenny Lake to see the beautiful Hidden Falls. Then hike a bit further up a steep trail to Inspiration Point. The views from this location are amazing. This was a moderate hike. We hiked another 20 minutes past Inspiration Point toward the canyon and we were rewarded by seeing a large moose lounging in a shallow waterway. What a magnificant creature.Another breathtaking view is from the Chapel of the Transfiguration near Moose entrance. An amazing little chapel open during the day with a clear glass window view inside of the Tetons with a wooden cross in the center. They do have worship service on Sunday mornings. This was a neat historical building. It's a very short walk from the parking lot to the chapel.
The Best Place for a Vacation - we liked the location and the ambience of the place and recommened this place highly for a vactaion.
review_title: The Best Place for a Vacation

review_body: We spent 3 full days in GTNP and could have stayed more. The hiking and scenery were top notch and we saw much more wild life here than we did in Yellowstone.We saw black bears, male and female moose and elk, and bison.We hiked to Hidden Falls and Inspiration Point before hiking on into Cascade Canyon. We also hiked the Leigh Lake and String Lake Trails. All if which I would highly recommend. The Leigh and String Lake trails were much easier hikes than the hike to Hidden Falls, Inspiration Point and Cascade Canyon. And, the only wildlife we saw while hiking was the moose. We saw no signs of bear activity.The weather in mid-September was perfect and the park was not crowded at all.We rented a condo through VRBO in Jackson Hole. The location was perfect and the drive into the park every day provided plenty in the way of wildlife sightings listed above.

This is a very nice National Parks with lots of water in several lakes. We loved the drive around the area. There are several places where on can get food, gas or lodging in the park. By the way there is a fee to enter. Maintain the proper speed limit as there are many park rangers that have nothing to do other that set up radar. When I first visited the area many years ago this was not the case. It’s apparently turning in to a revenue generating activity for the Nation Park Service If traveling north you will leave the Teton National park and enter Yellowstone. Be sure and allow plenty of time especially during the summer high season. The road will more than likely be closed in the winter according to one of the guides we listed to. If you have never been to this part of the United States you should certainly make it a point to add to your travel list. Last week it was cool and we were glad to be away from the Texas heat.

Grand Teton National Park is beautiful, but I expected it to be. It did not wow me the way the Sierra Nevada Mountains or Mount Rainier did. I found very little in the way of quality hiking here. I characterize it as a rich man's national park. Not much effort is needed here by the visitor to get the most out of this park. I always appreciate a tough hike with a rewarding vista. Or braving the elements to watch a sunrise, fighting off sleep to watch a sunset. Teton does not offer that, just get in your car, drive, stop, look, take photo, repeat.
This is a great national park. A little hard to get too. Many things to enjoy including beautiful views, hiking, and widelife.
Majestic. Great weather. Fantastic animal sights. Prices reasonable for the food and lodging.

We went to both Yellowstone and the Tetons. My favorite was the Tetons. Lots of hiking for all ages and skill levels, beautiful scenery and not nearly as crowded as Yellowstone. Although it was crowded. We avoided the town of Jackson as traffic there was terrible but all other areas were fairly reasonable. I would like to go back in the fall and winter to see the large elk herds. All facilities were nice and the lake is beautiful. We recommend you take a boat ride on the lake. Also recommend, if you have the time, to see the Tetons from the Idaho side - uncrowded and a different perspective.

We are accustomed to the Blue Ridge and Great Smoky Mountains, as we have a second home/rental cabin in North Carolina, but there's no comparison to The Grand Tetons. No foothills and no transition into the mountains. They rise straight out of the flatlands and the road is very close to them. What an amazing view along the entire length. GREAT views from Jenny Lake as well as from our rafting trip on the Snake River.

We spent three days in the Grand Teton National Park. We stayed at the Colter Bay cabins, which were very well maintained. You're sure to see plenty of wildlife including deer, moose, elk, pronghorn and bald eagles. For the adventurous, there are a variety of hiking trails to navigate, from easy to difficult. At Jackson Lake you can rent a boat for a couple of hours, or take a tour and let one of the well informed guides entertain you. For families with children, enrolling them in the Junior Ranger program is well worth the effort. It keeps them engaged and educates them in a fun and informative way. This is one of the most beautiful areas in America!

This park has everything that a person could want, beauty, great hiking trails, well marked drives and scenic lookout points and lots of wildlife. Staff at all points in the park areas were friendly and well informed.

Great trip - the mountains were fantastic as were the trails! Stayed 3 nights and 3 full days - a minimum to see some of the park - but longer would be better - at least one more full day. The last day the smoke from a distant forest fire made visibility of the mountains minimal, but luckily the wind was in our favor the other days. The staff were all very friendly and willing to answer any questions that we had. Can't wait to go back again!
This the most beautiful national park I have ever visited. The views of the Tetons are breathtaking.

Jenny Lake trail and boat ride was wonderful.The Laurence Rockefeller Preserve was very beautiful and the trail the right distance for our group. I suggest it as a quiet and meaningful part of the trip.
review_title: We had a fantastic time. Great shorter trails for little ones and everyone friendly.

review_body: My husband and I visited Grand Teton National Park for the first time in mid-May 2011. The area is just spectacular; words cannot describe its beauty. We stayed 3 nights in a cabin at Signal Mountain Lodge (review provided under Lodge). Not only is the scenery stunning, but wildlife abounds! We had the best time and would go back in a heartbeat! Mid-May is a nice time to go as much is snow-covered, there are fewer tourists, and bison are giving birth (the little ones are adorable). While we could not do everything one can do in the summer, i.e. Jenny Lake and Jackson Lakes were frozen while we were there, I think I would pick May again for a return visit.
Beautiful vistas, numerous hiking trails and biking paths and hardly any crowds - does that sound too good to be true? well that is GTNP!

This park is amazing. I think it often plays second fiddle to Yellowstone, but it is very beautiful and the hiking and other activities are definitely not second rate. If you are coming to Jackson please don't just view this park as a gateway to Yellowstone - it is so much more. My family enjoyed biking on the relatively new bikepath - you have awesome views of the Tetons the entire time! There are some great family friendly hikes - an easy one is the shuttle across Jenny Lake then up to the falls. Too much to mention. We are going back next year and will spend a few days in Jackson Lake lodge so we can take advantage of even more the park has to offer. My kids loved it!
Loved the view here..I personally liked this better than yellowstone. Road trip continues.

The Tetons aren't the tallest mountains in the US but they may well be the most photogenic. It's hard not to take a good picture of them and they look different all day long as the sun moves overhead. They can also seem "angry" and "sinister" as storm clouds gather around them. The best closeup views are on Grand Teton road, but some of the panoramas from US 191 are also excellent. Wildlife can be found anywhere; we encountered a large herd of bison crossing US191 one day. Although it didn't work for us, there is a lesser known road known as Moose Wilson Road that is known for good wildlife sightings. There are several visitor centers, each with a different theme, but the new one at Moose Junction overshadows the rest of them in our opinion (see separate reviews).
Lots to do, great scenery, friendly people, great wildlife.

I loved a visit to Grand Teton! It is absolutely gorgeous and majestic! The people are very friendly and helpfull at any visitor center I stopped. I loved hike there and take a bath at Jenny Lake. The rangers helped me to chose 2 hike trails for 2 days: one was organized, one I was alone. The newspaper you get at the entrance have all the relevant information about the park and about the activities with rangers. The kids can find their part of entertainment with rangers, too, and learn a lot! Every organized hike with rangers is full of different knowledge about the nature and geological changes. The movie at the visitor center introduced me to the park and it's worth to watch! The restaurants, gas station, groceries are all near the south entrance and near the visitor center. Stop also at the visitor center in Jackson. It is on Cache Rd in direction of the park. There you can get also a lot of helpful information about the daily activities and safeness!!!I LOVED IT!!!

Grand Teton is the picture perfect image you have seen of soaring snow-capped mountains rising out of crystal clear lakes. It is absolutely worth taking a few days to see. But the absolutely unique nature of Yellowstone overshadows GT. I recommend you visit the Tetons first BEFORE you are awed by Yellowstone. As for sheer scenic beauty, GT might win. But Yellowstone has all the geologic features AND many more animals. So, put side by side Yellowstone will win, in my opinion, every time. Does that mean you should skip GT? Absolutely NOT! Just let it impress you with its calm beauty as you begin your visit, so it can knock your socks off as it should, instead of feeling like an after-thought.

Every view is breathtaking, every photograph is more beautiful than the previous. We spend 2 full days in the park and would have need more to be able to go back to some spots for a second time. The kids did not want to leave. We went boating, hiking, rode bikes, etc... This National Park is gorgeous. Staying in Jackson Hole is perfect, it's not to far and there is a lot of choices for dinner and lot to do in town at night.

One of my favorite places. The views and outdoor activities are well above expectations.The only negative is that most lodging options seem to be run by ex post office executives. A little free enterprise competition would be quite helpful.

I know that is a grand statement, but it is true. If you read all the other reviews you will know how much there is to do in the Jackson hole, but not too many describe how it feels. The Tetons have a hypnotic effect on you that is hard to describe. It is hard to take your eyes off of them. I have always wanted to travel to the Teton-Yellowstone area, and was finally able to. Now I have to go back. I now know how Muir felt "The mountains are calling and I must go".
review_title: The most beautiful place I have ever seen.

review_body: Best National Park in America.Period!Exceptional beauty, magnificent mountain range, spectacular still lakes at sunrise, sublime, powerful, amazing.Jackson Hole is a great little town to stay and visit restaurants. I've camped in Teton NP, I've stayed in Jackson, both are great!Really, there are no words. Just go and enjoy! Ansel Adams' famous Snake River image is proof positive.

It is very frustrating to pay $$$ to our national parks, only to find out that there are strict regulations on where you can have a pet. For the most part it is within 6 ft off the roadway. There are no shady places to park where the pet would be cool. So you end up driving through the park and seeing only what you can from the car. I should have done more research on the regulations of our parks before driving over 2000 miles.

Grand Teton ( Yellowstone NP) are a must see on any nature lover's list. GTNP is situated along the Teton mountain range. The mountains are snow-capped even in the middle of the summer. Unfortunately the day that we were there it rained most of the day....quite unusual for the summer. Yet, it was still worth seeing. We did miss out on the boat ride and dinner cruise....have to save that for next time.
review_title: The Park is truly Awe Inspiring

review_body: Having seen many of the national parks, Grand Teton is one of the most beautiful, and easy to visit. It is as if the Tetons rise straight up from Jackson Lake. Don't miss the view from Jackson Lake Lodge. This is a day trip from Jackson Wy

We camped in GTNP for two nights. This place is one of the most beautiful parks we've ever been to. The snow capped Tetons were so big, majestic, and mesmerizing. There are so many wonderful hikes and activities to take part in. Jackson Lake is just pristine, but watch out for the boat rentals as they are very expensive! Jackson iHole is just a short drive away where you will find lots of restaurants, gas stations, rafting outfits, and anything else you desire! We can't wait to go back so we can spend more time marveling in the beauty of this gorgeous National Park!

The Grand Tetons National Park and Jackson Hole make for a perfect family vacation. We flew into Jackson and spent two nights at the Rustic Inn in a lovely log cabin on a beautiful creek overlooking the mountains. The Inn was 10minutes from the airport and within walking distance to downtown Jackson. The rate includes an unbelievable huge breakfast with lots of choices.Dinner at the Blue Lion was fabulous with a wonderful guitarist serenading us softly during our meal.Cafe Genevieve was a perfect place for lunch with great reasonable comfort food. Mad River Rafting was excellent for white water rafting and they supply wet suits,booties and slickers which I highly recommend as you will get wet and have a blast! Take the tram up the mountain in Jackson Village for unbelievable views and the best waffles and hot cocoa when you get out at the top.After two nights in Jackson, we headed to the Grand Teton National Park to stay at Signal Mountain Lodge. This could be the best family vacation spot ever! It is set on Jackson Lake surrounded by the Tetons with wrap around views that go on forever. We had a wonderful upper lake view unit 160 with two double beds, a big comfy leather sofa, stove top, microwave and full size fridge and bath.I would highly recommend an upper unit unless you have small children or a dog, then I would suggest a ground floor unit or separate log cabin. Our unit was smoke and pet free. Everything is very clean, but not fancy. There is a convenience store, gas station, gift shop, and three restaurants. with organic and gluten free options.The Peaks , has unbelievable views in a beautiful fire placed dining room with great food and service. The staff are friendly and helpful and seem genuinely happy to be working there.Andy set us up with a motorboat at the marina steps from our room to zip around the lake and explore some of the hidden coves. You could also canoe , kayak or rent a larger pontoon boat. Johanna , at the front desk, set us up with horseback riding at a family ranch about 25 minutes away followed by lunch at an adorable place called the Buffalo Cafe with great burgers and huckleberry shakes on a screened porch.Yellow Stone National Park is just minutes from Signal Mountain. Pack a picnic,water,beach towels , sunscreen and lots of bug spray and plan on a full day of exploring. We spent time swimming in Moose Falls and found a perfect picnic spot, but did't have enough time for the hour and a half trip to Old Faithful. The next day we took a shuttle boat to Jenny's Lake for some great hiking to beautiful Cascade Falls and amazing views from Inspiration Point.We had the best pizza and homemade ice cream 20 minutes from Signal ,at Leeks. The line was out the door, but well worth the wait. Once inside the big retro styled dining room overlooking the lake, we joined families of many different nationalities sitting at picnic tables sharing pizza and bopping to the oldies ,piped in from the ipods of the fantastic group of young people working there. Watching the staff singing and dancing as they worked made us all smile and enjoy the fabulous pizza even more. In fact ,everything about Signal Mountain will make you smile as you look around at the incredible natural beauty. Signal Mountain is a Green Resort and does it's part to make sure it stays that way. Can't wait to come back!
review_title: Spectacular setting with something for everyone!

review_body: It is truly unfortunate that people rush through Grand Teton National Park on their way to Yellowstone. My husband and I spent three nights in the Tetons in the summer of 2010 and were so sad to leave that we decided to return this summer for eight nights, all of them spent in the Colter Bay Cabins.. It was definitely not too long. We enjoyed each and every day; taking the hikes with the rangers, visiting the Lawrence Rockefeller Center as well as the Murrie cabin, and just being surrounded by absolute beauty. It was wonderful to be able to do everything at a liesurely pace. The ranger led hikes were generally three miles in length but took over two hours. Maybe because we're senior travelers we enjoyed the pace, but we learned so much along the way. We did go to Teton village twice, one morning and one evening in order to attend the Jackson Mlusic Festival, but other than that we spent our days in the Tetons. Wherever you look you are surrounded by magnificent scenery. We had read many of the reviews of the restaurants in the park and found it easier to take our meals in the various restaurants. Most of the restaurants have wonderful views of the mountains. I would return for another week in a heartbeat.

Get there early if you want a campsite. Even the don't usually fill campgrounds were filled by early evening. I have to give fair warning I hate RV's. They congest the roadways,run their stupid generators,block the views, go way to slow and just annoy me. That being said I'm 61, like tent camping, a campfire with story telling and marshmellows. My point is the parks are being overrun with homes on wheels, I believe taking away the experience of the great outdoors. Now about the Tetons. A beautiful and majestic park with well maintained facilities. Come prepared to soak in the views and burn up the camera batteries. Don't blow off this park to see Yellowstone. Make sure you have the time to see both. The Park rangers were great taking time to help all.

Grand Teton leaves anyone in awe, the peaks of the mountains combined with all the scenery are amazing. To enjoy it, its definitely worth doing walks, hikes and also rafting, anything that permits you to explore these natural surroundings. We saw a black bear from the road too.The town of Jackson is a lively place , has good restaurants and activities like the rodeo twice a week. If you have teenagers or you like action, its a great place to stay.

The Grand Tetons are simply breathtaking. We spent 4 days there at the end of June before heading to Yellowstone for 2 days. I am so glad that we spent most of our time in the Tetons. While Yellowstone is gorgeous in its own right, the lower loop area also has the crowds and can almost have an amusement park atmosphere at times. The Tetons, however, are simply majestic. You don't have the crowds, just peace and quiet and wonderful scenery. Some of the dayhikes we wanted to do were still closed because of heavy snow on the trails. However we did hike to hidden falls, which was just breathtaking, and we also hiked some of the lake trails. I can't wait to go back!!

Only spent couple of days each at Grand Tetons & Yellowstone, and needless to say that’s not enough time. Although both national parks are remarkable for different reasons, my favorite goes to the Tetons hands down. First, you have to be impressed with mountains as the constant backdrop – snowcapped, stately, and majestic in so many respects. There’s abundant wildlife (even during the day), breath-taking scenery (too many vantage points), and gorgeous hiking all around (only two we had time for). One of the best hikes is the cascade canyon trail, which you can shorten by taking the Jenny Lake shuttle across. One can side track to go to Hidden fall and Inspiration Point like most visitors but the stunning views comes when you hike deep (and up) the canyon trail. We were there in early June so it was packed snow but with good hiking boots you will be fine. Make sure you bring adequate water, layer your clothing (though most of us were still in t-shirts because it is strenuous), and start early so you can catch the boat ride back. Another great hike is Taggart Lake / Bradley Lake trail which again takes you to see some spectacular views. After the first couple of miles the trail does split, consider going and coming back on different segments of the trail as the different elevation will give you totally different views. The upper trail is very picturesque with mountains then against the lake background when you go higher up. The lower trail is very tranquil and charming when you walk along Taggart Lake. A note on the vantage points, when driving there are several overlooks on US191, which is excellent for the all encompassing view of the Teton Range. From deep within the park there are again numerous places along the Teton Park Road between Jackson Lake Junction and Jenny Lake Lodge. An unique view is to drive up Signal Mountain Rd., although the best vista point for the Tetons itself is not from the very top since it faces a different direction. Finally, further north on the road going towards Yellowstone there are couple more places that give you a view of Jackson Lake against yet another perspective of the Tetons

This is probably one of the most scenic places we have been to recently. The majestic snow capped mountains overlooking the jackson and jenny lakes provide an unforgettable experience. The drive along the jenny lake lodge is an absolute must see. If you are visiting yellowstone and have some time, we highly recommend driving down to the grand teton area through the South entrance of the yellowstone park. The route is very scenic and offers ample opportunities to see wildlife.

Scenery was beautiful and the weather was perfect the day we were there. There had been some recent snow so some of the trails were not open. The park rangers were very helpful in letting us know which ones were open or closed. Would definitely like to go back again.

I highly recommend renting four wheelers and riding the trails in the Teton Park. They ROCK!! We packed snacks and spend half a day riding allover them. We even had one very inexperienced rider with us, and she enjoyed it too. Stay close together, because the forest is thick and you won't be able to see eachother otherwise. Bring a rain coat too, it sneaks up on you. The scenery from those trails is amazing!!

Went to Grand Tetons after Yellowstone mid/end of May. There was still a lot of snow in both parks, so finding an open campground was hard. We were shooting for Jenny Lake, but ended up staying at Signal mountain campground. Only half the campground was open, but I managed to find a great site next to the lake (#17). There are almost 100 pitches, but the location is great. Had a wonderful meal at Jackson Lodge, and ducked into their bar till the rain let up a little bit. Next day was rained out again, so I headed to Steamboat Springs. When the skies did finally clear and reveal the Tetons, you could of sworn you just found heaven. What a magical place. Would love to go back and explore the trails and the water ways.
Jackson Lake Lodge has a great "bar and lounge" inside. Make sure to stop by. Great place to stop by for a drink(the best Bloody Mary I've ever had) and a good appetizer menu!
Take wonderful pictures there for sunrise and sunset.

We drove through the park from Yellowstone to Jackson Hole WY. The day was sunny and the mountains seemed to rise straight up from the ground instead of a gradual layer of foothills and smaller mountains. Majestic!

Don't miss Schwabacher Landing for some great photographs and a beautiful easy walk along the Snake River. There are great water reflection shots of the Grand Tetons. The landing is just a short drive off the road.Another great close-to-the-road photo opportunity is Cunningham cabin. The rustic cabin is situated with the Grand Tetons as a backdrop.Oxbow Bend turnout offers a great shot of the Snake River and the Grand Tetons. Jackson Dam offers picture opportunities from both sides. Lots of water action on the river side and a placid lake on the dam side. Watch out for mesquitos. The drive up Signal Mountain to the Jackson Point Overlook is well worth your time. You have a terrific view of the entire area.
review_title: Great spots for Photography in Grand Tetons

review_body: Grand Teton is beautiful. We stayed in the park and loved the views, the hikes and the abundant wildlife. We saw an ENTIRE wolf pack in the Teton National Forest. Bears are present near trails around North Jenny Lake.Ride the ferry from South Jenny Lake across the lake and take the hike to Inspiration Point. The hike is rocky but doable. Wear old shoes than can get muddy. The view is unbelievable of the glacier and the mountain's geology. We saw a mother moose and baby, marmots, chipmonks, lots of birds, and a huge falls. Few peoples are conducting lectures from 9th August to discuss about the changing climate of the Grand Teton Natinal park, which a attraction in Australia. Summer, autumn, and winter are the best times to visit the Northern Rockies. The days are sunny, the nights are clear, and the humidity is low. Typically, from mid-June on, you can hike, fish, camp, and watch wildlife, and if you come before July 4 or after Labor Day, you won't have to share the view all that much. Wildflowers bloom at these elevations in early summer -- beginning in May in the lower valleys and plains, while in the higher elevations they open up in July.

Just returned from spending 4 nights in GTNP and then 4 in Yellowstone. First time for both. Grand Teton is so beautiful and there are so many beautiful trails/roads/etc that it's worth all the time you can afford. We stayed in a cabin at Colter Bay Marina. Loved it, the area has everything you could need, grocery, laundry, gift shop, gas station. I loved the sunset from Jenny Lake the best, it is lovely. Great area for photography, I'm pretty bad but I got a couple shots that are very nice. Lots of wildlife, lots of roads you can just pull of an wander. There a great little restaurant 1 mile from Colter Bay, at Leeks Marina. They have great pizza and the view from their deck of the mountains was terrific. A must is also driving up Signal Mtn. to the overlooks. Very nice. This is just a beautiful place, I hope I get to go back someday. It would be a great honeymoon destination for some lucky people! Oh, and we did see quite a bit of snow still on the mountains and it was July 2-6, the weather was around 65-70 degrees and just gorgeous stars out at night. You can almost touch them!! Enchanting!!

We have just returned from a 2 week fly drive holiday in Wyoming and Montana and had to finish at Salt Lake City for our flight home.Our main "must do" when planning the holiday was to see Yellowstone National Park, and we were not disappointed as the park is amazing.We have to admit that we were really just travelling through Grand Teton National Park as a means and route to get to Salt Lake City and as an afterthought had booked a couple of nights in Jackson to break up the journey and we are so glad that we did.Grand Teton is just as scenic as Yellowstone and is far less crowded, we also saw plenty of wildlife so don't regard Grand Teton as the poor relation of Yellowstone it is well worth spending time in the area and Jackson is a very nice town with plenty of restaurants, bars and hotels.
review_title: Excellent park with great views and wildlife

review_body: We saw an ENTIRE wolf pack in the Teton National Forest. Bears are present near trails around North Jenny Lake.Ride the ferry from South Jenny Lake across the lake and take the hike to Inspiration Point. The hike is rocky but doable. Wear old shoes than can get muddy.The view is unbelievable of the glacier and the mountain's geology.We saw a mother moose and baby, marmots, chipmonks, lots of birds, and a huge falls.This is a must do.The main visitors center is stunning and the whole South Jenny Lake complex is very great, too.
review_title: Grand Teton better for wildlife viewing than Yellowstone. Get close to bears and wolves.

review_body: Grand Teton is beautiful. We stayed in the park and loved the views, the hikes and the abundant wildlife. This park is often overlooked because it is adjacent to Yellowstone. That can be a benefit because its not as crowded.

The road from Yellowstone to Grand Teton had only been open for 3 days when we visited in May 2010 - the views were spectacular, particularly with snow sparkling in the sunlight. However, the first views of the Teton Mountain Range were breathtaking and the views continually improved . Grand Teton is quite different to Yellowstone but well worth a visit nonetheless.

This National Park is the most beautiful one. Yellowstone is nice, but the scenery here is outstanding. Take some of the walks, the one to Taggart Lake is very easy and the view is great. Inspiration point is just that an inspiration, but the walk is strenuous and if you have a fear of heights, this walk is not for you. The boat ride to this area from Jenny Lake visitor center is nice, but you need to be able to walk up some steep stairs to get to the walking trails, and they are not easy hikes. So if you have a hard time walking, need a cane, do not spend the money on the boat ride. Stop and see the view from Jackson Lake Lodge, just spend some time in the lobby looking out their windows, you will not be disappointed. Stop at Mormon Row, the view is great.

As soon as you arrive at the Jackson Hole airport, and look over at the Teton range it is breathtaking and unbelievable, it is the most beautiful thing I have seen in the U.S so far.We entered the park everyday of our 5 day trip, and we never tired of that view, at times we said it was hard to believe that we standing right in front of something that beautiful almost looked like a green screen.1 st day we were able to see Bison and Moose.We took at float trip with Dave Hansen, that was nice and relaxing on the snake river.We went to the rockefeller preserve and went on the phelps lake trail, gorgeous.We stopped at many different overlooks, snake river overlook is the best, its the picture point of one of ansel adams Grand Teton pictures.We saw Moose and Bison many times, plus a coyote and some Elk once.Another day we stopped at oxbow bend on our way to Yellowstone, that is abosolutely beautiful, with the reflection of the mtn in the lake.One other thing we did in the park was the Jenny lake trail, we walked the trail one way and took the ferry back, I would suggest to at least walk it one way if you can, then once the other side, we did hidden falls and inspiration point, I really enjoyed going up inspiration point, great views of jenny lake and of the Teton range.We did some of the Beaver creek trail also, but it was a little scary for us,we're not big hikers or anything, both in good shape, but that trail was so quiet, and we were on it for over an hour and only passed 1 other couple, we stopped and saw some bear claws on a tree, so we decided to turn back from where we were, and once we got to the parking area, we passed another couple who were about to start the trail, I knew to make noise so as to not walk up on and scare a bear, but will still decided to turn back, just incase.Overall Grand Teton is an amazing park, we loved it, I feel like the 5 days we had were enough to see everything you would want to see in GT, and we even went to Yellowstone for 2 out of those 5, only returning to GT to drive back to our hotel in Jackson hole each evening.Grand Teton is a wonderful park, lots to see and do

The Grand Tetons are an imposing mountain range - easily recognizable when flying into Jackson Hole airport. A must visit - give yourself at least a full day. There's lots of turn-ins into this park - essentially all on the road towards Yellowstone if you start out from Jackson Hole/Teton Village and head north. We did one closest to Teton in the southern end called Jenny Lake. Nice easy 3 mile walk from visitor center around the lake to waterfall area. Waterfalls are nice to see. Since we had younger kids, we took the boat back across the lake. No food except at visitor center - definitely carry your own. Visitor area is clean, personnel helpful and the scenery fantastic.

When my sister and I entered the park throught the morth in the late afternoon, we were aware that overcast weather, including the possibility of snow, was predicted for the next 2 days. As we rounded a cruve, there was the most incredible range of peaks with the sun illuminating them from behind. The sight literally brought tears to my eyes! We stopped to take in the magnificent view. As we continued on our journey, we encountered the same peaks from many different angles, each one more dramatic and spectaluar than the last. The next 2 days brought overcast skies, as predicted, and we even got to take the boat across Jenny Lake and hike to Inspiration Point in a steady snowfall. We saw elk, bison, moose, eagles, beavers and a blue heron. But our first view of the mountains was the clearest one we saw
Skip the tram ride in the basin of the village. Not worth the money. Everything else is great.

This is such a wonderful national park- lots of people just drive through it on the way to yellowstone but you must stop. the tetons are amazing especially early in the morning. we were lucky enough to see elk, moose and bear in the Tetons. there are some wonderful walks and our favourite was the Rockafella national perserve, it was so quiet and such a magical walk. my husband and son took the boat across jenny lake and walked up the mountain for an amazing view of the valley. it is also worth finding out about the elk refuge -we would love to come back in the winter for a sleigh ride around it.
review_title: over shadowed by yellowstone but do stop here.

review_body: Great views, great food and atmosphere in the lodge (the fine dinning Resturant). The Jenny Lake ~1 hour hike back from where the boat dropped us is great.
review_title: Grand Teton Park and a quick hike

review_body: In my short experience, Grand Teton has been one of the most memorable outdoor experiences. The Mountains are absolutely gorgeous and the best part is that there are so many places where you can stop and take in the scenery. This was a big plus for me as I am unable to hike, but I didn't feel shortchanged for not being able to go too deep into the wilderness.If you are going to Yellowstone as well, make sure you buy the combo pass and save $$$, I made the mistake of buying passes separately.I was not sure if I wanted to stop by Grand Teton during my latest roadtrip, I was on my way to Yellowstone and thought I could just admire the Mountains from afar. I'm glad I did stop. More on my WY experience at http://tr.im/KAAWY
review_title: A Majestic Treat on the way to Yellowstone

review_body: Unfortunately, we only spent ½ a day hiking on the way to Yellowstone. The scenery (mountains, lakes, wildlife) is breathtaking. We skipped the boat to cross Jenny Lake and decided to hike from String Lake to Jenny Lake’s west shore and up to Hidden Falls. The hike was enjoyable as it ran along the creek that connects the two lakes. After passing the dock and seeing how crowded the boats were I am glad we skipped the ferry. We also hike Schwabacher’s Landing. This was quiet easy hike along Snake River. It provided great views of the mountain range. It was a bite of trek to get to the parking lot so make sure you have a semi-off road vehicle. We definitely want to return and spend more time exploring the park.

Really spectacular views. I can see why so many celebrities live around there. There's so much to talk about, I made a short video describing my experience. Check it out to get a better sense of the place:http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5ZLSvENe9PQ&feature=channel
review_title: Topography doesn’t get much better than this.

review_body: My family and I traveled out west from Illinois...By Car, with gas prices over $4.00/gallon.We were in the area from July 5, 2008 - July 12, 2008. It was one of the best vacations we ever had. We rented a condo in the Aspens just West of Jackson Hole. Easy drive to Jackson Hole, and only a few miles to the entrance of the Grand Teton National Park. Just a perfect spot for getting places.Kids ages 9-16 had a great time. I highly recommend taking a scenic float trip down the Snake River at night. We saw moose, elk, eagles, beaver, and gorgeous scenery. We used Barker/Ewing company to book, and our guide Steve H. was fabulous. He knew so much about the area. It was like sitting around a campfire listening to stories of the West, but actually floating down the river.My older kids rented a kayak at Colter Bay and spent two great hours on Jackson Lake. The views are breathtaking, and there is no way to acurately describe them. You must see for yourselves.Ate 2 times at the Gun Barrel in Jackson. Very good, and great menu for kids. Also Q Roadhouse BBQ. GREAT!, There is a Bagel place in Wilson and Jackson has the name street in it. WOW! Go early morning, they are making bagels on site. My bag I got was hot and the taste was incredible.Jenny Lake is a MUST see/do item also. Take the boat across the lake and hike up to Inspiration Point. Hidden Falls along the path is majestic. Do not miss this one.Worth the drive?? You bet! Worth the price of gas? Absolutely! Am I going back? Passionate about it!

Vacationed in early June '08. Be warned - unfortunately it was unseasonable cold in WY - highs in the 40's a couple days (not high of 69 degrees as stated on weather.com as average). Don't be surprised if it gets cold in early June. We made the best of it and still did most of the activities we had planned. Day 1 Jenny Lake hike to Hidden Falls and Inspiration Point - great hike!!! We did the alpine slide in Jackson in the late afternoon - a bit pricy but the kids loved it. Dinner at Rendezvous café - nice place. Toured Downtown Jackson which is a must. We even did the Stagecoach ride through town which was pretty good. Day 2 Bridger Gondola ride in Teton Village. This was fun. The heavy snow last winter was not yet melted so we were not able to hike much at the top but still was fun - snowball fights in June. We did the 5:30 PM raft trip with Solitude inc. that night and HIGHLY recommend it!!!! We saw a ton of wildlife including a grizzly bear from a distance which I guess is rare in GTNP. A great raft float trip. Oh by the way we stayed at Moulton Valley Cabins which we highly recommend. Secluded, awesome views, good cabins and nice south park location (closer to Jackson). Day 3 The horseback ride at Jackson Lake Lodge was good then we did a general tour of GTNP overlooks and sites.

There are some nice scenic hikes, a few lakes and some limited wildlife viewing. We stayed in park for 4 days, after 4 days in Yellowstone.Some of the so called "attractions" are nothing more than tourist traps.In my opinion, GTNP and YSNP worth a ONE visit, and that is mainly for geological points of Yellowstone. Considering the travel expense and flight time from California, we take any island of Hawaii any day, for their truely unique nature, and visitor-friendly people.

We spent four days at Grand Teton (Jackson Lake Lodge, review posted) and absolutely fell in love with it. Going to Yellowstone afterwards was more "interesting" but less satisfying in many ways. Grand Teton is just simply gorgeous and while there aren't as many "attractions" as Yellowstone, there is so much to see, do and so much to enjoy that I wish we had had a couple more days.Other than the requisite float trip on the Snake River and Horseback Riding, we filled our days with the boat across Jenny Lake and the hike to Inspiration Point which was fantastic (our 9 year old made it only half way but our 11 year old led the way for me up to the Point). We also went on various other smaller hikes. One of our favorite days there was a trip we took out of the park to the area of the Gros Ventre landslide. This has to be seen to be believed. Find Antelope Flats Road and take it out through buffalo filled fields and fantastic scenery and follow the signs to the short trail at Gros Ventre. It was so "off the beaten path" and so beautiful that we all loved it. We also drove through the Teton pass from Jackson Hole into Idaho and then back which was just gorgeous.This place is almost paradise. Yellowstone is more unique and there's more "to do" but coming back through Grand Teton on our way to the airport in Jackson was like coming home. If you're going to Yellowstone, make sure you spend at least two or three days in GT, you won't regret it.
